qTextArr: ['Was anyone hurt?']
qText: Was anyone hurt?
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr:
['No one, I am thankful to say,', 'except two housemaids
who lost their heads and jumped through a glass roof into the paved
court. They were in no danger. The fire never reached the bedrooms, I am
afraid. Still, they are bound to need doing up, everything black with
smoke and drenched in water and luckily they had that old-fashioned sort
of extinguisher that ruins _everything_. One really cannot complain. The
chief rooms were _completely_ gutted and everything was insured. Sylvia
Newport knows the people. I must get on to them this morning before that
ghoul Mrs Shutter snaps them up.']
qText:
No one, I am thankful to say, except two housemaids
who lost their heads and jumped through a glass roof into the paved
court. They were in no danger. The fire never reached the bedrooms, I am
afraid. Still, they are bound to need doing up, everything black with
smoke and drenched in water and luckily they had that old-fashioned sort
of extinguisher that ruins _everything_. One really cannot complain. The
chief rooms were _completely_ gutted and everything was insured. Sylvia
Newport knows the people. I must get on to them this morning before that
ghoul Mrs Shutter snaps them up.
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

qTextArr: ["Heavens, how nasty this stuff is. I wish you'd take to it, John. You're\nlooking so tired lately. I don't know how I should get through my day\nwithout it."]
qText:
Heavens, how nasty this stuff is. I wish you'd take to it, John. You're
looking so tired lately. I don't know how I should get through my day
without it.
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

qTextArr: ["But, mumsy, I haven't as much to do as you have."]
qText: But, mumsy, I haven't as much to do as you have.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["That's true, my son."]
qText: That's true, my son.
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

qTextArr: ['What was your evening?']
qText: What was your evening?
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

qTextArr: ['Audrey rang up at eight and asked me to dinner. Ten of us at the\nEmbassy, rather dreary. Afterwards we all went on to a party given by a\nwoman called de Trommet.']
qText:
Audrey rang up at eight and asked me to dinner. Ten of us at the
Embassy, rather dreary. Afterwards we all went on to a party given by a
woman called de Trommet.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["I know who you mean. American. She hasn't paid for the toile-de-jouy\nchair covers we made her last April. I had a dull time too; didn't hold\na card all the evening and came away four pounds ten to the bad."]
qText:
I know who you mean. American. She hasn't paid for the toile-de-jouy
chair covers we made her last April. I had a dull time too; didn't hold
a card all the evening and came away four pounds ten to the bad.
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

qTextArr: ['Poor mumsy.']
qText: Poor mumsy.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["I'm lunching at Viola Chasm's. What are you doing? I didn't order\nanything here, I'm afraid."]
qText:
I'm lunching at Viola Chasm's. What are you doing? I didn't order
anything here, I'm afraid.
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

qTextArr: ["Nothing so far. I can always go round to Bratt's."]
qText: Nothing so far. I can always go round to Bratt's.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["But that's so expensive. I'm sure if we ask Chambers she'll be able to\nget you something in. I thought you were certain to be out."]
qText:
But that's so expensive. I'm sure if we ask Chambers she'll be able to
get you something in. I thought you were certain to be out.
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

qTextArr: ["Well, I still may be. It isn't twelve yet."]
qText: Well, I still may be. It isn't twelve yet.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["John, darling, there's been a muddle and Sonia has\narrived without Reggie. Could you be an angel and help me out? Only be\nquick, because we're going in now"]
qText:
John, darling, there's been a muddle and Sonia has
arrived without Reggie. Could you be an angel and help me out? Only be
quick, because we're going in now
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

qTextArr: ['Where are you going for the week-end?']
qText: Where are you going for the week-end?
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

qTextArr: ['Hetton.']
qText: Hetton.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["Who's that? I forget."]
qText: Who's that? I forget.
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

qTextArr: ['Tony Last.']
qText: Tony Last.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["Yes, of course. She's lovely, he's rather a stick. I didn't know you\nknew them."]
qText:
Yes, of course. She's lovely, he's rather a stick. I didn't know you
knew them.
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

qTextArr: ["Well, I don't really. Tony asked me in Bratt's the other night. He may\nhave forgotten."]
qText:
Well, I don't really. Tony asked me in Bratt's the other night. He may
have forgotten.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['Send a telegram and remind them. It is far better than ringing up. It\ngives them less chance to make excuses. Send it to-morrow just before\nyou start. They owe me for a table.']
qText:
Send a telegram and remind them. It is far better than ringing up. It
gives them less chance to make excuses. Send it to-morrow just before
you start. They owe me for a table.
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

qTextArr: ["What's their dossier?"]
qText: What's their dossier?
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr:
["I used to see her quite a lot before she married. She was Brenda Rex,
Lord St Cloud's daughter, very fair, underwater look. People used to be
mad about her when she was a girl. Everyone thought she would marry Jock
Grant-Menzies at one time. Wasted on Tony Last, he's a prig. I should
say it was time she began to be bored. They've been married five or six
years. Quite well off but everything goes in keeping up the house. I've
never seen it but I've an idea it's huge and quite hideous. They've got
one child at least, perhaps more."]
qText:
I used to see her quite a lot before she married. She was Brenda Rex,
Lord St Cloud's daughter, very fair, underwater look. People used to be
mad about her when she was a girl. Everyone thought she would marry Jock
Grant-Menzies at one time. Wasted on Tony Last, he's a prig. I should
say it was time she began to be bored. They've been married five or six
years. Quite well off but everything goes in keeping up the house. I've
never seen it but I've an idea it's huge and quite hideous. They've got
one child at least, perhaps more.
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

qTextArr: ['Mumsy, you are wonderful. I believe you know about everyone.']
qText: Mumsy, you are wonderful. I believe you know about everyone.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["It's a great help. All a matter of paying attention while people are\ntalking."]
qText:
It's a great help. All a matter of paying attention while people are
talking.
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

qTextArr: ["That's the way,", "you are doing very nicely, Joyce. I'll soon\nget you on to something more interesting."]
qText:
That's the way, you are doing very nicely, Joyce. I'll soon
get you on to something more interesting.
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

qTextArr: ['Thank you, Mrs Beaver.']
qText: Thank you, Mrs Beaver.
speaker: Joyce

qTextArr: ['Mr\nBeaver? Will you please hold the line, sir, Mrs Tipping would like to\nspeak to you.']
qText:
Mr
Beaver? Will you please hold the line, sir, Mrs Tipping would like to
speak to you.
speaker: Unknowable

qTextArr:
["Oh, Mr Beaver, I _am_ so sorry to trouble you. I was wondering, could
you _possibly_ tell me the name of the young man you introduced to me
last night at Madame de Trommet's? The one with the reddish moustache. I
think he was in Parliament."]
qText:
Oh, Mr Beaver, I _am_ so sorry to trouble you. I was wondering, could
you _possibly_ tell me the name of the young man you introduced to me
last night at Madame de Trommet's? The one with the reddish moustache. I
think he was in Parliament.
speaker: Mrs Tipping
menTexts: [['Mr Beaver', 'you', 'you', 'Madame de Trommet', 'The one with the reddish moustache', 'he']]
menEnts: [[['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['De Trommet'], ['Jock Grant-Menzies'], ['Jock Grant-Menzies']]]

qTextArr: ['I expect you mean Jock Grant-Menzies.']
qText: I expect you mean Jock Grant-Menzies.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["Yes, that's the name. You don't by any chance know where I can find\nhim, do you?"]
qText:
Yes, that's the name. You don't by any chance know where I can find
him, do you?
speaker: Mrs Tipping

qTextArr: ["He's in the book but I don't suppose he'll be at home now. You might be\nable to get him at Bratt's at about one. He's almost always there."]
qText:
He's in the book but I don't suppose he'll be at home now. You might be
able to get him at Bratt's at about one. He's almost always there.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["Jock Grant-Menzies, Bratt's Club. Thank you so _very_ much. It _is_\nkind of you. I hope you will come and see me some day. _Good_-bye."]
qText:
Jock Grant-Menzies, Bratt's Club. Thank you so _very_ much. It _is_
kind of you. I hope you will come and see me some day. _Good_-bye.
speaker: Mrs Tipping

qTextArr: ['Well, old boy,', 'What are you\ndrinking?']
qText:
Well, old boy, What are you
drinking?
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

qTextArr: ['Nothing so far.']
qText: Nothing so far.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["But I think it's time I\nhad one. Brandy and ginger ale."]
qText:
But I think it's time I
had one. Brandy and ginger ale.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['Who was the old girl you wished on me at that party last night?']
qText: Who was the old girl you wished on me at that party last night?
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies
refExp: Jock called to the barman and then said

qTextArr: ["She's called Mrs Tipping."]
qText: She's called Mrs Tipping.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['I thought she might be. That explains it. They gave me a message\ndownstairs that someone with a name like that wanted me to lunch with\nher.']
qText:
I thought she might be. That explains it. They gave me a message
downstairs that someone with a name like that wanted me to lunch with
her.
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

qTextArr: ['Are you going?']
qText: Are you going?
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["No, I'm no good at lunch parties. Besides, I decided when I got up that\nI'd have oysters here."]
qText:
No, I'm no good at lunch parties. Besides, I decided when I got up that
I'd have oysters here.
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

qTextArr: ["Mr Beaver, sir, there's ten shillings against you in my books for last\nmonth."]
qText:
Mr Beaver, sir, there's ten shillings against you in my books for last
month.
speaker: The Barman

qTextArr: ['Ah, thank you, Macdougal, remind me some time, will you?']
qText: Ah, thank you, Macdougal, remind me some time, will you?
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['Very good, sir.']
qText: Very good, sir.
speaker: The Barman

qTextArr: ["I'm going to Hetton to-morrow."]
qText: I'm going to Hetton to-morrow.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['Are you now? Give Tony and Brenda my love.']
qText: Are you now? Give Tony and Brenda my love.
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

qTextArr: ["What's the form?"]
qText: What's the form?
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['Very quiet and enjoyable.']
qText: Very quiet and enjoyable.
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

qTextArr: ['No paper games?']
qText: No paper games?
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['Oh, no, nothing like that. A certain amount of bridge and backgammon\nand low poker with the neighbours.']
qText:
Oh, no, nothing like that. A certain amount of bridge and backgammon
and low poker with the neighbours.
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

qTextArr: ['Comfortable?']
qText: Comfortable?
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['Not bad. Plenty to drink. Rather a shortage of bathrooms. You can stay\nin bed all the morning.']
qText:
Not bad. Plenty to drink. Rather a shortage of bathrooms. You can stay
in bed all the morning.
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

qTextArr: ["I've never met Brenda."]
qText: I've never met Brenda.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["You'll like her, she's a grand girl. I often think Tony Last's one of\nthe happiest men I know. He's got just enough money, loves the place,\none son he's crazy about, devoted wife, not a worry in the world."]
qText:
You'll like her, she's a grand girl. I often think Tony Last's one of
the happiest men I know. He's got just enough money, loves the place,
one son he's crazy about, devoted wife, not a worry in the world.
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

qTextArr: ["Most enviable. You don't know anyone else who's going, do you? I was\nwondering if I could get a lift down there."]
qText:
Most enviable. You don't know anyone else who's going, do you? I was
wondering if I could get a lift down there.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["I don't, I'm afraid. It's quite easy by train."]
qText: I don't, I'm afraid. It's quite easy by train.
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

qTextArr: ["Yes, but it's more pleasant by road."]
qText: Yes, but it's more pleasant by road.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['And cheaper.']
qText: And cheaper.
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

qTextArr: ["Yes, and cheaper I suppose... well, I'm going down to lunch. You won't\nhave another?"]
qText:
Yes, and cheaper I suppose... well, I'm going down to lunch. You won't
have another?
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['Yes, I think I will.']
qText: Yes, I think I will.
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

qTextArr: ['Oh, all right. Macdougal. Two more, please.']
qText: Oh, all right. Macdougal. Two more, please.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['Shall I book them to you, sir?']
qText: Shall I book them to you, sir?
speaker: The Barman

qTextArr: ['Yes, if you will.']
qText: Yes, if you will.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['I made Beaver pay for a drink.']
qText: I made Beaver pay for a drink.
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

qTextArr: ["He can't have liked that."]
qText: He can't have liked that.
speaker: Unknowable

qTextArr: ['He nearly died of it. Know anything about pigs?']
qText: He nearly died of it. Know anything about pigs?
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

qTextArr: ['No. Why.']
qText: No. Why.
speaker: Unknowable

qTextArr: ['Only that they keep writing to me about them from my constituency.']
qText: Only that they keep writing to me about them from my constituency.
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

qTextArr: ['Mrs Tipping rang up a few minutes ago and asked whether you could come\nto luncheon with her to-day.']
qText:
Mrs Tipping rang up a few minutes ago and asked whether you could come
to luncheon with her to-day.
speaker: The Porter

qTextArr: ['Will you ring her up and say that I shall be delighted to, but that I\nmay be a few minutes late?']
qText:
Will you ring her up and say that I shall be delighted to, but that I
may be a few minutes late?
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['Has her ladyship been called yet?']
qText: Has her ladyship been called yet?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Then I'll have breakfast in her room."]
qText: Then I'll have breakfast in her room.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Well?']
qText: Well?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Kiss.']
qText: Kiss.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Anything interesting?']
qText: Anything interesting?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["No. Mama wants nanny to send John's measurements. She's knitting him\nsomething for Christmas. And the mayor wants me to open something next\nmonth. I needn't, need I?"]
qText:
No. Mama wants nanny to send John's measurements. She's knitting him
something for Christmas. And the mayor wants me to open something next
month. I needn't, need I?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["I think you'd better, we haven't done anything for him for a long\ntime."]
qText:
I think you'd better, we haven't done anything for him for a long
time.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Well, you must write the speech. I'm getting too old for the girlish\none I used to give them all. And Angela says, will we stay for the New\nYear?"]
qText:
Well, you must write the speech. I'm getting too old for the girlish
one I used to give them all. And Angela says, will we stay for the New
Year?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["That's easy. Not on her life, we won't."]
qText: That's easy. Not on her life, we won't.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['I guessed not... though it sounds an amusing party.']
qText: I guessed not... though it sounds an amusing party.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["You go if you like. I can't possibly get away."]
qText: You go if you like. I can't possibly get away.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['That\'s all right. I knew it would be "no" before I opened the letter.']
qText: That's all right. I knew it would be "no" before I opened the letter.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Well, what sort of pleasure can there be in going all the way to\nYorkshire in the middle of winter?']
qText:
Well, what sort of pleasure can there be in going all the way to
Yorkshire in the middle of winter?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Darling, don't be cross. I know we aren't going. I'm not making a thing\nabout it. I just thought it might be fun to eat someone else's food for\na bit."]
qText:
Darling, don't be cross. I know we aren't going. I'm not making a thing
about it. I just thought it might be fun to eat someone else's food for
a bit.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['As a matter of fact I probably _can_ manage to get away that\nweek-end.']
qText:
As a matter of fact I probably _can_ manage to get away that
week-end.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Darling, are you sure you wouldn't hate it?"]
qText: Darling, are you sure you wouldn't hate it?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['I daresay not.']
qText: I daresay not.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr:
["Reggie's
been making another speech... There's such an extraordinary picture of
Babe and Jock... a woman in America has had twins by two different
husbands. Would you have thought that possible?... Two more chaps in
gas ovens... a little girl has been strangled in a cemetery with a
bootlace... that play we went to about a farm is coming off.", "I don't believe you're listening.
Why doesn't Sylvia want Rupert to get the letter?"]
qText:
Reggie's
been making another speech... There's such an extraordinary picture of
Babe and Jock... a woman in America has had twins by two different
husbands. Would you have thought that possible?... Two more chaps in
gas ovens... a little girl has been strangled in a cemetery with a
bootlace... that play we went to about a farm is coming off. I don't believe you're listening.
Why doesn't Sylvia want Rupert to get the letter?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["Eh? Oh well, you see, she doesn't really trust Rupert."]
qText: Eh? Oh well, you see, she doesn't really trust Rupert.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["I _knew_ it. There's no such character as Rupert in the story. I shall\nnever read to you again."]
qText:
I _knew_ it. There's no such character as Rupert in the story. I shall
never read to you again.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Well, to tell you the truth I was just thinking.']
qText: Well, to tell you the truth I was just thinking.
speaker: Tony Last

qText: Oh.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["I was thinking how delightful it is, that it's Saturday morning and we\nhaven't got anyone coming for the week-end."]
qText:
I was thinking how delightful it is, that it's Saturday morning and we
haven't got anyone coming for the week-end.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Oh, you thought that?']
qText: Oh, you thought that?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["Don't you?"]
qText: Don't you?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Well, it sometimes seems to me rather pointless keeping up a house this\nsize if we don't now and then ask some other people to stay in it."]
qText:
Well, it sometimes seems to me rather pointless keeping up a house this
size if we don't now and then ask some other people to stay in it.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr:
["_Pointless?_ I can't think what you mean. I don't keep up this house to
be a hostel for a lot of bores to come and gossip in. We've always lived
here and I hope John will be able to keep it on after me. One has a duty
towards one's employees, and towards the place too. It's a definite part
of English life which would be a serious loss if..."]
qText:
_Pointless?_ I can't think what you mean. I don't keep up this house to
be a hostel for a lot of bores to come and gossip in. We've always lived
here and I hope John will be able to keep it on after me. One has a duty
towards one's employees, and towards the place too. It's a definite part
of English life which would be a serious loss if...
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Oh God,', 'What have I done?']
qText: Oh God, What have I done?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['I say, am I being pompous again?']
qText: I say, am I being pompous again?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Oh no,\ndarling, not _pompous_. You wouldn't know how."]
qText:
Oh no,
darling, not _pompous_. You wouldn't know how.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Sorry.']
qText: Sorry.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["And, please, I didn't mean it. I'm jolly glad too, that\nno one's coming."]
qText:
And, please, I didn't mean it. I'm jolly glad too, that
no one's coming.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["Now take it quite easy. Canter up slow and when she takes off lean\nforward in the saddle and you'll be over like a bird. Keep her head\nstraight at it."]
qText:
Now take it quite easy. Canter up slow and when she takes off lean
forward in the saddle and you'll be over like a bird. Keep her head
straight at it.
speaker: Ben

qTextArr: ["What\nd'you suppose your bloody legs are for? Here, take this and just give\nher a tap when you get up to it!"]
qText:
What
d'you suppose your bloody legs are for? Here, take this and just give
her a tap when you get up to it!
speaker: Ben

qTextArr: ['Legs!']
qText: Legs!
speaker: Ben

qTextArr: ["Oh, what's happened, Mr Hacket, is he hurt?"]
qText: Oh, what's happened, Mr Hacket, is he hurt?
speaker: Nanny

qTextArr: ["He's all right,"]
qText: He's all right,
speaker: Ben

qTextArr: ["I'm all right,", 'I think she put in a short step.']
qText: I'm all right, I think she put in a short step.
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ['Short step my grandmother. You just opened your bloody legs and took an\narser. Keep hold on to the reins next time. You can lose a hunt that\nway.']
qText:
Short step my grandmother. You just opened your bloody legs and took an
arser. Keep hold on to the reins next time. You can lose a hunt that
way.
speaker: Ben

qTextArr: ['There, how did that feel? You just skimmed over like a swallow. Try it\nagain?']
qText:
There, how did that feel? You just skimmed over like a swallow. Try it
again?
speaker: Ben

qTextArr: ['Oh dear, look at all the mud on your\ncoat.']
qText:
Oh dear, look at all the mud on your
coat.
speaker: Nanny

qTextArr: ["We'll have you riding the winner at Aintree soon."]
qText: We'll have you riding the winner at Aintree soon.
speaker: Ben

qTextArr: ['Good morning, Mr Hacket.']
qText: Good morning, Mr Hacket.
speaker: Nanny

qTextArr: ['Good morning, miss.']
qText: Good morning, miss.
speaker: Ben

qTextArr: ['Good-bye, Ben, may I come and see you doing the farm horses this\nevening?']
qText:
Good-bye, Ben, may I come and see you doing the farm horses this
evening?
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ["That's not for me to say. You must ask nanny. Tell you what though, the\ngrey carthorse has got worms. Would you like to see me give him a pill?"]
qText:
That's not for me to say. You must ask nanny. Tell you what though, the
grey carthorse has got worms. Would you like to see me give him a pill?
speaker: Ben

qTextArr: ['Oh yes; please, nanny, may I?']
qText: Oh yes; please, nanny, may I?
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ["You must ask mother. Come along now, you've had quite enough of horses\nfor one day."]
qText:
You must ask mother. Come along now, you've had quite enough of horses
for one day.
speaker: Nanny

qTextArr: ["Can't have enough of horses,", 'ever.']
qText: Can't have enough of horses, ever.
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ["Can I have my milk in mummy's room?"]
qText: Can I have my milk in mummy's room?
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ['That depends.']
qText: That depends.
speaker: Nanny

qTextArr: ["We'll see"]
qText: We'll see
speaker: Nanny

qTextArr: ["That's\nasking"]
qText:
That's
asking
speaker: Nanny

qTextArr: ['Those that ask no questions hear no lies']
qText: Those that ask no questions hear no lies
speaker: Nanny

qTextArr: ['What does it depend on?']
qText: What does it depend on?
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ['Lots of things.']
qText: Lots of things.
speaker: Nanny

qTextArr: ['Tell me one of them.']
qText: Tell me one of them.
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ['On your not asking a lot of silly questions.']
qText: On your not asking a lot of silly questions.
speaker: Nanny

qTextArr: ['Silly old tart.']
qText: Silly old tart.
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ['_John!_ How dare you? What do you mean?']
qText: _John!_ How dare you? What do you mean?
speaker: Nanny

qTextArr: ['Silly old tart, silly old tart']
qText: Silly old tart, silly old tart
speaker: John Andrew
refExp: John broke away from her hand and danced in front of her saying

qTextArr: ['Go straight up to the nursery,', 'I am going to speak to your\nmother about you.']
qText:
Go straight up to the nursery, I am going to speak to your
mother about you.
speaker: Nanny

qTextArr: ["Please, nanny. I don't know what it means, but I didn't mean it."]
qText: Please, nanny. I don't know what it means, but I didn't mean it.
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ['Go straight to the nursery.']
qText: Go straight to the nursery.
speaker: Nanny

qTextArr: ["It's been the same ever since Ben Hacket started teaching him to ride,\nmy lady, there's been no doing anything with him."]
qText:
It's been the same ever since Ben Hacket started teaching him to ride,
my lady, there's been no doing anything with him.
speaker: Nanny

qTextArr: ['But, nanny, what exactly did he say?']
qText: But, nanny, what exactly did he say?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["Oh, I couldn't repeat it, my lady."]
qText: Oh, I couldn't repeat it, my lady.
speaker: Nanny

qTextArr: ['Nonsense, you must tell me. Otherwise I shall be thinking it something\nfar worse than it was.']
qText:
Nonsense, you must tell me. Otherwise I shall be thinking it something
far worse than it was.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["It couldn't have been worse... he called me a silly old tart, my\nlady."]
qText:
It couldn't have been worse... he called me a silly old tart, my
lady.
speaker: Nanny

qTextArr: ['He said _that_?']
qText: He said _that_?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Repeatedly. He danced in front of me all the way up the drive, _singing\nit_.']
qText:
Repeatedly. He danced in front of me all the way up the drive, _singing
it_.
speaker: Nanny

qTextArr: ['I see... well, you were quite right to tell me.']
qText: I see... well, you were quite right to tell me.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr:
["Thank you, my lady, and since we are talking about it I think I ought
to say that it seems to me that Ben Hacket is making the child go ahead
far too quickly with his riding. It's very dangerous. He had what might
have been a serious fall this morning."]
qText:
Thank you, my lady, and since we are talking about it I think I ought
to say that it seems to me that Ben Hacket is making the child go ahead
far too quickly with his riding. It's very dangerous. He had what might
have been a serious fall this morning.
speaker: Nanny

qTextArr: ["All right, nanny, I'll speak to Mr Last about it."]
qText: All right, nanny, I'll speak to Mr Last about it.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Darling,', "_you_ must speak to him. You're so much better at being\nserious than I am."]
qText:
Darling, _you_ must speak to him. You're so much better at being
serious than I am.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['I should have thought it was very nice to be called a tart,', "and anyway it's a word Ben often uses about people."]
qText: I should have thought it was very nice to be called a tart, and anyway it's a word Ben often uses about people.
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ["Well, he's got no business to."]
qText: Well, he's got no business to.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["I like Ben more than anyone in the world. And I should think he's\ncleverer too."]
qText:
I like Ben more than anyone in the world. And I should think he's
cleverer too.
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ["Now, you know you don't like him more than your mother."]
qText: Now, you know you don't like him more than your mother.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Yes I do. _Far_ more.']
qText: Yes I do. _Far_ more.
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ['Now listen, John. It was very wrong\nof you to call nanny a silly old tart. First, because it was unkind to\nher. Think of all the things she does for you every day.']
qText:
Now listen, John. It was very wrong
of you to call nanny a silly old tart. First, because it was unkind to
her. Think of all the things she does for you every day.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["She's paid to."]
qText: She's paid to.
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr:
['Be quiet. And secondly, because you were using a word which people of
your age and class do not use. Poor people use certain expressions which
gentlemen do not. You are a gentleman. When you grow up all this house
and lots of other things besides will belong to you. You must learn to
speak like someone who is going to have these things and to be
considerate to people less fortunate than you, particularly women. Do
you understand?']
qText:
Be quiet. And secondly, because you were using a word which people of
your age and class do not use. Poor people use certain expressions which
gentlemen do not. You are a gentleman. When you grow up all this house
and lots of other things besides will belong to you. You must learn to
speak like someone who is going to have these things and to be
considerate to people less fortunate than you, particularly women. Do
you understand?
speaker: Tony Last
menEnts: [[['John Andrew'], ['John Last'], ['John Andrew'], ['John Andrew'], ['John Andrew'], ['John Andrew'], ['John Andrew'], ['John Last']]]

qTextArr: ['Is Ben less fortunate than me?']
qText: Is Ben less fortunate than me?
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ['That has nothing to do with it. Now you are to go upstairs and say you\nare sorry to nanny and promise never to use that word about anyone\nagain.']
qText:
That has nothing to do with it. Now you are to go upstairs and say you
are sorry to nanny and promise never to use that word about anyone
again.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['All right.']
qText: All right.
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ['And because you have been so naughty to-day you are not to ride\nto-morrow.']
qText:
And because you have been so naughty to-day you are not to ride
to-morrow.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["To-morrow's Sunday."]
qText: To-morrow's Sunday.
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ['Well, next day then.']
qText: Well, next day then.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['But you said']
qText: But you said
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ["It isn't fair to change now."]
qText: It isn't fair to change now.
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ["John, don't argue. If you are not careful I shall send Thunderclap back\nto Uncle Reggie and say that I find you are not a good enough boy to\nkeep it. You wouldn't like that, would you?"]
qText:
John, don't argue. If you are not careful I shall send Thunderclap back
to Uncle Reggie and say that I find you are not a good enough boy to
keep it. You wouldn't like that, would you?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["What would Uncle Reggie do with her? She couldn't carry him. Besides,\nhe's usually abroad."]
qText:
What would Uncle Reggie do with her? She couldn't carry him. Besides,
he's usually abroad.
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ["He'd give her to some other little boy. Anyway, that's got nothing to\ndo with it. Now run off and say you're sorry to nanny."]
qText:
He'd give her to some other little boy. Anyway, that's got nothing to
do with it. Now run off and say you're sorry to nanny.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["It's all right riding on Monday, isn't it? You\ndid _say_"]
qText:
It's all right riding on Monday, isn't it? You
did _say_
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ['Yes, I suppose so.']
qText: Yes, I suppose so.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Hooray. Thunderclap went very well to-day. We jumped a big post and\nrail. She refused first time but went like a bird after that.']
qText:
Hooray. Thunderclap went very well to-day. We jumped a big post and
rail. She refused first time but went like a bird after that.
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ["Didn't you come off?"]
qText: Didn't you come off?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Yes, once. It wasn't Thunderclap's fault. I just opened my bloody legs\nand cut an arser."]
qText:
Yes, once. It wasn't Thunderclap's fault. I just opened my bloody legs
and cut an arser.
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ['How did the lecture go?']
qText: How did the lecture go?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Bad. Rotten bad.']
qText: Bad. Rotten bad.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["The trouble is that nanny's jealous of Ben."]
qText: The trouble is that nanny's jealous of Ben.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["I'm not sure we shan't both be soon."]
qText: I'm not sure we shan't both be soon.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["I'm sure it does me a great deal of good."]
qText: I'm sure it does me a great deal of good.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr:
['Yes, darling, and when we get tired of it we might try an alphabetical
diet, having things beginning with a different letter every day. J would
be hungry, nothing but jam and jellied eels... What are your plans for
the afternoon?']
qText:
Yes, darling, and when we get tired of it we might try an alphabetical
diet, having things beginning with a different letter every day. J would
be hungry, nothing but jam and jellied eels... What are your plans for
the afternoon?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr:
["Nothing much. Carter's coming up at five to go over a few things. I may
go to Pigstanton after luncheon. I think we've got a tenant for Lowater
Farm but it's been empty some time and I ought to see how much needs
doing to it."]
qText:
Nothing much. Carter's coming up at five to go over a few things. I may
go to Pigstanton after luncheon. I think we've got a tenant for Lowater
Farm but it's been empty some time and I ought to see how much needs
doing to it.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['I wouldn\'t say "no" to going in to the "movies".']
qText: I wouldn't say "no" to going in to the "movies".
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['All right. I can easily leave Lowater till Monday.']
qText: All right. I can easily leave Lowater till Monday.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["And we might go to Woolworth's afterwards, eh?"]
qText: And we might go to Woolworth's afterwards, eh?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Hell.']
qText: Hell.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Badders?']
qText: Badders?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Something too horrible has happened. Look at this.']
qText: Something too horrible has happened. Look at this.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["What's Beaver?"]
qText: What's Beaver?
speaker: Brenda
refExp: Brenda read Arriving 318 so looking forward visit Beaver And asked

qTextArr: ["It's a young man."]
qText: It's a young man.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['That sounds all right.']
qText: That sounds all right.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["Oh no it's not. Wait till you see him."]
qText: Oh no it's not. Wait till you see him.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["What's he coming here for? Did you ask him to stay?"]
qText: What's he coming here for? Did you ask him to stay?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["I suppose I did in a vague kind of way. I went to Bratt's one evening\nand he was the only chap there so we had some drinks and he said\nsomething about wanting to see the house..."]
qText:
I suppose I did in a vague kind of way. I went to Bratt's one evening
and he was the only chap there so we had some drinks and he said
something about wanting to see the house...
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['I suppose you were tight.']
qText: I suppose you were tight.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["Not really, but I never thought he'd hold it against me."]
qText: Not really, but I never thought he'd hold it against me.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Well, it jolly well serves you right. That's what comes of going up to\nLondon on business and leaving me alone here... Who is he anyway?"]
qText:
Well, it jolly well serves you right. That's what comes of going up to
London on business and leaving me alone here... Who is he anyway?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Just a young man. His mother keeps that shop.']
qText: Just a young man. His mother keeps that shop.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["I used to know her. She's hell. Come to think of it we owe her some\nmoney."]
qText:
I used to know her. She's hell. Come to think of it we owe her some
money.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["Look here, we must put a call through and say we're ill."]
qText: Look here, we must put a call through and say we're ill.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr:
["Too late, he's in the train now, recklessly mixing starch and protein
in the Great Western three and sixpenny lunch... Anyway, he can go into
Galahad. No one who sleeps there ever comes again--the bed's agony I
believe."]
qText:
Too late, he's in the train now, recklessly mixing starch and protein
in the Great Western three and sixpenny lunch... Anyway, he can go into
Galahad. No one who sleeps there ever comes again--the bed's agony I
believe.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["What on earth are we going to do with him? It's too late to get anyone\nelse."]
qText:
What on earth are we going to do with him? It's too late to get anyone
else.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr:
["You go over to Pigstanton. I'll look after him. It's easier alone. We
can take him to the movies to-night, and to-morrow he can see over the
house. If we're lucky he may go up by the evening train. Does he have to
work on Monday morning?"]
qText:
You go over to Pigstanton. I'll look after him. It's easier alone. We
can take him to the movies to-night, and to-morrow he can see over the
house. If we're lucky he may go up by the evening train. Does he have to
work on Monday morning?
speaker: Brenda
menEnts: [[['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['Brenda', 'Tony Last'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver']]]

qTextArr: ["I shouldn't know."]
qText: I shouldn't know.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr:
["It is nice that you
were able to come. I must break it to you at once that we haven't got a
party. I'm afraid you'll be terribly bored... Tony had to go out but
he'll be in soon... was the train crowded? It often is on Saturdays...
would you like to come outside? It'll be dark soon and we might get some
of the sun while we can..."]
qText:
It is nice that you
were able to come. I must break it to you at once that we haven't got a
party. I'm afraid you'll be terribly bored... Tony had to go out but
he'll be in soon... was the train crowded? It often is on Saturdays...
would you like to come outside? It'll be dark soon and we might get some
of the sun while we can...
speaker: Brenda
menEnts: [[['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['Brenda', 'Tony Last'], ['John Beaver'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony'], ['John Beaver'], ['Brenda'], ['Brenda']]]

qTextArr: ['Polly Cockpurse is having one soon.']
qText: Polly Cockpurse is having one soon.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['Yes, I know.']
qText: Yes, I know.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Are you coming up for it?']
qText: Are you coming up for it?
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["I don't expect so. We never go anywhere nowadays."]
qText: I don't expect so. We never go anywhere nowadays.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["What's happening to Mary and Simon?"]
qText: What's happening to Mary and Simon?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["Oh, didn't you know? That's broken up."]
qText: Oh, didn't you know? That's broken up.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['When?']
qText: When?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['It began in Austria this summer...']
qText: It began in Austria this summer...
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['And Billy Angmering?']
qText: And Billy Angmering?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["He's having a terrific walk out with a girl called Sheila Shrub."]
qText: He's having a terrific walk out with a girl called Sheila Shrub.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['And the Helm-Hubbards?']
qText: And the Helm-Hubbards?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["That marriage isn't going too well either... Daisy has started a new\nrestaurant. It's going very well... and there's a new night club called\nthe Warren..."]
qText:
That marriage isn't going too well either... Daisy has started a new
restaurant. It's going very well... and there's a new night club called
the Warren...
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['Dear me,', 'What fun everyone seems to be having.']
qText: Dear me, What fun everyone seems to be having.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['How do you do?', "I didn't know you were coming.\nDaddy said he had a week-end to himself for once. Do you hunt?"]
qText:
How do you do? I didn't know you were coming.
Daddy said he had a week-end to himself for once. Do you hunt?
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ['Not for a long time.']
qText: Not for a long time.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['Ben says it stands to reason everyone ought to hunt who can afford to,\nfor the good of the country.']
qText:
Ben says it stands to reason everyone ought to hunt who can afford to,
for the good of the country.
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ["Perhaps I can't afford to."]
qText: Perhaps I can't afford to.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['Are you poor?']
qText: Are you poor?
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ["Please, Mr Beaver, you mustn't let him bore you."]
qText: Please, Mr Beaver, you mustn't let him bore you.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Yes, very poor.']
qText: Yes, very poor.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['Poor enough to call people tarts?']
qText: Poor enough to call people tarts?
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ['Yes, quite poor enough.']
qText: Yes, quite poor enough.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['How did you get poor?']
qText: How did you get poor?
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ['I always have been.']
qText: I always have been.
speaker: John Beaver

qText: Oh.
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ['The grey horse at the farm has\ngot worms.']
qText:
The grey horse at the farm has
got worms.
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ['How do you know?']
qText: How do you know?
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["Ben says so. Besides, you've only got to look at his dung."]
qText: Ben says so. Besides, you've only got to look at his dung.
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ['Oh dear,', 'what would nanny say if she heard you talking\nlike that?']
qText:
Oh dear, what would nanny say if she heard you talking
like that?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['How old are you?']
qText: How old are you?
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ['Twenty-five. How old are you?']
qText: Twenty-five. How old are you?
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['What do you do?']
qText: What do you do?
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ['Nothing much.']
qText: Nothing much.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["Well, if I was you I'd do something and earn some money. Then you'd be\nable to hunt."]
qText:
Well, if I was you I'd do something and earn some money. Then you'd be
able to hunt.
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ["But I shouldn't be able to call people tarts."]
qText: But I shouldn't be able to call people tarts.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["I don't see any point in that anyway."]
qText: I don't see any point in that anyway.
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ["I\nthink Mr Beaver's a very silly man, don't you?"]
qText:
I
think Mr Beaver's a very silly man, don't you?
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ["I'm sure I don't know,"]
qText: I'm sure I don't know,
speaker: Nanny

qTextArr: ["I think he's the silliest man who's ever been here."]
qText: I think he's the silliest man who's ever been here.
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ['Comparisons are odious.']
qText: Comparisons are odious.
speaker: Nanny

qTextArr: ["There just isn't anything nice about him. He's got a silly voice and a\nsilly face, silly eyes and silly nose,"]
qText:
There just isn't anything nice about him. He's got a silly voice and a
silly face, silly eyes and silly nose,
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ['silly feet and silly toes, silly head and silly\nclothes...']
qText:
silly feet and silly toes, silly head and silly
clothes...
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ['Now you eat up your supper,']
qText: Now you eat up your supper,
speaker: Nanny

qTextArr: ['I feel rather guilty about Beaver--going off and leaving you like that.\nYou were heavenly to him.']
qText:
I feel rather guilty about Beaver--going off and leaving you like that.
You were heavenly to him.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Oh, it wasn't bad really. He's rather pathetic."]
qText: Oh, it wasn't bad really. He's rather pathetic.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['I hope you sleep well.']
qText: I hope you sleep well.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["I'm sure I shall."]
qText: I'm sure I shall.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["D'you like to be called in the morning?"]
qText: D'you like to be called in the morning?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['May I ring?']
qText: May I ring?
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['Certainly. Got everything you want?']
qText: Certainly. Got everything you want?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Yes, thanks. Good night.']
qText: Yes, thanks. Good night.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['Good night.']
qText: Good night.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['You know, I feel awful about Beaver.']
qText: You know, I feel awful about Beaver.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Oh, Beaver's all right,"]
qText: Oh, Beaver's all right,
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['I hope you slept all right?']
qText: I hope you slept all right?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Beautifully,']
qText: Beautifully,
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["I'm so glad. I always sleep well here myself. I say, I don't like the\nlook of that train guide. I hope you weren't thinking of leaving us\nyet?"]
qText:
I'm so glad. I always sleep well here myself. I say, I don't like the
look of that train guide. I hope you weren't thinking of leaving us
yet?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Alas, I've got to get up to-night, I'm afraid."]
qText: Alas, I've got to get up to-night, I'm afraid.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["Too bad. I've hardly seen you. The trains aren't very good on Sundays.\nThe best leaves at five-forty-five and gets up about nine. It stops a\nlot and there's no restaurant car."]
qText:
Too bad. I've hardly seen you. The trains aren't very good on Sundays.
The best leaves at five-forty-five and gets up about nine. It stops a
lot and there's no restaurant car.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["That'll do fine."]
qText: That'll do fine.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["Sure you can't stay until to-morrow?"]
qText: Sure you can't stay until to-morrow?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Quite sure.']
qText: Quite sure.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["Well, I'm just off to church. I don't suppose you'd care to come."]
qText: Well, I'm just off to church. I don't suppose you'd care to come.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Oh yes, I should\nlike to very much.']
qText:
Oh yes, I should
like to very much.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["No, really, I shouldn't if I were you. You wouldn't enjoy it. I only go\nbecause I more or less have to. You stay here. Brenda will be down\ndirectly. Ring for a drink when you feel like it."]
qText:
No, really, I shouldn't if I were you. You wouldn't enjoy it. I only go
because I more or less have to. You stay here. Brenda will be down
directly. Ring for a drink when you feel like it.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Oh, all right.']
qText: Oh, all right.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['See you later then.']
qText: See you later then.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['How very sad.']
qText: How very sad.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Well, _I_ thought it was sad too, but it isn't. Ben said it made him\nlaugh fit to bust his pants."]
qText:
Well, _I_ thought it was sad too, but it isn't. Ben said it made him
laugh fit to bust his pants.
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr:
['...And so as we stand here bareheaded at this solemn hour of the
week,', 'let
us remember our Gracious Queen Empress in whose service we are here, and
pray that she may long be spared to send us at her bidding to do our
duty in the uttermost parts of the earth; and let us think of our dear
ones far away and the homes we have left in her name, and remember that
though miles of barren continent and leagues of ocean divide us, we are
never so near to them as on these Sunday mornings, united with them
across dune and mountain in our loyalty to our sovereign and
thanksgiving for her welfare; one with them as proud subjects of her
sceptre and crown.']
qText:
...And so as we stand here bareheaded at this solemn hour of the
week, let
us remember our Gracious Queen Empress in whose service we are here, and
pray that she may long be spared to send us at her bidding to do our
duty in the uttermost parts of the earth; and let us think of our dear
ones far away and the homes we have left in her name, and remember that
though miles of barren continent and leagues of ocean divide us, we are
never so near to them as on these Sunday mornings, united with them
across dune and mountain in our loyalty to our sovereign and
thanksgiving for her welfare; one with them as proud subjects of her
sceptre and crown.
speaker: The Vicar

qTextArr: ['The Reverend Tendril "e do speak uncommon "igh of the Queen,']
qText: The Reverend Tendril "e do speak uncommon "igh of the Queen,
speaker: A Gardener'S Wife
refExp: a gardeners wife had once remarked to Tony

qTextArr: ['Lady Brenda is not ill, I hope?']
qText: Lady Brenda is not ill, I hope?
speaker: The Vicar

qTextArr: ['No, nothing serious.']
qText: No, nothing serious.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['A most interesting sermon, Vicar.']
qText: A most interesting sermon, Vicar.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["My dear boy, I'm delighted to hear you say so. It is one of my\nfavourites. But have you never heard it before?"]
qText:
My dear boy, I'm delighted to hear you say so. It is one of my
favourites. But have you never heard it before?
speaker: The Vicar

qTextArr: ['No, I assure you.']
qText: No, I assure you.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["I haven't used it here lately. When I am asked to supply elsewhere it\nis the one I invariably choose. Let me see now, I always make a note of\nthe times I use it."]
qText:
I haven't used it here lately. When I am asked to supply elsewhere it
is the one I invariably choose. Let me see now, I always make a note of
the times I use it.
speaker: The Vicar

qTextArr:
["Ah yes, here we are. I preached it first in Jellalabad when the
Coldstream Guards were there; then I used it in the Red Sea coming home
from my fourth leave; then at Sidmouth... Mentone... Winchester... to
the Girl Guides at their summer rally in 1921... the Church Stage Guild
at Leicester... twice at Bournemouth during the winter of 1926 when
poor Ada was so ill... No, I don't seem to have used it here since
1911, when you would have been too young to enjoy it..."]
qText:
Ah yes, here we are. I preached it first in Jellalabad when the
Coldstream Guards were there; then I used it in the Red Sea coming home
from my fourth leave; then at Sidmouth... Mentone... Winchester... to
the Girl Guides at their summer rally in 1921... the Church Stage Guild
at Leicester... twice at Bournemouth during the winter of 1926 when
poor Ada was so ill... No, I don't seem to have used it here since
1911, when you would have been too young to enjoy it...
speaker: The Vicar

qTextArr: ["...he'd have been all right, Ben says,\nif he had been able to cat the rum up, but mules can't cat, neither\ncan horses..."]
qText:
...he'd have been all right, Ben says,
if he had been able to cat the rum up, but mules can't cat, neither
can horses...
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr:
['How many times
have I told you not to go repeating whatever Ben Hacket tells you? Miss
Tendril didn't want to hear about Peppermint. And don't ever use that
rude word "cat" again.']
qText:
How many times
have I told you not to go repeating whatever Ben Hacket tells you? Miss
Tendril didn't want to hear about Peppermint. And don't ever use that
rude word "cat" again.
speaker: Nanny

qTextArr: ['It only means to be sick.']
qText: It only means to be sick.
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ["Well, Miss Tendril isn't interested in being sick..."]
qText: Well, Miss Tendril isn't interested in being sick...
speaker: Nanny

qTextArr: ["I say, can't I carry something?"]
qText: I say, can't I carry something?
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["No thanks, I've got everything safe. How did you sleep?"]
qText: No thanks, I've got everything safe. How did you sleep?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Beautifully.']
qText: Beautifully.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["I bet you didn't."]
qText: I bet you didn't.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["Well, I'm not a very good sleeper."]
qText: Well, I'm not a very good sleeper.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr:
["Next time you come you shall have a different room. But I daresay you
won't ever come again. People so seldom do. It is very sad because it's
such fun for us having them and we never make any new friends living
down here."]
qText:
Next time you come you shall have a different room. But I daresay you
won't ever come again. People so seldom do. It is very sad because it's
such fun for us having them and we never make any new friends living
down here.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["Tony's gone to church."]
qText: Tony's gone to church.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["Yes, he likes that. He'll be back soon. Let's go out for a minute or\ntwo, it looks lovely."]
qText:
Yes, he likes that. He'll be back soon. Let's go out for a minute or
two, it looks lovely.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr:
['... Now cut to me again,', "and I'll see if it's any clearer... Oh yes... there is going to be a
sudden death which will cause you great pleasure and profit. In fact you
are going to kill someone. I can't tell if it's a man or a woman...
yes, a woman... then you are going to go on a long journey across the
sea, marry six dark men and have eleven children, grow a beard and die."]
qText:
... Now cut to me again, and I'll see if it's any clearer... Oh yes... there is going to be a
sudden death which will cause you great pleasure and profit. In fact you
are going to kill someone. I can't tell if it's a man or a woman...
yes, a woman... then you are going to go on a long journey across the
sea, marry six dark men and have eleven children, grow a beard and die.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["Beast. And all this time I've been thinking it was serious. Hullo,\nTony. Jolly church?"]
qText:
Beast. And all this time I've been thinking it was serious. Hullo,
Tony. Jolly church?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Most enjoyable; how about some sherry?']
qText: Most enjoyable; how about some sherry?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Darling,\nyou're being heroic with Beaver."]
qText:
Darling,
you're being heroic with Beaver.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Oh, I quite enjoy coping--in fact I'm bitching him rather."]
qText: Oh, I quite enjoy coping--in fact I'm bitching him rather.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["So I saw. Well, I'll look after him this afternoon and he's going this\nevening."]
qText:
So I saw. Well, I'll look after him this afternoon and he's going this
evening.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr:
["Is he? I'll be quite sorry. You know that's a difference between us,
that when someone's awful you just run away and hide, while I actually
enjoy it--making up to them and showing off to myself how well I can do
it. Besides, Beaver isn't so bad. He's quite like us in some ways."]
qText:
Is he? I'll be quite sorry. You know that's a difference between us,
that when someone's awful you just run away and hide, while I actually
enjoy it--making up to them and showing off to myself how well I can do
it. Besides, Beaver isn't so bad. He's quite like us in some ways.
speaker: Brenda
menEnts: [[['John Beaver'], ['Tony Last'], ['Brenda', 'Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['Brenda', 'Tony Last']]]

qTextArr: ["He's not like me,"]
qText: He's not like me,
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr:
["Well, if it would really amuse you, we might
go over the house. I know it isn't fashionable to like this sort of
architecture now--my Aunt Frances says it is an authentic Pecksniff--but
I think it's good of its kind."]
qText:
Well, if it would really amuse you, we might
go over the house. I know it isn't fashionable to like this sort of
architecture now--my Aunt Frances says it is an authentic Pecksniff--but
I think it's good of its kind.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["The So-and-so's have got one rather like\nthat at Such-and-such a place"]
qText:
The So-and-so's have got one rather like
that at Such-and-such a place
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["Yes, I've seen it\nbut I think mine is the earlier."]
qText:
Yes, I've seen it
but I think mine is the earlier.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Well,', 'what did you\nthink of it?']
qText:
Well, what did you
think of it?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Magnificent.']
qText: Magnificent.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["You don't have to say that to me, you know."]
qText: You don't have to say that to me, you know.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Well, a lot of the things are very fine.']
qText: Well, a lot of the things are very fine.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['Yes, the _things_ are all right, I suppose.']
qText: Yes, the _things_ are all right, I suppose.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["But don't you like the house?"]
qText: But don't you like the house?
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr:
["Me? I _detest_ it... at least I don't mean that really, but I do wish
sometimes that it wasn't _all_, every bit of it, so appallingly ugly.
Only I'd die rather than say that to Tony. We could never live anywhere
else, of course. He's crazy about the place... It's funny. None of us
minded very much when my brother Reggie sold _our_ house--and that was
built by Vanbrugh, you know... I suppose we're lucky to be able to
afford to keep it up at all. Do you know how much it costs just to live
here? We should be quite rich if it wasn't for that. As it is we support
fifteen servants indoors, besides gardeners and carpenters and a
night-watchman and all the people at the farm and odd little men
constantly popping in to wind the clocks and cook the accounts and clean
the moat, while Tony and I have to fuss about whether it's cheaper to
take a car up to London for the night or buy an excursion ticket... I
shouldn't feel so badly about it if it were a really lovely house--like
my home for instance... but of course Tony's been brought up here and
sees it all differently..."]
qText:
Me? I _detest_ it... at least I don't mean that really, but I do wish
sometimes that it wasn't _all_, every bit of it, so appallingly ugly.
Only I'd die rather than say that to Tony. We could never live anywhere
else, of course. He's crazy about the place... It's funny. None of us
minded very much when my brother Reggie sold _our_ house--and that was
built by Vanbrugh, you know... I suppose we're lucky to be able to
afford to keep it up at all. Do you know how much it costs just to live
here? We should be quite rich if it wasn't for that. As it is we support
fifteen servants indoors, besides gardeners and carpenters and a
night-watchman and all the people at the farm and odd little men
constantly popping in to wind the clocks and cook the accounts and clean
the moat, while Tony and I have to fuss about whether it's cheaper to
take a car up to London for the night or buy an excursion ticket... I
shouldn't feel so badly about it if it were a really lovely house--like
my home for instance... but of course Tony's been brought up here and
sees it all differently...
speaker: Brenda
menEnts: [[['Tony Last'], ['Brenda', 'Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Brenda', 'Tony'], ['Reggie'], ['John Beaver'], ['Brenda', 'Tony Last'], ['John Beaver'], ['Brenda', 'Tony Last'], ['Brenda', 'Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last']]]

qTextArr: ["I don't want to seem inhospitable, but if\nyou're going to catch that train, you ought really to be getting ready."]
qText:
I don't want to seem inhospitable, but if
you're going to catch that train, you ought really to be getting ready.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["That's all right. I've persuaded him to stay on till to-morrow."]
qText: That's all right. I've persuaded him to stay on till to-morrow.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["If you're sure you don't..."]
qText: If you're sure you don't...
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["Splendid. I _am_ glad. It's beastly going up at this time, particularly\nby that train."]
qText:
Splendid. I _am_ glad. It's beastly going up at this time, particularly
by that train.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['I thought Mr Beaver was going.']
qText: I thought Mr Beaver was going.
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ['Not till to-morrow.']
qText: Not till to-morrow.
speaker: Unknowable

qText: Oh.
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ["I've\nthought of something"]
qText:
I've
thought of something
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['Do let me know when you come to London.']
qText: Do let me know when you come to London.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['I may be up this week.']
qText: I may be up this week.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["Well, that's the last of _him_. You were superb, darling. I'm sure he's\ngone back thinking that you're mad about him."]
qText:
Well, that's the last of _him_. You were superb, darling. I'm sure he's
gone back thinking that you're mad about him.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Oh, he wasn't too awful."]
qText: Oh, he wasn't too awful.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['No. I must say he took a very intelligent interest when we went round\nthe house.']
qText:
No. I must say he took a very intelligent interest when we went round
the house.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Who was\nthere?']
qText:
Who was
there?
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

qTextArr: ['No one.']
qText: No one.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['No one? My poor boy.']
qText: No one? My poor boy.
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

qTextArr: ["They weren't expecting me. It was awful at first but got better. They\nwere just as you said. She's very charming. He scarcely spoke."]
qText:
They weren't expecting me. It was awful at first but got better. They
were just as you said. She's very charming. He scarcely spoke.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['I wish I saw her sometimes.']
qText: I wish I saw her sometimes.
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

qTextArr: ['She talked of taking a flat in London.']
qText: She talked of taking a flat in London.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['_Did_ she?']
qText: _Did_ she?
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

qTextArr: ['What does she want?']
qText: What does she want?
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

qTextArr: ["Something quite simple. Two rooms and a bath. But it's all quite vague.\nShe hasn't said anything to Tony yet."]
qText:
Something quite simple. Two rooms and a bath. But it's all quite vague.
She hasn't said anything to Tony yet.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['I am sure I shall be able to find her something.']
qText: I am sure I shall be able to find her something.
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

qTextArr: ['Darling, what _does_ the country do to you? You look like a thousand\npounds. Where _did_ you get that suit?']
qText:
Darling, what _does_ the country do to you? You look like a thousand
pounds. Where _did_ you get that suit?
speaker: Marjorie

qTextArr: ["I don't know. Some shop."]
qText: I don't know. Some shop.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["What's the news at Hetton?"]
qText: What's the news at Hetton?
speaker: Marjorie

qTextArr: ['All the same. Tony madly feudal. John Andrew cursing like a stable\nboy.']
qText:
All the same. Tony madly feudal. John Andrew cursing like a stable
boy.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['And you?']
qText: And you?
speaker: Marjorie

qTextArr: ["Me? Oh, I'm all right."]
qText: Me? Oh, I'm all right.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["Who's been to stay?"]
qText: Who's been to stay?
speaker: Marjorie

qTextArr: ["No one. We had a friend of Tony's called Mr Beaver last week-end."]
qText: No one. We had a friend of Tony's called Mr Beaver last week-end.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["John Beaver?... How very odd. I shouldn't have thought he was at all\nTony's ticket."]
qText:
John Beaver?... How very odd. I shouldn't have thought he was at all
Tony's ticket.
speaker: Marjorie

qTextArr: ["He wasn't... What's he like?"]
qText: He wasn't... What's he like?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["I hardly know him. I see him at Margot's sometimes. He's a great one\nfor going everywhere."]
qText:
I hardly know him. I see him at Margot's sometimes. He's a great one
for going everywhere.
speaker: Marjorie

qTextArr: ['I thought he was rather pathetic.']
qText: I thought he was rather pathetic.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["Oh, he's _pathetic_ all right. D'you fancy him?"]
qText: Oh, he's _pathetic_ all right. D'you fancy him?
speaker: Marjorie

qTextArr: ['Heavens, no.']
qText: Heavens, no.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["I don't believe he has a spark of human\nfeeling,"]
qText:
I don't believe he has a spark of human
feeling,
speaker: Marjorie

qTextArr: ["He's never done that to me,", "What do you suppose is Mr Beaver's sex-life?"]
qText: He's never done that to me, What do you suppose is Mr Beaver's sex-life?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["I shouldn't know. Pretty dim, I imagine... You _do_ fancy him?"]
qText: I shouldn't know. Pretty dim, I imagine... You _do_ fancy him?
speaker: Marjorie

qTextArr: ['Oh well,', "I don't see such a lot of young men..."]
qText: Oh well, I don't see such a lot of young men...
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["Do come up\nfor it. It's certain to be amusing."]
qText:
Do come up
for it. It's certain to be amusing.
speaker: Marjorie

qTextArr: ["I might... if I can find someone to take me. Tony doesn't like her...\nI can't go to parties alone at my age."]
qText:
I might... if I can find someone to take me. Tony doesn't like her...
I can't go to parties alone at my age.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["You're in luck,", "there's your Mr\nBeaver's mother.", 'God, what a\nparty,']
qText:
You're in luck, there's your Mr
Beaver's mother. God, what a
party,
speaker: Marjorie

qTextArr: ["You're both coming to my party, darlings?", "Only don't tell anyone about it. It's\njust a very small, secret party. The house will only hold a few\npeople--just old friends."]
qText:
You're both coming to my party, darlings? Only don't tell anyone about it. It's
just a very small, secret party. The house will only hold a few
people--just old friends.
speaker: Polly Cockpurse

qTextArr: ["It would be wonderful to see what Polly's _real_ old friends were\nlike,", "She hasn't known anyone more than five years."]
qText:
It would be wonderful to see what Polly's _real_ old friends were
like, She hasn't known anyone more than five years.
speaker: Marjorie

qTextArr: ['I wish Tony could see her point.']
qText: I wish Tony could see her point.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr:
["I _must_ come and
speak to you, though I'm in a great hurry. It's _so_ long since we met
and John has been telling me about a _delightful_ week-end he had with
you."]
qText:
I _must_ come and
speak to you, though I'm in a great hurry. It's _so_ long since we met
and John has been telling me about a _delightful_ week-end he had with
you.
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

qTextArr: ['It was very quiet.']
qText: It was very quiet.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr:
["That's just what he _loves_. Poor boy, he gets rushed off his feet in
London. Tell me, Lady Brenda, is it true you are looking for a
flat?--because I think I've got just the place for you. It's being done
up now and will be ready well before Christmas."]
qText:
That's just what he _loves_. Poor boy, he gets rushed off his feet in
London. Tell me, Lady Brenda, is it true you are looking for a
flat?--because I think I've got just the place for you. It's being done
up now and will be ready well before Christmas.
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

qTextArr: ["Oh dear, I must fly. You couldn't possibly come in for a\ncocktail, this evening? Then you could hear all about it."]
qText:
Oh dear, I must fly. You couldn't possibly come in for a
cocktail, this evening? Then you could hear all about it.
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

qTextArr: ['I _could_...']
qText: I _could_...
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["Then _do_. I'll expect you about six. I daresay you don't know where I\nlive?"]
qText:
Then _do_. I'll expect you about six. I daresay you don't know where I
live?
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

qTextArr: ["What's all this about a flat?"]
qText: What's all this about a flat?
speaker: Marjorie

qTextArr: ['Oh, just something I thought of...']
qText: Oh, just something I thought of...
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["I'll ask my husband and let you know."]
qText: I'll ask my husband and let you know.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["You _will_ let me know soon, won't you, because _everyone_ will be\nwanting one."]
qText:
You _will_ let me know soon, won't you, because _everyone_ will be
wanting one.
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

qTextArr: ["I'll let you know very soon."]
qText: I'll let you know very soon.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["I'm sure you want to go away."]
qText: I'm sure you want to go away.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['No, really.']
qText: No, really.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["I've got lots to read."]
qText: I've got lots to read.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['I _want_ to stay.']
qText: I _want_ to stay.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["It's very sweet of you.", "I suppose you wouldn't\nlike to take me to Polly's party, would you?"]
qText:
It's very sweet of you. I suppose you wouldn't
like to take me to Polly's party, would you?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['I wish\nI could,', "but I've promised to dine out for it."]
qText:
I wish
I could, but I've promised to dine out for it.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['I was afraid you would have.']
qText: I was afraid you would have.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["But we'll meet there."]
qText: But we'll meet there.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['Yes, if I go.']
qText: Yes, if I go.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['I wish I could have taken you.']
qText: I wish I could have taken you.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["It's quite all right... I just wondered."]
qText: It's quite all right... I just wondered.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["Well, I think perhaps I'll\nleave you now."]
qText:
Well, I think perhaps I'll
leave you now.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['Yes, run along. Thank you for coming.']
qText: Yes, run along. Thank you for coming.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Barnardo case?']
qText: Barnardo case?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Down and out,', 'sunk, right under.']
qText: Down and out, sunk, right under.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Good day?']
qText: Good day?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Saw Marjorie and her filthy dog. Bought some things.\nLunched at Daisy's new joint. Bone-setter. That's all."]
qText:
Saw Marjorie and her filthy dog. Bought some things.
Lunched at Daisy's new joint. Bone-setter. That's all.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["You know I wish you'd give up these day-trips to London. They're far\ntoo much for you."]
qText:
You know I wish you'd give up these day-trips to London. They're far
too much for you.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Me? Oh, I'm all right. Wish I was dead, that's all... and please,\nplease, darling Tony, don't say anything about bed, because I can't\nmove."]
qText:
Me? Oh, I'm all right. Wish I was dead, that's all... and please,
please, darling Tony, don't say anything about bed, because I can't
move.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['You seem in wonderful spirits to-day,']
qText: You seem in wonderful spirits to-day,
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["I feel big. I think it's Mr Cruttwell. He puts all one's nerves right\nand one's circulation and everything."]
qText:
I feel big. I think it's Mr Cruttwell. He puts all one's nerves right
and one's circulation and everything.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["Where's mummy gone?"]
qText: Where's mummy gone?
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ['London.']
qText: London.
speaker: Tony Last

qText: Why?
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ['Someone called Lady Cockpurse is giving a party.']
qText: Someone called Lady Cockpurse is giving a party.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Is she nice?']
qText: Is she nice?
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ["Mummy thinks so. I don't."]
qText: Mummy thinks so. I don't.
speaker: Tony Last

qText: Why?
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ['Because she looks like a monkey.']
qText: Because she looks like a monkey.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['I should love to see her. Does she live in a cage? Has she got a tail?\nBen saw a woman who looked like a fish, with scales all over instead of\nskin. It was in a circus in Cairo. Smelt like a fish too, Ben says.']
qText:
I should love to see her. Does she live in a cage? Has she got a tail?
Ben saw a woman who looked like a fish, with scales all over instead of
skin. It was in a circus in Cairo. Smelt like a fish too, Ben says.
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ['Daddy, what does Lady Cockpurse eat?']
qText: Daddy, what does Lady Cockpurse eat?
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ['Oh, nuts and things.']
qText: Oh, nuts and things.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Nuts and what things?']
qText: Nuts and what things?
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ['Different kinds of nuts.']
qText: Different kinds of nuts.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["You mustn't say things like that about real people,", 'Whatever would Lady Cockpurse do if she heard about it?']
qText: You mustn't say things like that about real people, Whatever would Lady Cockpurse do if she heard about it?
speaker: Nanny

qTextArr: ["She'd gibber and chatter and lash round with her tail, and then I\nexpect she'd catch some nice, big, juicy fleas and forget all about it."]
qText:
She'd gibber and chatter and lash round with her tail, and then I
expect she'd catch some nice, big, juicy fleas and forget all about it.
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ['Lovely, darling. New?']
qText: Lovely, darling. New?
speaker: Marjorie

qTextArr: ['Fairly.']
qText: Fairly.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["Look\nhere, are you absolutely sure you can't make Allan come to-night?"]
qText:
Look
here, are you absolutely sure you can't make Allan come to-night?
speaker: The Woman At Whose House She Was Dining

qTextArr: ["Absolutely. He's got a meeting in Camberwell. He may not even come to\nPolly's."]
qText:
Absolutely. He's got a meeting in Camberwell. He may not even come to
Polly's.
speaker: Marjorie
addressee: ['The Woman At Whose House She Was Dining']

qTextArr: ['Is there _any_ man you can bring?']
qText: Is there _any_ man you can bring?
speaker: The Woman At Whose House She Was Dining

qTextArr: ["Can't think of anybody."]
qText: Can't think of anybody.
speaker: Marjorie
addressee: ['The Woman At Whose House She Was Dining']

qTextArr: ["Well, we shall have to be one short, that's all. I can't think what's\nhappened to-night. I rang up John Beaver but even _he_ won't come."]
qText:
Well, we shall have to be one short, that's all. I can't think what's
happened to-night. I rang up John Beaver but even _he_ won't come.
speaker: The Woman At Whose House She Was Dining
menEnts: [[['Marjorie', 'The Woman At Whose House She Was Dining'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver']]]

qTextArr: ['You know,', "you're causing a\ngreat deal of trouble. You've taken London's only spare man."]
qText:
You know, you're causing a
great deal of trouble. You've taken London's only spare man.
speaker: Marjorie

qTextArr: ["Oh dear, I didn't realize..."]
qText: Oh dear, I didn't realize...
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['I must see your Mr Beaver properly,', "Let's make him\ntake off his coat and drink something."]
qText:
I must see your Mr Beaver properly, Let's make him
take off his coat and drink something.
speaker: Marjorie

qTextArr: ["Mrs Jimmy Deane's very upset that she couldn't get you for to-night. I\ndidn't give away what you were doing."]
qText:
Mrs Jimmy Deane's very upset that she couldn't get you for to-night. I
didn't give away what you were doing.
speaker: Marjorie
menEnts: [[['The Woman At Whose House She Was Dining'], ['The Woman At Whose House She Was Dining'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver']]]

qTextArr: ['Give her my love,', "Anyway we'll all meet at Polly's."]
qText: Give her my love, Anyway we'll all meet at Polly's.
speaker: John Beaver
menEnts: [[['The Woman At Whose House She Was Dining']], [['Marjorie', 'John Beaver', 'The Woman At Whose House She Was Dining'], ['Polly Cockpurse']]]

qTextArr: ["I must go, we're dining at nine."]
qText: I must go, we're dining at nine.
speaker: Marjorie
menEnts: [[['Marjorie', 'The Woman At Whose House She Was Dining']]]

qTextArr: ['Stay a bit,', "She's sure to be late."]
qText: Stay a bit, She's sure to be late.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['No, I must go. Enjoy yourselves, bless you both.']
qText: No, I must go. Enjoy yourselves, bless you both.
speaker: Marjorie

qTextArr: ['I suppose we ought to be going\ntoo.']
qText:
I suppose we ought to be going
too.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['Yes, where?']
qText: Yes, where?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["I thought Espinosa's."]
qText: I thought Espinosa's.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["Yes, lovely. Only listen. I want you to understand right away that it's\n_my_ dinner."]
qText:
Yes, lovely. Only listen. I want you to understand right away that it's
_my_ dinner.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Of course not... nothing of the sort.']
qText: Of course not... nothing of the sort.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["Yes it is. I'm a year older than you and an old married woman and quite\nrich, so, please, I'm going to pay."]
qText:
Yes it is. I'm a year older than you and an old married woman and quite
rich, so, please, I'm going to pay.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['_Please_, Brenda,']
qText: _Please_, Brenda,
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['You choose. Very little for me,\nbut it must only have starch, no protein.']
qText:
You choose. Very little for me,
but it must only have starch, no protein.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["You can't think how exciting\nit is for me to take a young man out. I've never done it before."]
qText:
You can't think how exciting
it is for me to take a young man out. I've never done it before.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["I'm sorry I was an ass in the taxi just now."]
qText: I'm sorry I was an ass in the taxi just now.
speaker: John Beaver

qText: Eh?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Did you mind when I tried to kiss you just\nnow?']
qText:
Did you mind when I tried to kiss you just
now?
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['Me? No, not particularly.']
qText: Me? No, not particularly.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["Then why wouldn't you let me?"]
qText: Then why wouldn't you let me?
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["Oh dear, you've got a lot to learn."]
qText: Oh dear, you've got a lot to learn.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["How d'you mean?"]
qText: How d'you mean?
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["You mustn't ever ask questions like that. Will you try and remember?"]
qText: You mustn't ever ask questions like that. Will you try and remember?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['You talk to me as if I was an undergraduate having\nhis first walk out.']
qText:
You talk to me as if I was an undergraduate having
his first walk out.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['Oh, is this a walk out?']
qText: Oh, is this a walk out?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Not as far as I am concerned.']
qText: Not as far as I am concerned.
speaker: John Beaver
