qTextArr: ["I am not sure it hasn't been a\nmistake, taking you out to dinner. Let's ask for the bill and go to\nPolly's."]
qText:
I am not sure it hasn't been a
mistake, taking you out to dinner. Let's ask for the bill and go to
Polly's.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["You've got to _learn_ to be nicer,", "I don't believe\nyou'd find it impossible.", 'How\nmuch do I tip him?']
qText:
You've got to _learn_ to be nicer, I don't believe
you'd find it impossible. How
much do I tip him?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["Are you sure that's enough?\nI should have given twice as much."]
qText:
Are you sure that's enough?
I should have given twice as much.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["It's exactly right,"]
qText: It's exactly right,
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['Shut up,', 'Come here.']
qText: Shut up, Come here.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["You're not to leave me, please.\nI'm not going to know anybody,"]
qText:
You're not to leave me, please.
I'm not going to know anybody,
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["All right, I'll give you a rest. Only don't\nlet me get left."]
qText:
All right, I'll give you a rest. Only don't
let me get left.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Time for supper.']
qText: Time for supper.
speaker: Brenda
refExp: Brenda saw he was out of temper and said

qTextArr: ["I don't propose to move for a long time, d'you mind?"]
qText: I don't propose to move for a long time, d'you mind?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Are you dying of it?']
qText: Are you dying of it?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['No, indeed, never happier.']
qText: No, indeed, never happier.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["Well, I am. Let's go and dance."]
qText: Well, I am. Let's go and dance.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Oh dear,', "now we're done. We can't go back\nto the table... it almost looks as though we should have to go home."]
qText:
Oh dear, now we're done. We can't go back
to the table... it almost looks as though we should have to go home.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["It's not two."]
qText: It's not two.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["That's late for me. Look here, don't you come. Stay and enjoy\nyourself."]
qText:
That's late for me. Look here, don't you come. Stay and enjoy
yourself.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["Of course I'll come,"]
qText: Of course I'll come,
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['There already?']
qText: There already?
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["I am afraid I can't ask you in for a drink. You see it isn't my house\nand I shouldn't know where to find anything."]
qText:
I am afraid I can't ask you in for a drink. You see it isn't my house
and I shouldn't know where to find anything.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['No, of course not.']
qText: No, of course not.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["Well, good night, my dear. Thank you a thousand times for looking after\nme. I'm afraid I rather bitched your evening."]
qText:
Well, good night, my dear. Thank you a thousand times for looking after
me. I'm afraid I rather bitched your evening.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['No, of course not,']
qText: No, of course not,
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['Will you ring me in the morning... promise?']
qText: Will you ring me in the morning... promise?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["Darling, I was just going to ring off. I thought you must have gone\nback to Polly's. Is the telephone not by your bed?"]
qText:
Darling, I was just going to ring off. I thought you must have gone
back to Polly's. Is the telephone not by your bed?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["No, it's on the ground floor."]
qText: No, it's on the ground floor.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["Oh dear, then it wasn't a very good idea to ring up, was it?"]
qText: Oh dear, then it wasn't a very good idea to ring up, was it?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["Oh, I don't know. What is it?"]
qText: Oh, I don't know. What is it?
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['Just to say "good night".']
qText: Just to say "good night".
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Oh, I see, well--good night.']
qText: Oh, I see, well--good night.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["And you'll ring me in the morning?"]
qText: And you'll ring me in the morning?
speaker: Brenda

qText: Yes.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["Early, before you've made any plans."]
qText: Early, before you've made any plans.
speaker: Brenda

qText: Yes.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['Then good night, bless you.']
qText: Then good night, bless you.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['...going away in the middle of the party.']
qText: ...going away in the middle of the party.
speaker: Marjorie

qTextArr: ["I can't tell you how innocent it was. He didn't even come in."]
qText: I can't tell you how innocent it was. He didn't even come in.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['No one is going to know that.']
qText: No one is going to know that.
speaker: Marjorie

qTextArr: ['And he was furious when I rang him up.']
qText: And he was furious when I rang him up.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['What does he think of you?']
qText: What does he think of you?
speaker: Marjorie

qTextArr: ["Simply can't make me out at all... terribly puzzled, and rather bored\nin bits."]
qText:
Simply can't make me out at all... terribly puzzled, and rather bored
in bits.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Are you going to go on with it?']
qText: Are you going to go on with it?
speaker: Marjorie

qTextArr: ["I shouldn't know."]
qText: I shouldn't know.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["Perhaps that's him."]
qText: Perhaps that's him.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["But, really, Brenda, he's such a _dreary_ young man."]
qText: But, really, Brenda, he's such a _dreary_ young man.
speaker: Marjorie

qTextArr:
["I know it all. He's second rate and a snob and, I should think, as cold
as a fish, but I happen to have a fancy for him, that's all... besides
I'm not sure he's _altogether_ awful... he's got that odious mother
whom he adores... and he's always been very poor. I don't think he's
had a fair deal. I heard all about it last night. He got engaged once
but they couldn't get married because of money and since then he's never
had a proper affair with anyone decent... he's got to be taught a whole
lot of things. That's part of his attraction."]
qText:
I know it all. He's second rate and a snob and, I should think, as cold
as a fish, but I happen to have a fancy for him, that's all... besides
I'm not sure he's _altogether_ awful... he's got that odious mother
whom he adores... and he's always been very poor. I don't think he's
had a fair deal. I heard all about it last night. He got engaged once
but they couldn't get married because of money and since then he's never
had a proper affair with anyone decent... he's got to be taught a whole
lot of things. That's part of his attraction.
speaker: Brenda
menEnts: [[['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['Mrs. Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver']]]

qTextArr: ["Oh dear, I see you're very serious."]
qText: Oh dear, I see you're very serious.
speaker: Marjorie

qTextArr: ["Perhaps _that's_ him."]
qText: Perhaps _that's_ him.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["Good morning, darling, what's the dirt to-day?"]
qText: Good morning, darling, what's the dirt to-day?
speaker: Polly Cockpurse

qTextArr: ['Oh, Polly, what a good party last night.']
qText: Oh, Polly, what a good party last night.
speaker: Marjorie

qTextArr: ['Not so bad for the old girl, was it? I say, what about your sister and\nMr Beaver?']
qText:
Not so bad for the old girl, was it? I say, what about your sister and
Mr Beaver?
speaker: Polly Cockpurse

qTextArr: ['What about them?']
qText: What about them?
speaker: Marjorie

qTextArr: ['How long has _that_ been on?']
qText: How long has _that_ been on?
speaker: Polly Cockpurse

qTextArr: ["There's nothing doing there, Polly."]
qText: There's nothing doing there, Polly.
speaker: Marjorie

qTextArr: ["Don't you tell me. They were well away last night. How's the boy\nmanaged it? That's what I want to know. He must have something we didn't\nknow about..."]
qText:
Don't you tell me. They were well away last night. How's the boy
managed it? That's what I want to know. He must have something we didn't
know about...
speaker: Polly Cockpurse

qTextArr: ["So Polly's on to your story. She'll be telling everyone in London at\nthis moment."]
qText:
So Polly's on to your story. She'll be telling everyone in London at
this moment.
speaker: Marjorie

qTextArr: ["How I wish there was anything to tell! The cub hasn't even rung me\nup... Well, I'll leave him in peace. If he doesn't do anything about me,\nI'll go down to Hetton this afternoon. Perhaps that's him."]
qText:
How I wish there was anything to tell! The cub hasn't even rung me
up... Well, I'll leave him in peace. If he doesn't do anything about me,
I'll go down to Hetton this afternoon. Perhaps that's him.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['I hear Brenda disgraced\nherself,']
qText:
I hear Brenda disgraced
herself,
speaker: Allan

qTextArr: ['Goodness,', 'People do think that young men are easily come\nby.']
qText:
Goodness, People do think that young men are easily come
by.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["I scarcely saw you at Polly's last night,", 'What\nbecame of you?']
qText:
I scarcely saw you at Polly's last night, What
became of you?
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

qTextArr: ['We went early. Brenda Last was tired.']
qText: We went early. Brenda Last was tired.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["She was looking lovely. I am so glad you've made friends with her. When\nare you going to see her again?"]
qText:
She was looking lovely. I am so glad you've made friends with her. When
are you going to see her again?
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

qTextArr: ["I said I'd ring up."]
qText: I said I'd ring up.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["Well, why don't you?"]
qText: Well, why don't you?
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

qTextArr:
["Oh, mumsy, what's the use? I can't afford to start taking about women
like Brenda Last. If I ring up she'll say, what are you doing, and I
shall have to ask her to something, and it will be the same thing every
day. I simply haven't the money."]
qText:
Oh, mumsy, what's the use? I can't afford to start taking about women
like Brenda Last. If I ring up she'll say, what are you doing, and I
shall have to ask her to something, and it will be the same thing every
day. I simply haven't the money.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr:
["I know, my son. It's very difficult for you... and you're wonderful
about money. I ought to be grateful that I haven't a son always coming
to me with debts. Still, it doesn't do to deny yourself _everything_,
you know. You're getting to be an old bachelor already at twenty-five. I
could see Brenda liked you, that evening she came here."]
qText:
I know, my son. It's very difficult for you... and you're wonderful
about money. I ought to be grateful that I haven't a son always coming
to me with debts. Still, it doesn't do to deny yourself _everything_,
you know. You're getting to be an old bachelor already at twenty-five. I
could see Brenda liked you, that evening she came here.
speaker: Mrs. Beaver
menEnts: [[['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['Brenda'], ['John Beaver'], ['Brenda']]]

qTextArr: ['Oh, she likes me all right.']
qText: Oh, she likes me all right.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr:
["I hope she makes up her mind about that flat. They're going like hot
cakes. I shall have to look about for another suitable house to split
up. You'd be surprised who've been taking them--quite a number of people
with houses in London already... Well, I must be getting back to work.
I'm away for two nights by the way. See that Chambers looks after you
properly. There are some Australians Sylvia Newport discovered who want
to take a house in the country, so I'm driving them round to one or two
that might do for them. Where are you lunching?"]
qText:
I hope she makes up her mind about that flat. They're going like hot
cakes. I shall have to look about for another suitable house to split
up. You'd be surprised who've been taking them--quite a number of people
with houses in London already... Well, I must be getting back to work.
I'm away for two nights by the way. See that Chambers looks after you
properly. There are some Australians Sylvia Newport discovered who want
to take a house in the country, so I'm driving them round to one or two
that might do for them. Where are you lunching?
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

qTextArr: ["Margot's."]
qText: Margot's.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["So that's that,", "I daresay I'm\nglad really."]
qText:
So that's that, I daresay I'm
glad really.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["I don't\nseem to have anywhere to lunch,"]
qText:
I don't
seem to have anywhere to lunch,
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["Why don't you come to Margot's? I know she'd love it."]
qText: Why don't you come to Margot's? I know she'd love it.
speaker: Marjorie

qTextArr: ['Well, ring up and ask her.']
qText: Well, ring up and ask her.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['I kept trying to get through to you this\nmorning,', 'but the line was always engaged.']
qText:
I kept trying to get through to you this
morning, but the line was always engaged.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['Oh, come on,', "I'll sock you a movie."]
qText: Oh, come on, I'll sock you a movie.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Is mummy coming back to-day?']
qText: Is mummy coming back to-day?
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ['I hope so.']
qText: I hope so.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["That monkey-woman's party has lasted a long time. Can I come in to the\nstation and meet her?"]
qText:
That monkey-woman's party has lasted a long time. Can I come in to the
station and meet her?
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ["Yes, we'll both go."]
qText: Yes, we'll both go.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["She hasn't seen Thunderclap for four days. She hasn't seen me jump the\nnew post and rail, has she, daddy?"]
qText:
She hasn't seen Thunderclap for four days. She hasn't seen me jump the
new post and rail, has she, daddy?
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ['Her\nladyship coming back to-day?']
qText:
Her
ladyship coming back to-day?
speaker: The Stationmaster

qTextArr: ["I've been expecting her every day. You know what it is when ladies get\nto London."]
qText:
I've been expecting her every day. You know what it is when ladies get
to London.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Sam Brace's wife went to London and he couldn't get her back. Had to go\nup and fetch her himself. And then she give him a hiding."]
qText:
Sam Brace's wife went to London and he couldn't get her back. Had to go
up and fetch her himself. And then she give him a hiding.
speaker: The Stationmaster
menEnts: [[["Sam Brace'S Wife"], ['Sam Brace'], ["Sam Brace'S Wife"], ["Sam Brace'S Wife"], ["Sam Brace'S Wife"], ['Sam Brace']]]

qTextArr: ["You've _both_ come. What angels you are. I don't\nat all deserve it."]
qText:
You've _both_ come. What angels you are. I don't
at all deserve it.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Oh, mummy, have you brought the monkey-lady?']
qText: Oh, mummy, have you brought the monkey-lady?
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ['What _does_ the child mean?']
qText: What _does_ the child mean?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["He's got it into his head that your chum Polly has a tail."]
qText: He's got it into his head that your chum Polly has a tail.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Come to think of it, I shouldn't be surprised if she had."]
qText: Come to think of it, I shouldn't be surprised if she had.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["What's all the news?"]
qText: What's all the news?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr:
["Ben's put the rail up ever so high and Thunderclap and I jumped it six
times yesterday and six times again to-day and two more of the fish in
the little pond are dead, floating upside down all swollen and nanny
burnt her finger on the kettle yesterday and daddy and I saw a fox just
as near as anything and he sat quite still and then went away into the
wood and I began drawing a picture of a battle only I couldn't finish it
because the paints weren't right and the grey carthorse the one that had
worms is quite well again."]
qText:
Ben's put the rail up ever so high and Thunderclap and I jumped it six
times yesterday and six times again to-day and two more of the fish in
the little pond are dead, floating upside down all swollen and nanny
burnt her finger on the kettle yesterday and daddy and I saw a fox just
as near as anything and he sat quite still and then went away into the
wood and I began drawing a picture of a battle only I couldn't finish it
because the paints weren't right and the grey carthorse the one that had
worms is quite well again.
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ['Nothing much has happened,', "We've missed you. What did you\nfind to do in London all this time?"]
qText:
Nothing much has happened, We've missed you. What did you
find to do in London all this time?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Me? Oh, I've been behaving rather badly to tell you the truth."]
qText: Me? Oh, I've been behaving rather badly to tell you the truth.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Buying things?']
qText: Buying things?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Worse. I've been carrying on madly with young men and I've spent heaps\nof money and I've enjoyed it very much indeed. But there's one awful\nthing."]
qText:
Worse. I've been carrying on madly with young men and I've spent heaps
of money and I've enjoyed it very much indeed. But there's one awful
thing.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["What's that?"]
qText: What's that?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["No, I think it had better keep. It's something you won't like at all."]
qText: No, I think it had better keep. It's something you won't like at all.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["You've bought a Pekingese."]
qText: You've bought a Pekingese.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Worse, far worse. Only I haven't done it yet. But I _want_ to\ndreadfully."]
qText:
Worse, far worse. Only I haven't done it yet. But I _want_ to
dreadfully.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Go on.']
qText: Go on.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Tony, I've found a flat."]
qText: Tony, I've found a flat.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["Well, you'd better lose it again, quick."]
qText: Well, you'd better lose it again, quick.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["All right. I'll attack you about it again later. Meanwhile, try not to\nbrood about it."]
qText:
All right. I'll attack you about it again later. Meanwhile, try not to
brood about it.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["I shan't give it another thought."]
qText: I shan't give it another thought.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["What's a flat, daddy?"]
qText: What's a flat, daddy?
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ["I suppose all this means that you're going to start again about your\nflat?"]
qText:
I suppose all this means that you're going to start again about your
flat?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Mmmm.']
qText: Mmmm.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["You haven't signed any papers yet, have you?"]
qText: You haven't signed any papers yet, have you?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Oh no.']
qText: Oh no.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["Then no great harm's done."]
qText: Then no great harm's done.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Listen, you\nhaven't been brooding?"]
qText:
Listen, you
haven't been brooding?
speaker: Brenda

qText: No.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr:
["Because, you see, when you say 'flat' you're thinking of something
quite different to me. _You_ mean by a flat, a lift and a man in
uniform, and a big front door with knobs, and an entrance hall and doors
opening in all directions, with kitchens and sculleries and dining-rooms
and drawing-rooms and servants' bedrooms... don't you, Tony?"]
qText:
Because, you see, when you say 'flat' you're thinking of something
quite different to me. _You_ mean by a flat, a lift and a man in
uniform, and a big front door with knobs, and an entrance hall and doors
opening in all directions, with kitchens and sculleries and dining-rooms
and drawing-rooms and servants' bedrooms... don't you, Tony?
speaker: Brenda
menEnts: [[['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last']]]

qTextArr: ['More or less.']
qText: More or less.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['_Exactly._ Now _I_ mean just a bedroom and a bath and a telephone. You\nsee the difference? Now a woman I know--']
qText:
_Exactly._ Now _I_ mean just a bedroom and a bath and a telephone. You
see the difference? Now a woman I know--
speaker: Brenda

qText: Who?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr:
["Just a woman--has fixed up a whole house like that off Belgrave Square
and they are three pounds a week, no rates and taxes, constant hot water
and central heating, woman comes in to make the bed when required, what
d'you think of that?"]
qText:
Just a woman--has fixed up a whole house like that off Belgrave Square
and they are three pounds a week, no rates and taxes, constant hot water
and central heating, woman comes in to make the bed when required, what
d'you think of that?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['I see.']
qText: I see.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr:
["Now this is how I look at it. What's three pounds a week? Less than
nine bob a night. Where could one stay for less than nine bob a night
with all those advantages? You're always going to the club, and that
costs more, and I can't stay often with Marjorie because it's hell for
her having me, and anyway she's got that dog, and you're always saying
when I come back in the evenings after shopping,"]
qText:
Now this is how I look at it. What's three pounds a week? Less than
nine bob a night. Where could one stay for less than nine bob a night
with all those advantages? You're always going to the club, and that
costs more, and I can't stay often with Marjorie because it's hell for
her having me, and anyway she's got that dog, and you're always saying
when I come back in the evenings after shopping,
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['you say,']
qText: you say,
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["Time and again you\nsay it. I'm sure we spend much more than three pounds a week through not\nhaving a flat. Tell you what, I'll give up Mr Cruttwell. How's that?"]
qText:
Time and again you
say it. I'm sure we spend much more than three pounds a week through not
having a flat. Tell you what, I'll give up Mr Cruttwell. How's that?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["D'you really want this thing?"]
qText: D'you really want this thing?
speaker: Tony Last

qText: Mmm.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["Well, I'll have to see. We _might_ manage it, but it'll mean putting\noff the improvements down here."]
qText:
Well, I'll have to see. We _might_ manage it, but it'll mean putting
off the improvements down here.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["I don't really deserve it,", "I've been\ncarrying on _anyhow_ this week."]
qText:
I don't really deserve it, I've been
carrying on _anyhow_ this week.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["I'm sorry to be pompous,", "but I\njust don't want your Mr Beaver hanging about the house all day and\ncalling me Marjorie."]
qText:
I'm sorry to be pompous, but I
just don't want your Mr Beaver hanging about the house all day and
calling me Marjorie.
speaker: Marjorie

qTextArr: ["Oh well, the flat won't be long now."]
qText: Oh well, the flat won't be long now.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["And I shall go on saying that I think you're making a ridiculous\nmistake."]
qText:
And I shall go on saying that I think you're making a ridiculous
mistake.
speaker: Marjorie

qTextArr: ["It's just that you don't like Mr Beaver."]
qText: It's just that you don't like Mr Beaver.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["It isn't only that. I think it's hard cheese on Tony."]
qText: It isn't only that. I think it's hard cheese on Tony.
speaker: Marjorie

qTextArr: ["Oh, Tony's all right."]
qText: Oh, Tony's all right.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["And if there's a row--"]
qText: And if there's a row--
speaker: Marjorie

qTextArr: ["There won't be a row."]
qText: There won't be a row.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["You never know. If there is, I don't want Allan to think I've been\nhelping to arrange things."]
qText:
You never know. If there is, I don't want Allan to think I've been
helping to arrange things.
speaker: Marjorie

qTextArr: ["I wasn't so disagreeable to you about Robin Beaseley."]
qText: I wasn't so disagreeable to you about Robin Beaseley.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['There was never much in that,']
qText: There was never much in that,
speaker: Marjorie

qTextArr:
["Of course the subject has
not been mentioned between John and myself, but if what I hear is true,
I think it will do the boy a world of good. Of course he's always been
very much in demand and had a great number of friends, but _that isn't
the same thing_. I've felt for a long time a Lack of Something in him,
and I think that a charming and experienced woman like Brenda Last is
just the person to help him. He's got a _very_ affectionate nature, but
he's so sensitive that he hardly ever lets it appear... to tell you the
truth I felt something of the kind was in the air last week, so I made
an excuse to go away for a few days. If I had been there things might
never have come to anything. He's very shy and reserved even to me. I'll
have the chess-men done up and sent round to you this afternoon. Thank
you so much."]
qText:
Of course the subject has
not been mentioned between John and myself, but if what I hear is true,
I think it will do the boy a world of good. Of course he's always been
very much in demand and had a great number of friends, but _that isn't
the same thing_. I've felt for a long time a Lack of Something in him,
and I think that a charming and experienced woman like Brenda Last is
just the person to help him. He's got a _very_ affectionate nature, but
he's so sensitive that he hardly ever lets it appear... to tell you the
truth I felt something of the kind was in the air last week, so I made
an excuse to go away for a few days. If I had been there things might
never have come to anything. He's very shy and reserved even to me. I'll
have the chess-men done up and sent round to you this afternoon. Thank
you so much.
speaker: Mrs. Beaver
menEnts: [[['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['Brenda'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver']]]

qTextArr: ["I'm talking from the\nflat."]
qText:
I'm talking from the
flat.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Oh, ah.']
qText: Oh, ah.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["_Darling_, do try to sound interested. It's very exciting for me."]
qText: _Darling_, do try to sound interested. It's very exciting for me.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["What's it like?"]
qText: What's it like?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr:
["Well, there are a good many smells at present and the bath makes odd
sounds and when you turn on the hot tap there's just a rush of air and
that's all, and the cold tap keeps dripping and the water is rather
brown and the cupboard doors are jammed and the curtains won't pull
right across so that the street lamp shines in all night... but it's
_lovely_."]
qText:
Well, there are a good many smells at present and the bath makes odd
sounds and when you turn on the hot tap there's just a rush of air and
that's all, and the cold tap keeps dripping and the water is rather
brown and the cupboard doors are jammed and the curtains won't pull
right across so that the street lamp shines in all night... but it's
_lovely_.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["You don't say so."]
qText: You don't say so.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr:
["Tony, you must be nice about it. It's all so exciting--front door and a
latch-key and all... And someone sent me a lot of flowers to-day--so
many that there's hardly room for them and I've had to put them in the
basin on account of having no pots. It wasn't you, was it?"]
qText:
Tony, you must be nice about it. It's all so exciting--front door and a
latch-key and all... And someone sent me a lot of flowers to-day--so
many that there's hardly room for them and I've had to put them in the
basin on account of having no pots. It wasn't you, was it?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Yes... as a matter of fact.']
qText: Yes... as a matter of fact.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Darling, I did so hope it was... how like you.']
qText: Darling, I did so hope it was... how like you.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Three minutes, please.']
qText: Three minutes, please.
speaker: Unknowable

qTextArr: ['Must stop now.']
qText: Must stop now.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['When are you coming back?']
qText: When are you coming back?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Almost at once. Good night, my sweet.']
qText: Almost at once. Good night, my sweet.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['What a lot of talk,']
qText: What a lot of talk,
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["Wasn't it sweet of Tony to send those flowers?"]
qText: Wasn't it sweet of Tony to send those flowers?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["I'm not awfully fond of Tony."]
qText: I'm not awfully fond of Tony.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["Don't let that worry you, my beauty, he doesn't like you _at all_."]
qText: Don't let that worry you, my beauty, he doesn't like you _at all_.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["_Doesn't_ he? Why not?"]
qText: _Doesn't_ he? Why not?
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["No one does except me. You must get that clear... it's very odd that\n_I_ should."]
qText:
No one does except me. You must get that clear... it's very odd that
_I_ should.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr:
['How difficult it is for us,', 'to realize that this is indeed
Christmas. Instead of the glowing log fire and windows tight shuttered
against the drifting snow, we have only the harsh glare of an alien sun;
instead of the happy circle of loved faces, of home and family, we have
the uncomprehending stares of the subjugated, though no doubt grateful,
heathen. Instead of the placid ox and ass of Bethlehem,', 'we have for companions
the ravening tiger and the exotic camel, the furtive jackal and the
ponderous elephant...']
qText:
How difficult it is for us, to realize that this is indeed
Christmas. Instead of the glowing log fire and windows tight shuttered
against the drifting snow, we have only the harsh glare of an alien sun;
instead of the happy circle of loved faces, of home and family, we have
the uncomprehending stares of the subjugated, though no doubt grateful,
heathen. Instead of the placid ox and ass of Bethlehem, we have for companions
the ravening tiger and the exotic camel, the furtive jackal and the
ponderous elephant...
speaker: The Vicar

qTextArr: ['Dear child, all these feelings of delicacy are valueless;\nonly the rich realize the gulf that separates them from the poor,']
qText:
Dear child, all these feelings of delicacy are valueless;
only the rich realize the gulf that separates them from the poor,
speaker: Aunt Frances
refExp: Aunt Frances with acid mind quickly discerned the trouble and attempted to reassure her saying

qTextArr: ["I can't complain, he's never pretended to like me\nmuch. And anyway it was a damned silly present."]
qText:
I can't complain, he's never pretended to like me
much. And anyway it was a damned silly present.
speaker: Brenda
refExp: Brenda felt a little sick when she read this letter but she showed it to Marjorie saying

qTextArr: ["Don't come, darling. I'll make it all right with them."]
qText: Don't come, darling. I'll make it all right with them.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["No, I'll come. I haven't seen so much of you in the last three weeks."]
qText: No, I'll come. I haven't seen so much of you in the last three weeks.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["I'll tell you something very odd,", 'Who do you think is here?']
qText: I'll tell you something very odd, Who do you think is here?
speaker: Tony Last

qText: Who?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Our old friend Beaver.']
qText: Our old friend Beaver.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Why's that odd particularly?"]
qText: Why's that odd particularly?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["Oh, I don't know. I'd forgotten all about him, hadn't you? D'you think\nhe sent a telegram as he did to us?"]
qText:
Oh, I don't know. I'd forgotten all about him, hadn't you? D'you think
he sent a telegram as he did to us?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['I daresay.']
qText: I daresay.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["All kinds of changes since we saw you last.\nBrenda's taken a flat in London."]
qText:
All kinds of changes since we saw you last.
Brenda's taken a flat in London.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Yes, I know.']
qText: Yes, I know.
speaker: John Beaver

qText: How?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Well, my mother let it to her, you know.']
qText: Well, my mother let it to her, you know.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["You never told\nme who was behind your flat. I might not have been so amiable if I'd\nknown."]
qText:
You never told
me who was behind your flat. I might not have been so amiable if I'd
known.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["No, darling, that's why."]
qText: No, darling, that's why.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["I daresay it was a mistake to ask him. It's so hard to know."]
qText: I daresay it was a mistake to ask him. It's so hard to know.
speaker: Angela

qTextArr: ["I've\nmade a New Year resolution."]
qText:
I've
made a New Year resolution.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Anything to do with spending more time at home?']
qText: Anything to do with spending more time at home?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Oh no, _quite_ the reverse. Listen, Tony, it's serious. I think I'll\ntake a course of something."]
qText:
Oh no, _quite_ the reverse. Listen, Tony, it's serious. I think I'll
take a course of something.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Not bone-setters again? I thought that was over.']
qText: Not bone-setters again? I thought that was over.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr:
["No, something like economics. You see, I've been thinking. I don't
really _do_ anything at all at present. The house runs itself. It seems
to me time I _took_ to something. Now you're always talking about going
into Parliament. Well, if I had done a course of economics I could be
some use canvassing and writing speeches and things--you know, the way
Marjorie did when Allan was standing on the Clydeside. There are all
sorts of lectures in London, to do with the University, where girls go.
Don't you think it's rather a good idea?"]
qText:
No, something like economics. You see, I've been thinking. I don't
really _do_ anything at all at present. The house runs itself. It seems
to me time I _took_ to something. Now you're always talking about going
into Parliament. Well, if I had done a course of economics I could be
some use canvassing and writing speeches and things--you know, the way
Marjorie did when Allan was standing on the Clydeside. There are all
sorts of lectures in London, to do with the University, where girls go.
Don't you think it's rather a good idea?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["It's one better than the bone-setters,"]
qText: It's one better than the bone-setters,
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Anyone here?']
qText: Anyone here?
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

qTextArr: ['Very quiet to-night, sir. Mr Last is in the dining-room.']
qText: Very quiet to-night, sir. Mr Last is in the dining-room.
speaker: The Barman

qTextArr: ['Hullo,', 'Chucked? Come and join me.']
qText: Hullo, Chucked? Come and join me.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Been chucked?']
qText: Been chucked?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Yes, it's the last time I ask that bitch out."]
qText: Yes, it's the last time I ask that bitch out.
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

qTextArr: ["Better have a drink. I've been drinking a whole lot. Much the best\nthing."]
qText:
Better have a drink. I've been drinking a whole lot. Much the best
thing.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Just come up for the night,', 'Staying here.']
qText: Just come up for the night, Staying here.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["You've got a flat now, haven't you?"]
qText: You've got a flat now, haven't you?
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

qTextArr: ["Well, Brenda has. There isn't really room for two... we tried it once\nand it wasn't a success."]
qText:
Well, Brenda has. There isn't really room for two... we tried it once
and it wasn't a success.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["What's she doing to-night?"]
qText: What's she doing to-night?
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

qTextArr:
["Out somewhere. I didn't let her know I was coming... silly not to, but
you see I got fed up with being alone at Hetton and thought I'd like to
see Brenda, so I came up suddenly on the spur of the moment, just like
that. Damned silly thing to do. Might have known she'd be going out
somewhere... she's very high-principled about chucking... so there it
is. She's going to ring me up here later, if she can get away."]
qText:
Out somewhere. I didn't let her know I was coming... silly not to, but
you see I got fed up with being alone at Hetton and thought I'd like to
see Brenda, so I came up suddenly on the spur of the moment, just like
that. Damned silly thing to do. Might have known she'd be going out
somewhere... she's very high-principled about chucking... so there it
is. She's going to ring me up here later, if she can get away.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr:
['Extraordinary idea of hers, taking up
economics,', "I never thought it would last, but she seems
really keen on it... I suppose it's a good plan. You know there wasn't
really much for her to do all the time at Hetton. Of course she'd rather
die than admit it, but I believe she got a bit bored there sometimes.
I've been thinking it over and that's the conclusion I came to. Brenda
must have been bored... Daresay she'll get bored with economics some
time... Anyway, she seems cheerful enough now. We've had parties every
week-end lately... I wish you'd come down sometimes, Jock. I don't seem
to get on with Brenda's new friends."]
qText:
Extraordinary idea of hers, taking up
economics, I never thought it would last, but she seems
really keen on it... I suppose it's a good plan. You know there wasn't
really much for her to do all the time at Hetton. Of course she'd rather
die than admit it, but I believe she got a bit bored there sometimes.
I've been thinking it over and that's the conclusion I came to. Brenda
must have been bored... Daresay she'll get bored with economics some
time... Anyway, she seems cheerful enough now. We've had parties every
week-end lately... I wish you'd come down sometimes, Jock. I don't seem
to get on with Brenda's new friends.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['People from the school of economics?']
qText: People from the school of economics?
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

qTextArr: ["No, but ones I don't know. I believe I bore them. Thinking it over,\nthat's the conclusion I've come to. I bore them. They talk about me as"]
qText:
No, but ones I don't know. I believe I bore them. Thinking it over,
that's the conclusion I've come to. I bore them. They talk about me as
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['John heard them.']
qText: John heard them.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Well, that's friendly enough."]
qText: Well, that's friendly enough.
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

qTextArr: ["Yes, that's friendly."]
qText: Yes, that's friendly.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['I\nsay, come next week-end, will you?']
qText:
I
say, come next week-end, will you?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["I think I'd love to."]
qText: I think I'd love to.
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

qTextArr: ["Wish you would. I don't see many old friends... Sure to be lots of\npeople in the house, but you won't mind that, will you?... sociable\nchap, Jock... doesn't mind people about. _I_ mind it like hell."]
qText:
Wish you would. I don't see many old friends... Sure to be lots of
people in the house, but you won't mind that, will you?... sociable
chap, Jock... doesn't mind people about. _I_ mind it like hell.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Not enough bathrooms, you know... but\nof course you know. You've been there before, often. Not like the new\nfriends who think me a bore. You don't think I'm a bore, do you?"]
qText:
Not enough bathrooms, you know... but
of course you know. You've been there before, often. Not like the new
friends who think me a bore. You don't think I'm a bore, do you?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['No, old boy.']
qText: No, old boy.
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

qTextArr:
["Not even when I'm tight, like this?... There would have been
bathrooms. I had the plans out. Four new ones. A chap down there made
the plans... but then Brenda wanted the flat so I had to postpone them
as an economy... I say, that's funny. We had to economize because of
Brenda's economics."]
qText:
Not even when I'm tight, like this?... There would have been
bathrooms. I had the plans out. Four new ones. A chap down there made
the plans... but then Brenda wanted the flat so I had to postpone them
as an economy... I say, that's funny. We had to economize because of
Brenda's economics.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Yes, that's funny. Let's have some port."]
qText: Yes, that's funny. Let's have some port.
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

qTextArr: ['You seem pretty low to-night.']
qText: You seem pretty low to-night.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['I am rather. Worried about the Pig Scheme. Constituents keep writing.']
qText: I am rather. Worried about the Pig Scheme. Constituents keep writing.
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

qTextArr:
["_I_ felt low, _bloody_ low, but I'm all right again now. The best thing
is to get tight. That's what I did and I don't feel low any more...
discouraging to come to London and find you're not wanted. Funny thing,
_you_ feel low because your girl's chucked, and _I_ feel low because
mine won't chuck."]
qText:
_I_ felt low, _bloody_ low, but I'm all right again now. The best thing
is to get tight. That's what I did and I don't feel low any more...
discouraging to come to London and find you're not wanted. Funny thing,
_you_ feel low because your girl's chucked, and _I_ feel low because
mine won't chuck.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Yes, that's funny."]
qText: Yes, that's funny.
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

qTextArr: ["But you know I've felt low for weeks now... bloody low... how about\nsome brandy?"]
qText:
But you know I've felt low for weeks now... bloody low... how about
some brandy?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Yes, why not? After all, there are other things in life besides women\nand pigs.']
qText:
Yes, why not? After all, there are other things in life besides women
and pigs.
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

qTextArr: ['A message from Lady\nBrenda, sir.']
qText:
A message from Lady
Brenda, sir.
speaker: A Page
refExp: a page came to their table to say

qTextArr: ["Good, I'll go and speak to her."]
qText: Good, I'll go and speak to her.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["It's not her ladyship speaking. Someone was sending a message."]
qText: It's not her ladyship speaking. Someone was sending a message.
speaker: A Page

qTextArr: ["I'll come and speak to her."]
qText: I'll come and speak to her.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Darling,']
qText: Darling,
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Is that Mr Last? I've got a message here, from Lady Brenda."]

qText: Right, put me through to her.

qText: Tell her I want to speak to her.

speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["Oh dear. I feel rather awful about him. But what _can_ he expect,\ncoming up suddenly like this? He's got to be taught not to make surprise\nvisits."]

Oh dear. I feel rather awful about him. But what _can_ he expect,
coming up suddenly like this? He's got to be taught not to make surprise
visits.

qText: Is he often like that?

qText: No, it's quite new.

D'you suppose that's him again? I'd better

qText: I want to speak to Lady Brenda Last.

qText: Tony, darling, this _is_ me, Brenda.

qText: Some damn fool said I couldn't speak to you.

I left a message from where I was dining. Are you having a lovely

Hellish. I'm with Jock. He's worried about the Pig Scheme. Shall we

qText: No, not now, darling, I'm terribly tired and just going to bed.

qText: We'll come and see you.

qText: Tony, are you a tiny bit tight?

qText: Stinking. Jock and I'll come and see you.

_Tony_, you're _not_ to. D'you hear? I can't have you making a brawl.
The flats are getting a bad name anyhow.

qText: Their name'll be mud when Jock and I come.
speaker: Tony Last

qText: Shan't be long.
speaker: Tony Last

qText: Jock, what _have_ you been doing to my husband?

qText: He's a bit tight, that's all.

qText: Yes, I understand.

qTextArr: ["Brenda can't expect us to do more than that,"]
qText: Brenda can't expect us to do more than that,
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["I tell you what I'll do. I go almost past her door, so I'll ring the\nbell a bit just in case she's awake and still waiting up for us."]
qText:
I tell you what I'll do. I go almost past her door, so I'll ring the
bell a bit just in case she's awake and still waiting up for us.
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

qTextArr: ['Yes, you do that. What a good friend you are, Jock.']
qText: Yes, you do that. What a good friend you are, Jock.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Oh, I'm fond of Brenda... a grand girl."]
qText: Oh, I'm fond of Brenda... a grand girl.
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

qTextArr: ["Grand girl... I wish I didn't feel ill."]
qText: Grand girl... I wish I didn't feel ill.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Well, Tony, how do you feel?']
qText: Well, Tony, how do you feel?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Awful. I _was_ tight.']
qText: Awful. I _was_ tight.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['You were.']
qText: You were.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["I'm feeling pretty guilty too."]
qText: I'm feeling pretty guilty too.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["I'm not surprised."]
qText: I'm not surprised.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["I don't remember everything very clearly but I have the impression that\nJock and I were rather bores."]
qText:
I don't remember everything very clearly but I have the impression that
Jock and I were rather bores.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['You were.']
qText: You were.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Are you in a rage?']
qText: Are you in a rage?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Well, I was last night. What made you do it, Tony, grown up men like\nyou two?']
qText:
Well, I was last night. What made you do it, Tony, grown up men like
you two?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['We felt low.']
qText: We felt low.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['I bet you feel lower this morning... A box of white roses has just\narrived from Jock.']
qText:
I bet you feel lower this morning... A box of white roses has just
arrived from Jock.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["I wish I'd thought of that."]
qText: I wish I'd thought of that.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["You're such infants, both of you."]
qText: You're such infants, both of you.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["You aren't really in a rage?"]
qText: You aren't really in a rage?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Of course I'm not, darling. Now just you go straight back to the\ncountry. You'll feel all right again to-morrow."]
qText:
Of course I'm not, darling. Now just you go straight back to the
country. You'll feel all right again to-morrow.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Am I not going to see you?']
qText: Am I not going to see you?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Not to-day, I'm afraid. I've got lectures all the morning and I'm\nlunching out. But I'll be coming down on Friday evening or anyway\nSaturday morning."]
qText:
Not to-day, I'm afraid. I've got lectures all the morning and I'm
lunching out. But I'll be coming down on Friday evening or anyway
Saturday morning.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["I see. You couldn't possibly chuck lunch or one of the lectures?"]
qText: I see. You couldn't possibly chuck lunch or one of the lectures?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Not possibly, darling.']
qText: Not possibly, darling.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['I see. You are an angel to be so sweet about last night.']
qText: I see. You are an angel to be so sweet about last night.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr:
['Nothing could have been more fortunate,', "If I know Tony,
he'll be tortured with guilt for weeks to come. It was maddening last
night but it was worth it. He's put himself so much in the wrong now
that he won't dare to _feel_ resentful, let alone say anything, whatever
I do. And he hasn't really enjoyed himself at all, the poor sweet, so
_that's_ a good thing too. He had to learn not to make surprise visits."]
qText:
Nothing could have been more fortunate, If I know Tony,
he'll be tortured with guilt for weeks to come. It was maddening last
night but it was worth it. He's put himself so much in the wrong now
that he won't dare to _feel_ resentful, let alone say anything, whatever
I do. And he hasn't really enjoyed himself at all, the poor sweet, so
_that's_ a good thing too. He had to learn not to make surprise visits.
speaker: Brenda
menEnts: [[], [['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last']]]

qTextArr: ['You are one for making people learn things,']
qText: You are one for making people learn things,
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["Hullo, daddy, had a good\ntime in London? You didn't mind me coming to the station, did you? I\n_made_ nanny let me."]
qText:
Hullo, daddy, had a good
time in London? You didn't mind me coming to the station, did you? I
_made_ nanny let me.
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ['Very pleased to see you, John.']
qText: Very pleased to see you, John.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['How was mummy?']
qText: How was mummy?
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ["She sounded very well. I didn't see her."]
qText: She sounded very well. I didn't see her.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['But you _said_ you were going to see her.']
qText: But you _said_ you were going to see her.
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ['Yes, I thought I was, but I turned out to be wrong. I talked to her\nseveral times on the telephone.']
qText:
Yes, I thought I was, but I turned out to be wrong. I talked to her
several times on the telephone.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["But you can telephone her from here, can't you, daddy? Why did you go\nall the way to London to telephone her?... _Why_, daddy?"]
qText:
But you can telephone her from here, can't you, daddy? Why did you go
all the way to London to telephone her?... _Why_, daddy?
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ['It would take too long to explain.']
qText: It would take too long to explain.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Well tell me some of it... _Why_, daddy?']
qText: Well tell me some of it... _Why_, daddy?
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ["Look here, I'm tired. If you don't stop asking questions I shan't let\nyou ever come and meet the train again."]
qText:
Look here, I'm tired. If you don't stop asking questions I shan't let
you ever come and meet the train again.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["I thought you'd _like_ me to come\nand meet you."]
qText:
I thought you'd _like_ me to come
and meet you.
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ["If you cry I shall put you in front with Dawson. It's absurd to cry at\nyour age."]
qText:
If you cry I shall put you in front with Dawson. It's absurd to cry at
your age.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["I'd _sooner_ go in front with Dawson,"]
qText: I'd _sooner_ go in front with Dawson,
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ["Nanny, I don't\nwant John to come to the station in future unless her ladyship or I\nspecially say he can."]
qText:
Nanny, I don't
want John to come to the station in future unless her ladyship or I
specially say he can.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["No, sir, I wouldn't have let him go to-day, only he went on so. Come\nalong now, John, and take off your coat. Goodness, child, where's your\nhandkerchief?"]
qText:
No, sir, I wouldn't have let him go to-day, only he went on so. Come
along now, John, and take off your coat. Goodness, child, where's your
handkerchief?
speaker: Nanny
menEnts: [[['Tony Last'], ['John Andrew'], ['John Andrew'], ['John Andrew'], ['John Last'], ['John Andrew']]]

qTextArr:
['Two men of
thirty,', 'behaving as if they were up for the night
from Sandhurst--getting drunk and ringing people up and dancing with
tarts at the Old Hundredth... And it makes it all the worse that Brenda
was so nice about it.']
qText:
Two men of
thirty, behaving as if they were up for the night
from Sandhurst--getting drunk and ringing people up and dancing with
tarts at the Old Hundredth... And it makes it all the worse that Brenda
was so nice about it.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Ambrose, when I'm alone I think in future I'll have\ndinner in the library."]
qText:
Ambrose, when I'm alone I think in future I'll have
dinner in the library.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Ambrose, when I'm alone I don't\nreally need a long dinner. In future I'll just have two courses."]
qText:
Ambrose, when I'm alone I don't
really need a long dinner. In future I'll just have two courses.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['When I wake up it will be the week-end.']
qText: When I wake up it will be the week-end.
speaker: Tony Last
refExp: He looked over some accounts his agent had left for him and then went to bed saying to himself

qTextArr: ['She usually\ndoes better than this.']
qText:
She usually
does better than this.
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ['Not till to-morrow.']
qText: Not till to-morrow.
speaker: Tony Last

qText: Oh.
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ["I've got to go over to Little Bayton this afternoon. Would you like to\ncome too and perhaps we could see the kennels?"]
qText:
I've got to go over to Little Bayton this afternoon. Would you like to
come too and perhaps we could see the kennels?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['No, thank\nyou,', "I want to finish a picture I'm painting."]
qText:
No, thank
you, I want to finish a picture I'm painting.
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ['You can do that any time.']
qText: You can do that any time.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['I want to do it this afternoon.']
qText: I want to do it this afternoon.
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ["Whatever made you speak to your dad\nlike that for? You've been going on about seeing the kennels since\nChristmas."]
qText:
Whatever made you speak to your dad
like that for? You've been going on about seeing the kennels since
Christmas.
speaker: Ben

qTextArr: ['Not with _him_,']
qText: Not with _him_,
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ["You ungrateful little bastard, that's a lousy way to speak of your\ndad."]
qText:
You ungrateful little bastard, that's a lousy way to speak of your
dad.
speaker: Ben

qTextArr: ['And you ought not to say bastard or lousy in front of me, nanny says\nnot.']
qText:
And you ought not to say bastard or lousy in front of me, nanny says
not.
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ["My poor Brenda, it's an appalling room,"]
qText: My poor Brenda, it's an appalling room,
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

qTextArr: ["It's not one we use a great deal,"]
qText: It's not one we use a great deal,
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['I should think not,']
qText: I should think not,
speaker: Veronica
refExp: said the one they called Veronica

qTextArr: ["I can't see much wrong with it,", "except it's a bit\nmouldy."]
qText:
I can't see much wrong with it, except it's a bit
mouldy.
speaker: Polly Cockpurse

qTextArr:
['You see,', "What I thought was
that I must have _one_ habitable room downstairs. At present there's
only the smoking-room and the library. The drawing-room is vast and
quite out of the question. I thought what I needed was a small
sitting-room more or less to myself. Don't you think it has
possibilities?"]
qText:
You see, What I thought was
that I must have _one_ habitable room downstairs. At present there's
only the smoking-room and the library. The drawing-room is vast and
quite out of the question. I thought what I needed was a small
sitting-room more or less to myself. Don't you think it has
possibilities?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["But, my angel, the _shape's_ all wrong,", "and that\nchimney-piece--what is it made of, pink granite, and all the plaster\nwork and the dado. _Everything's_ horrible. It's so _dark_."]
qText:
But, my angel, the _shape's_ all wrong, and that
chimney-piece--what is it made of, pink granite, and all the plaster
work and the dado. _Everything's_ horrible. It's so _dark_.
speaker: Daisy

qTextArr:
['I know exactly what Brenda wants,', "I
don't think it will be impossible. I must think about it. As Veronica
says, the structure does rather limit one... you know, I think the only
thing to do would be to disregard it altogether and find some treatment
so definite that it _carried_ the room, if you see what I mean...
supposing we covered the walls with white chromium plating and had
natural sheepskin carpet... I wonder if that would be running you in
for more than you meant to spend?"]
qText:
I know exactly what Brenda wants, I
don't think it will be impossible. I must think about it. As Veronica
says, the structure does rather limit one... you know, I think the only
thing to do would be to disregard it altogether and find some treatment
so definite that it _carried_ the room, if you see what I mean...
supposing we covered the walls with white chromium plating and had
natural sheepskin carpet... I wonder if that would be running you in
for more than you meant to spend?
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

qTextArr: ["I'd blow the whole thing sky-high,"]
qText: I'd blow the whole thing sky-high,
speaker: Veronica

qTextArr: ["D'you really want Mrs Beaver to do up the morning-room?"]
qText: D'you really want Mrs Beaver to do up the morning-room?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Not if you don't, sweet."]
qText: Not if you don't, sweet.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['But can you imagine it--white chromium plating?']
qText: But can you imagine it--white chromium plating?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Oh, that was just an idea.']
qText: Oh, that was just an idea.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['I say,', "You aren't going away to-morrow too, are you?"]
qText: I say, You aren't going away to-morrow too, are you?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Must.']
qText: Must.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['By the way,', 'what did you think about keeping on\nGrimshawe?--it seems rather a waste.']
qText:
By the way, what did you think about keeping on
Grimshawe?--it seems rather a waste.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["You used always to say you couldn't get on without her."]
qText: You used always to say you couldn't get on without her.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Yes, but now I'm living at the flat everything's so simple."]
qText: Yes, but now I'm living at the flat everything's so simple.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['_Living?_ Darling, you talk as though you had settled there for good.']
qText: _Living?_ Darling, you talk as though you had settled there for good.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["D'you mind moving a second, sweet? I can't see properly."]
qText: D'you mind moving a second, sweet? I can't see properly.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Brenda, how long are you going on with this course of economics?']
qText: Brenda, how long are you going on with this course of economics?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Me? I don't know."]
qText: Me? I don't know.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['But you must have some idea?']
qText: But you must have some idea?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Oh, it's surprising what a lot there is to learn... I was so backward\nwhen I started..."]
qText:
Oh, it's surprising what a lot there is to learn... I was so backward
when I started...
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Brenda...']
qText: Brenda...
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Now run and put on your coat. They'll all be downstairs waiting for\nus."]
qText:
Now run and put on your coat. They'll all be downstairs waiting for
us.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Why, Tony,', 'Why,\nTony,', 'I was almost asleep.']
qText:
Why, Tony, Why,
Tony, I was almost asleep.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Very tired?']
qText: Very tired?
speaker: Tony Last

qText: Mm.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Want to be left alone?']
qText: Want to be left alone?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["So tired... and I've just drunk a lot of that stuff of Polly's."]
qText: So tired... and I've just drunk a lot of that stuff of Polly's.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['I see... well, good night.']
qText: I see... well, good night.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Good night... don't mind, do you?... so tired."]
qText: Good night... don't mind, do you?... so tired.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Lady Brenda not ill, I hope?']
qText: Lady Brenda not ill, I hope?
speaker: The Vicar

qTextArr: ['No, nothing serious, thank you very much. She gets rather done up in\nLondon, you know, during the week, and likes to take Sunday quietly.']
qText:
No, nothing serious, thank you very much. She gets rather done up in
London, you know, during the week, and likes to take Sunday quietly.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['And how are the great studies progressing?']
qText: And how are the great studies progressing?
speaker: The Vicar

qTextArr: ['Very well, I gather. She seems keen on it still.']
qText: Very well, I gather. She seems keen on it still.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Splendid. We shall all be coming to her soon to solve our economic\nproblems. But I daresay you and John miss her?']
qText:
Splendid. We shall all be coming to her soon to solve our economic
problems. But I daresay you and John miss her?
speaker: The Vicar

qTextArr: ['Yes, we do rather.']
qText: Yes, we do rather.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Well, please give her my kindest regards.']
qText: Well, please give her my kindest regards.
speaker: The Vicar

qTextArr: ['I will indeed. Thank you so much.']
qText: I will indeed. Thank you so much.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Come in, darling, it isn't anything. It's only we had a bet on what\ncoloured buttonhole you'd be wearing and none of us won."]
qText:
Come in, darling, it isn't anything. It's only we had a bet on what
coloured buttonhole you'd be wearing and none of us won.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr:
["Any time you are buying cuttings
or seeds do get them through me. I've made quite a little business of
it, perhaps you didn't know... all kinds of rather unusual flowers. I
do everything like that for Sylvia Newport and all sorts of people."]
qText:
Any time you are buying cuttings
or seeds do get them through me. I've made quite a little business of
it, perhaps you didn't know... all kinds of rather unusual flowers. I
do everything like that for Sylvia Newport and all sorts of people.
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

qTextArr: ['You must talk to my head man about it.']
qText: You must talk to my head man about it.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Well, to tell you the truth I _have_--this morning while you were in\nchurch. He seems quite to understand.']
qText:
Well, to tell you the truth I _have_--this morning while you were in
church. He seems quite to understand.
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

qTextArr: ['Golly, what a house.']
qText: Golly, what a house.
speaker: Daisy

qTextArr: ["Now you can see what I've been through all these years."]
qText: Now you can see what I've been through all these years.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['My poor Brenda,']
qText: My poor Brenda,
speaker: Veronica

qTextArr: ['You know,', "I'm not _absolutely_ happy about\nTony."]
qText:
You know, I'm not _absolutely_ happy about
Tony.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["What's the old boy been up to?"]
qText: What's the old boy been up to?
speaker: Polly Cockpurse

qTextArr: ["Nothing much yet, but I do see it's pretty boring for him at Hetton all\nthis time."]
qText:
Nothing much yet, but I do see it's pretty boring for him at Hetton all
this time.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["I shouldn't worry."]
qText: I shouldn't worry.
speaker: Polly Cockpurse

qTextArr: ["Oh, I'm not _worrying_. It's only, supposing he took to drink or\nsomething. It would make everything very difficult."]
qText:
Oh, I'm not _worrying_. It's only, supposing he took to drink or
something. It would make everything very difficult.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["I shouldn't have said that was his thing... We must get him interested\nin a girl."]
qText:
I shouldn't have said that was his thing... We must get him interested
in a girl.
speaker: Polly Cockpurse

qTextArr: ['If only we could... Who is there?']
qText: If only we could... Who is there?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["There's always old Sybil."]
qText: There's always old Sybil.
speaker: Polly Cockpurse

qTextArr: ["Darling, he's known her all his life."]
qText: Darling, he's known her all his life.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Or Souki de Foucauld-Esterhazy.']
qText: Or Souki de Foucauld-Esterhazy.
speaker: Polly Cockpurse

qTextArr: ["He isn't his best with Americans."]
qText: He isn't his best with Americans.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["Well, we'll find him someone."]
qText: Well, we'll find him someone.
speaker: Polly Cockpurse

qTextArr: ["The trouble is that I've become such a habit with him--he won't take\neasily to a new one... ought she to be like me, or quite different?"]
qText:
The trouble is that I've become such a habit with him--he won't take
easily to a new one... ought she to be like me, or quite different?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["I'd say different, but it's hard to tell."]
qText: I'd say different, but it's hard to tell.
speaker: Polly Cockpurse

qTextArr: ["Are you _certain_ Jenny will be Tony's tea?"]
qText: Are you _certain_ Jenny will be Tony's tea?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["You can't ever be certain,", "She bores my pants off, but\nshe's a good trier."]
qText:
You can't ever be certain, She bores my pants off, but
she's a good trier.
speaker: Polly Cockpurse

qTextArr: ['Is mummy coming down to-day, daddy?']
qText: Is mummy coming down to-day, daddy?
speaker: John Andrew

qText: Yes.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Who else?']
qText: Who else?
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ['Someone called Jenny Abdul Akbar.']
qText: Someone called Jenny Abdul Akbar.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['What a silly name. Is she foreign?']
qText: What a silly name. Is she foreign?
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ["I don't know."]
qText: I don't know.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Sounds foreign, doesn't she, daddy? D'you think she won't be able to\ntalk any English? Is she black?"]
qText:
Sounds foreign, doesn't she, daddy? D'you think she won't be able to
talk any English? Is she black?
speaker: John Andrew
menEnts: [[['Jenny Abdul Akbar'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Jenny Abdul Akbar'], ['Jenny Abdul Akbar']]]

qTextArr: ['Mummy says not.']
qText: Mummy says not.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Oh... who else?']
qText: Oh... who else?
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ['Lady Cockpurse.']
qText: Lady Cockpurse.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr:
["The monkey-woman. You know she wasn't a bit like a monkey except
perhaps her face and I don't think she had a tail because I looked as
close as anything... unless perhaps she has it rolled up between her
legs. D'you think she has, daddy?"]
qText:
The monkey-woman. You know she wasn't a bit like a monkey except
perhaps her face and I don't think she had a tail because I looked as
close as anything... unless perhaps she has it rolled up between her
legs. D'you think she has, daddy?
speaker: John Andrew
menEnts: [[['Polly Cockpurse'], ['Tony Last'], ['Polly Cockpurse'], ['Polly Cockpurse'], ['Polly Cockpurse'], ['Polly Cockpurse'], ['Polly'], ['Tony Last'], ['Polly Cockpurse'], ['Tony Last']]]

qTextArr: ["I shouldn't be surprised."]
qText: I shouldn't be surprised.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['_Very_ uncomfortable.']
qText: _Very_ uncomfortable.
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ['Give\nthe girl a chance to get down to it,']
qText:
Give
the girl a chance to get down to it,
speaker: Polly Cockpurse

qTextArr: ['Princess Abdul Akbar.']
qText: Princess Abdul Akbar.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Oh, Mr Last,', 'what a sweet old place this is.']
qText: Oh, Mr Last, what a sweet old place this is.
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

qTextArr: ["I'm afraid it's been restored a great deal,"]
qText: I'm afraid it's been restored a great deal,
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Ah, but its _atmosphere_. I always think that's what counts in a house.\nSuch dignity, and repose. But of course you're used to it. When you've\nbeen very unhappy as I have, you appreciate these things."]
qText:
Ah, but its _atmosphere_. I always think that's what counts in a house.
Such dignity, and repose. But of course you're used to it. When you've
been very unhappy as I have, you appreciate these things.
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

qTextArr: ["I'm afraid Brenda hasn't arrived yet. She's coming by car\nwith Lady Cockpurse."]
qText:
I'm afraid Brenda hasn't arrived yet. She's coming by car
with Lady Cockpurse.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Brenda's been _such_ a friend to me."]
qText: Brenda's been _such_ a friend to me.
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

qTextArr: ["D'you\nmind if I take off my hat?"]
qText:
D'you
mind if I take off my hat?
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

qTextArr: ['No, no... of course.']
qText: No, no... of course.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr:
['D'you know, Mr Last, I'm going to call you Teddy right
away. You don't think that very fresh of me? And you must call me Jenny.
"Princess" is so formal, isn't it, and suggests tight trousers and gold
braid... Of course', 'my husband
was not called "Prince" in Morocco; his title was Moulay--but there's no
proper equivalent for a woman, so I've always called myself Princess in
Europe... Moulay is _far_ higher really... my husband was a descendant
of the Prophet. Are you interested in the East?']
qText:
D'you know, Mr Last, I'm going to call you Teddy right
away. You don't think that very fresh of me? And you must call me Jenny.
"Princess" is so formal, isn't it, and suggests tight trousers and gold
braid... Of course my husband
was not called "Prince" in Morocco; his title was Moulay--but there's no
proper equivalent for a woman, so I've always called myself Princess in
Europe... Moulay is _far_ higher really... my husband was a descendant
of the Prophet. Are you interested in the East?
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar
menEnts: [[['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Jenny Abdul Akbar'], ['Jenny Abdul Akbar']], [['Moulay'], ['Moulay'], ['Moulay'], ['Tony Last']]]

qTextArr: ['No... yes. I mean I know very little about it.']
qText: No... yes. I mean I know very little about it.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["It has an uncanny fascination for me. You must go there, Teddy. I know\nyou'd like it. I've been saying the same to Brenda."]
qText:
It has an uncanny fascination for me. You must go there, Teddy. I know
you'd like it. I've been saying the same to Brenda.
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

qTextArr: ["I expect you'd like to see your room,", "They'll bring tea\nsoon."]
qText:
I expect you'd like to see your room, They'll bring tea
soon.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["No, I'll stay here. I like just to curl up like a cat in front of the\nfire, and if you're nice to me I'll purr, and if you're cruel I shall\npretend not to notice--just like a cat... Shall I purr, Teddy?"]
qText:
No, I'll stay here. I like just to curl up like a cat in front of the
fire, and if you're nice to me I'll purr, and if you're cruel I shall
pretend not to notice--just like a cat... Shall I purr, Teddy?
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

qTextArr: ["Er... yes... do, please, if that's what you like doing."]
qText: Er... yes... do, please, if that's what you like doing.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr:
["Englishmen are so gentle and considerate. It's wonderful to be back
among them... mine own people. Sometimes when I look back at my life,
especially at times like this, among lovely old English things and kind
people, I think the whole thing must be a frightful nightmare... then I
remember my _scars_..."]
qText:
Englishmen are so gentle and considerate. It's wonderful to be back
among them... mine own people. Sometimes when I look back at my life,
especially at times like this, among lovely old English things and kind
people, I think the whole thing must be a frightful nightmare... then I
remember my _scars_...
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

qTextArr: ["Brenda tells me you've taken one of the flats in the same house as\nhers. They must be very convenient."]
qText:
Brenda tells me you've taken one of the flats in the same house as
hers. They must be very convenient.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr:
["How English you are, Teddy--so shy of talking about personal things,
intimate things... I like you for that, you know. I love everything
that's solid and homely and _good_ after... after all I've been
through."]
qText:
How English you are, Teddy--so shy of talking about personal things,
intimate things... I like you for that, you know. I love everything
that's solid and homely and _good_ after... after all I've been
through.
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

qTextArr: ["You're not studying economics too, are you, like Brenda?"]
qText: You're not studying economics too, are you, like Brenda?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['No; is Brenda? She never told me. What a wonderful person she is. When\n_does_ she find the time?']
qText:
No; is Brenda? She never told me. What a wonderful person she is. When
_does_ she find the time?
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

qTextArr: ['Ah, here comes tea at last,', 'I hope you allow yourself to\neat muffins. So many of our guests nowadays are on a diet. I think\nmuffins one of the few things that make the English winter endurable.']
qText:
Ah, here comes tea at last, I hope you allow yourself to
eat muffins. So many of our guests nowadays are on a diet. I think
muffins one of the few things that make the English winter endurable.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Muffins stand for so much,']
qText: Muffins stand for so much,
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

qTextArr: ['Come and be introduced to Princess Abdul Akbar.']
qText: Come and be introduced to Princess Abdul Akbar.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Aren't you going to give me a kiss?"]
qText: Aren't you going to give me a kiss?
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

qTextArr: ['Oh,', 'What a beautiful smell.']
qText: Oh, What a beautiful smell.
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ["It's my last link with the East,"]
qText: It's my last link with the East,
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

qTextArr: ["You've got butter on your chin."]
qText: You've got butter on your chin.
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ['Why, so I have. Teddy, you _might_\nhave told me.']
qText:
Why, so I have. Teddy, you _might_
have told me.
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

qTextArr: ['Why do you call daddy Teddy?']
qText: Why do you call daddy Teddy?
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ['Because I hope we are going to be great friends.']
qText: Because I hope we are going to be great friends.
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

qTextArr: ['What a funny reason.']
qText: What a funny reason.
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ['Have you got a crown?', 'How did you learn to speak English?\nWhat is that big ring made of? Did it cost much? Why are your nails that\ncolour? Can you ride?']
qText:
Have you got a crown? How did you learn to speak English?
What is that big ring made of? Did it cost much? Why are your nails that
colour? Can you ride?
speaker: John Andrew
menEnts: [[['Jenny Abdul Akbar']], [['Jenny Abdul Akbar'], ['Jenny Abdul Akbar']]]

qTextArr: ['That is my only crown... now,']
qText: That is my only crown... now,
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

qTextArr: ["On the Moulay's birthday--"]
qText: On the Moulay's birthday--
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

qTextArr: ["What's the Moulay?"]
qText: What's the Moulay?
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr:
['A beautiful and a very bad man,', 'and on his birthday
all his horsemen used to assemble round a great square, with all their
finest clothes and trappings and jewels, with long swords in their
hands. The Moulay used to sit on a throne under a great crimson canopy.']
qText:
A beautiful and a very bad man, and on his birthday
all his horsemen used to assemble round a great square, with all their
finest clothes and trappings and jewels, with long swords in their
hands. The Moulay used to sit on a throne under a great crimson canopy.
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

qTextArr: ["What's a canopy?"]
qText: What's a canopy?
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr:
['Like a tent,', 'and all the horsemen used to gallop across the plain, in a great cloud
of dust, waving their swords, straight towards the Moulay. And everyone
used to hold their breath, thinking the horsemen were bound to ride
right on top of the Moulay, but when they were a few feet away, as near
as I am to you, galloping at full speed, they used to rein their horses
back, up on to their hind legs and salute--']
qText:
Like a tent, and all the horsemen used to gallop across the plain, in a great cloud
of dust, waving their swords, straight towards the Moulay. And everyone
used to hold their breath, thinking the horsemen were bound to ride
right on top of the Moulay, but when they were a few feet away, as near
as I am to you, galloping at full speed, they used to rein their horses
back, up on to their hind legs and salute--
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

qTextArr: ["Oh, but they _shouldn't_,", "It's _very_ bad horsemanship\nindeed. Ben says so."]
qText:
Oh, but they _shouldn't_, It's _very_ bad horsemanship
indeed. Ben says so.
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ["They're the most wonderful horsemen in the world. Everyone knows that."]
qText: They're the most wonderful horsemen in the world. Everyone knows that.
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

qTextArr: ["Oh, no, they can't be, if they do _that_. It's one of the _worst_\nthings. Were they natives?"]
qText:
Oh, no, they can't be, if they do _that_. It's one of the _worst_
things. Were they natives?
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ['Yes, of course.']
qText: Yes, of course.
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

qTextArr: ["Ben says natives aren't humans at all really."]
qText: Ben says natives aren't humans at all really.
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ["Ah, but he's thinking of Negroes, I expect. These are pure Semitic\ntype."]
qText:
Ah, but he's thinking of Negroes, I expect. These are pure Semitic
type.
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

qTextArr: ["What's that?"]
qText: What's that?
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ['The same as Jews.']
qText: The same as Jews.
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

qTextArr: ['Ben says Jews are worse than natives.']
qText: Ben says Jews are worse than natives.
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ['Oh dear, what a very severe boy you are. I was like that once. Life\nteaches one to be tolerant.']
qText:
Oh dear, what a very severe boy you are. I was like that once. Life
teaches one to be tolerant.
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

qTextArr: ["It hasn't taught Ben,", "When's mummy coming? I thought she'd\nbe here, otherwise I wouldn't have stopped painting my picture."]
qText:
It hasn't taught Ben, When's mummy coming? I thought she'd
be here, otherwise I wouldn't have stopped painting my picture.
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ['Good night, Johnny-boy,']
qText: Good night, Johnny-boy,
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

qTextArr: ['What did you call me?']
qText: What did you call me?
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ['Johnny-boy.']
qText: Johnny-boy.
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

qTextArr: ['You are funny with names.']
qText: You are funny with names.
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ["Nanny, I do think that Princess is beautiful, don't you?"]
qText: Nanny, I do think that Princess is beautiful, don't you?
speaker: John Andrew

qTextArr: ['It would be a dull world if we all thought alike,']
qText: It would be a dull world if we all thought alike,
speaker: Nanny

qTextArr: ["She's more beautiful than Miss Tendril, even. I think she's the most\nbeautiful lady I've ever seen... D'you think she'd like to watch me\nhave my bath?"]
