qTextArr: ['Jock rang up. He wanted to know if there was\nanything he could do.']
qText:
Jock rang up. He wanted to know if there was
anything he could do.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["How sweet of him. Why don't you have him down for the week-end?"]
qText: How sweet of him. Why don't you have him down for the week-end?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Would you like that?']
qText: Would you like that?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["I shan't be here. I'm going to Veronica's."]
qText: I shan't be here. I'm going to Veronica's.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["You're going to Veronica's?"]
qText: You're going to Veronica's?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Yes, don't you remember?"]
qText: Yes, don't you remember?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Are you really going\naway?']
qText:
Are you really going
away?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Yes. I can't stay here. You understand that, don't you?"]
qText: Yes. I can't stay here. You understand that, don't you?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Yes, of course. I was thinking we might both go away, abroad\nsomewhere.']
qText:
Yes, of course. I was thinking we might both go away, abroad
somewhere.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["I couldn't\nstay here. It's all over, don't you see, our life down here."]
qText:
I couldn't
stay here. It's all over, don't you see, our life down here.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Darling, what _do_ you mean?']
qText: Darling, what _do_ you mean?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Don't ask me to explain... not just now."]
qText: Don't ask me to explain... not just now.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["But, Brenda, sweet, I don't understand. We're both young. Of course, we\ncan never forget John. He'll always be our eldest son, but..."]
qText:
But, Brenda, sweet, I don't understand. We're both young. Of course, we
can never forget John. He'll always be our eldest son, but...
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Don't go on, Tony, please don't go on."]
qText: Don't go on, Tony, please don't go on.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["So you're going to Veronica's\nto-morrow?"]
qText:
So you're going to Veronica's
to-morrow?
speaker: Tony Last
refExp: Tony stopped and after a time said

qTextArr: ['Mmmm.']
qText: Mmmm.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['I think I will ask Jock to come.']
qText: I think I will ask Jock to come.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Yes, I should.']
qText: Yes, I should.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["And we can think about plans later when we've got more used to things."]
qText: And we can think about plans later when we've got more used to things.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Yes, later.']
qText: Yes, later.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['A sweet letter from mother,']
qText: A sweet letter from mother,
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['I got a telegram from Jock,', 'he _can_ come.']
qText: I got a telegram from Jock, he _can_ come.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["It's really rather embarrassing for us all, Brenda coming,", "I do think she might have chucked. I shan't in the least know\nwhat to say to her."]
qText:
It's really rather embarrassing for us all, Brenda coming, I do think she might have chucked. I shan't in the least know
what to say to her.
speaker: Veronica

qTextArr:
["I've been trying to
understand, and I think I do now. It's not how I feel myself, but Brenda
and I are quite different in lots of ways. It's _because_ they were
strangers and didn't know John, and were never in our life here, that
she wants to be with them. That's it, don't you think? She wants to be
absolutely alone and away from everything that reminds her of what has
happened... all the same I feel awful about letting her go. I can't
tell you what she was like here... quite mechanical. It's so much worse
for her than it is for me, I see that. It's so terrible not being able
to do anything to help."]
qText:
I've been trying to
understand, and I think I do now. It's not how I feel myself, but Brenda
and I are quite different in lots of ways. It's _because_ they were
strangers and didn't know John, and were never in our life here, that
she wants to be with them. That's it, don't you think? She wants to be
absolutely alone and away from everything that reminds her of what has
happened... all the same I feel awful about letting her go. I can't
tell you what she was like here... quite mechanical. It's so much worse
for her than it is for me, I see that. It's so terrible not being able
to do anything to help.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Until Wednesday,\nwhen I thought something had happened to you, I had no idea that I loved\nyou.']
qText:
Until Wednesday,
when I thought something had happened to you, I had no idea that I loved
you.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["Well you've said it often enough."]
qText: Well you've said it often enough.
speaker: Beaver

qTextArr: ["I'm going to make you understand,", 'You clod.']
qText: I'm going to make you understand, You clod.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["She's only seen Beaver twice to my knowledge,"]
qText: She's only seen Beaver twice to my knowledge,
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["I'm sorry it should\nhave happened like this."]
qText:
I'm sorry it should
have happened like this.
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

qTextArr: ["But it's not true, is it?"]
qText: But it's not true, is it?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Yes, I'm afraid it is. Everyone has known for some time."]
qText: Yes, I'm afraid it is. Everyone has known for some time.
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

qTextArr: ["How's the old boy taking it?"]
qText: How's the old boy taking it?
speaker: Unknowable

qTextArr: ['Not so well. It makes me feel rather a beast,', "I'm afraid\nhe minds a lot."]
qText:
Not so well. It makes me feel rather a beast, I'm afraid
he minds a lot.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["Well, you wouldn't like it if he didn't,"]
qText: Well, you wouldn't like it if he didn't,
speaker: Polly Cockpurse

qTextArr: ['No, I suppose not.']
qText: No, I suppose not.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['I shall stick by you whatever happens,']
qText: I shall stick by you whatever happens,
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

qTextArr: ['Oh, everything is going quite smoothly now,', 'There was a\ncertain amount of _g?ne_ with relatives.']
qText:
Oh, everything is going quite smoothly now, There was a
certain amount of _g?ne_ with relatives.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['You just wait a few weeks,', "Brenda will come back. She'll\nsoon get sick of Beaver."]
qText:
You just wait a few weeks, Brenda will come back. She'll
soon get sick of Beaver.
speaker: Allan

qTextArr: ["But I don't want her back."]
qText: But I don't want her back.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr:
["I know just how you feel, but it doesn't do to be medieval about it. If
Brenda hadn't been upset at John's death this need never have come to a
crisis. Why, last year Marjorie was going everywhere with that ass Robin
Beaseley. She was mad about him at the time, but I pretended not to
notice and it all blew over. If I were you I should refuse to recognize
that anything has happened."]
qText:
I know just how you feel, but it doesn't do to be medieval about it. If
Brenda hadn't been upset at John's death this need never have come to a
crisis. Why, last year Marjorie was going everywhere with that ass Robin
Beaseley. She was mad about him at the time, but I pretended not to
notice and it all blew over. If I were you I should refuse to recognize
that anything has happened.
speaker: Allan

qTextArr:
["Of _course_ Brenda doesn't love Beaver. How could
she?... And if she thinks she does at the moment, it's your duty to
prevent her making a fool of herself. You must refuse to be
divorced--anyway, until she has found someone more reasonable."]
qText:
Of _course_ Brenda doesn't love Beaver. How could
she?... And if she thinks she does at the moment, it's your duty to
prevent her making a fool of herself. You must refuse to be
divorced--anyway, until she has found someone more reasonable.
speaker: Marjorie

qTextArr:
["Brenda has been very, very foolish. She always
was an excitable girl, but I am sure there was never anything _wrong_,
quite sure. _That_ wouldn't be like Brenda at all. I haven't met Mr
Beaver and I do not wish to. I understand he is unsuitable in every way.
Brenda would never want to marry anyone like that. I will tell you
exactly how it happened, Tony. Brenda must have felt a tiny bit
neglected--people often do at that stage of marriage. I have known
countless cases--and it was naturally flattering to find a young man to
beg and carry for her. That's all it was, nothing _wrong_. And then the
terrible shock of little John's accident unsettled her and she didn't
know what she was saying or writing. You'll both laugh over this little
fracas in years to come."]
qText:
Brenda has been very, very foolish. She always
was an excitable girl, but I am sure there was never anything _wrong_,
quite sure. _That_ wouldn't be like Brenda at all. I haven't met Mr
Beaver and I do not wish to. I understand he is unsuitable in every way.
Brenda would never want to marry anyone like that. I will tell you
exactly how it happened, Tony. Brenda must have felt a tiny bit
neglected--people often do at that stage of marriage. I have known
countless cases--and it was naturally flattering to find a young man to
beg and carry for her. That's all it was, nothing _wrong_. And then the
terrible shock of little John's accident unsettled her and she didn't
know what she was saying or writing. You'll both laugh over this little
fracas in years to come.
speaker: Lady St. Cloud

qTextArr: ["I've been talking to Brenda,", "She's sick\nof Beaver already. The one thing she wants is to go back to Hetton and\nsettle down with you again."]
qText:
I've been talking to Brenda, She's sick
of Beaver already. The one thing she wants is to go back to Hetton and
settle down with you again.
speaker: Allan

qTextArr: ['Brenda, this is Tony.']
qText: Brenda, this is Tony.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Hullo, Tony, what is it?']
qText: Hullo, Tony, what is it?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["I've been talking to Allan. He's just told me about your change of\nmind."]
qText:
I've been talking to Allan. He's just told me about your change of
mind.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["I'm not sure I know what you mean."]
qText: I'm not sure I know what you mean.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['That you want to leave Beaver and come back to Hetton.']
qText: That you want to leave Beaver and come back to Hetton.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Did Allan say that?']
qText: Did Allan say that?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["Yes; isn't it true?"]
qText: Yes; isn't it true?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr:
["I'm afraid it's not. Allan is an interfering ass. I had him here this
afternoon. He told me that you didn't want a divorce but that you were
willing to let me stay on alone in London and do as I liked provided
there was no public scandal. It seemed a good idea and I was going to
ring you up about it. But I suppose that's just his diplomacy too.
Anyway, I'm afraid there's no prospect of my coming back to Hetton just
at present."]
qText:
I'm afraid it's not. Allan is an interfering ass. I had him here this
afternoon. He told me that you didn't want a divorce but that you were
willing to let me stay on alone in London and do as I liked provided
there was no public scandal. It seemed a good idea and I was going to
ring you up about it. But I suppose that's just his diplomacy too.
Anyway, I'm afraid there's no prospect of my coming back to Hetton just
at present.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["Oh, I see. I didn't think it was likely... I just rang you up."]
qText: Oh, I see. I didn't think it was likely... I just rang you up.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["That's all right. How are you, Tony?"]
qText: That's all right. How are you, Tony?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['All right, thanks.']
qText: All right, thanks.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Good, so am I. Good-bye.']
qText: Good, so am I. Good-bye.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr:
["I gather Lady Brenda is being far from discreet. It is quite likely
that the King's Proctor may intervene... Moreover, there is the
question of money. You understand that by the present arrangement since
she is the innocent and injured party she will be entitled to claim
substantial alimony from the courts?"]
qText:
I gather Lady Brenda is being far from discreet. It is quite likely
that the King's Proctor may intervene... Moreover, there is the
question of money. You understand that by the present arrangement since
she is the innocent and injured party she will be entitled to claim
substantial alimony from the courts?
speaker: The Solicitor

qTextArr:
["Oh, that's all right,", "I've been into all that with her
brother-in-law and have decided to make a settlement of five hundred a
year. She has four hundred of her own and I understand Mr Beaver has
something."]
qText:
Oh, that's all right, I've been into all that with her
brother-in-law and have decided to make a settlement of five hundred a
year. She has four hundred of her own and I understand Mr Beaver has
something.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["It's a pity we can't put it in writing,", 'but that\nmight constitute Conspiracy.']
qText:
It's a pity we can't put it in writing, but that
might constitute Conspiracy.
speaker: The Solicitor

qTextArr: ["Lady Brenda's word is quite good enough,"]
qText: Lady Brenda's word is quite good enough,
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['We like to protect our clients against even the most remote\ncontingencies,']
qText:
We like to protect our clients against even the most remote
contingencies,
speaker: The Solicitor

qTextArr: ['We always\nsend our clients there. The servants are well accustomed to giving\nevidence']
qText:
We always
send our clients there. The servants are well accustomed to giving
evidence
speaker: The Solicitor

qTextArr:
['It only remains to
select a partner,', 'We have on occasions been instrumental in accommodating our
clients but there have been frequent complaints, so we find it best to
leave the choice to them. Lately we had a particularly delicate case
involving a man of very rigid morality and a certain diffidence. In the
end his own wife consented to go with him and supply the evidence. She
wore a red wig. It was quite successful.']
qText:
It only remains to
select a partner, We have on occasions been instrumental in accommodating our
clients but there have been frequent complaints, so we find it best to
leave the choice to them. Lately we had a particularly delicate case
involving a man of very rigid morality and a certain diffidence. In the
end his own wife consented to go with him and supply the evidence. She
wore a red wig. It was quite successful.
speaker: The Solicitor

qTextArr: ["I don't think that would do in this case."]
qText: I don't think that would do in this case.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['No. Exactly. I was merely quoting it as a matter of interest.']
qText: No. Exactly. I was merely quoting it as a matter of interest.
speaker: The Solicitor

qTextArr: ['I expect I shall be able to find someone,']
qText: I expect I shall be able to find someone,
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['I have no doubt of it,']
qText: I have no doubt of it,
speaker: The Solicitor

qTextArr:
["It's not a thing one can ask every girl to do,", "whichever way you put it. If you say it is merely a legal form it is
rather insulting, and if you suggest going the whole hog it's rather
fresh--suddenly, I mean, if you've never paid any particular attention
to her before and don't propose to carry on with it afterwards... Of
course there's always old Sybil."]
qText:
It's not a thing one can ask every girl to do, whichever way you put it. If you say it is merely a legal form it is
rather insulting, and if you suggest going the whole hog it's rather
fresh--suddenly, I mean, if you've never paid any particular attention
to her before and don't propose to carry on with it afterwards... Of
course there's always old Sybil.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr:
["I'd do it like a shot any other time,", "but just at the moment it wouldn't suit my book. There's a
certain person who might hear about it and take it wrong... There's an
awfully pretty girl called Jenny Abdul Akbar. I wonder if you've met
her."]
qText:
I'd do it like a shot any other time, but just at the moment it wouldn't suit my book. There's a
certain person who might hear about it and take it wrong... There's an
awfully pretty girl called Jenny Abdul Akbar. I wonder if you've met
her.
speaker: Sybil
menTexts: [[], ['an\nawfully pretty girl called Jenny Abdul Akbar', 'you']]

qTextArr: ["Yes, I've met her."]
qText: Yes, I've met her.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Well, won't she do?"]
qText: Well, won't she do?
speaker: Sybil

qText: No.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Oh dear, I don't know who to suggest."]
qText: Oh dear, I don't know who to suggest.
speaker: Sybil

qTextArr: ["We'd better go and study the market at the Old Hundredth,"]
qText: We'd better go and study the market at the Old Hundredth,
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

qTextArr: ['Is it any good going there yet?']
qText: Is it any good going there yet?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["We may as well try. After all, we aren't going there for enjoyment."]
qText: We may as well try. After all, we aren't going there for enjoyment.
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

qTextArr: ['No, indeed.']
qText: No, indeed.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Any of those do?']
qText: Any of those do?
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

qTextArr: ["I don't much care."]
qText: I don't much care.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Better get someone you like. You've got to put in a lot of time with\nher."]
qText:
Better get someone you like. You've got to put in a lot of time with
her.
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

qTextArr: ["How are the postmen's hats?"]
qText: How are the postmen's hats?
speaker: Milly

qTextArr: ["You are the two boys who were here last month, aren't you?"]
qText: You are the two boys who were here last month, aren't you?
speaker: Milly
menEnts: [[['Jock Grant-Menzies', 'Tony Last'], ['Tony Last', 'Jock Grant-Menzies'], ['Jock Grant-Menzies', 'Tony Last']]]

qTextArr: ["Yes. I'm afraid we were rather tight."]
qText: Yes. I'm afraid we were rather tight.
speaker: Unknowable

qTextArr: ["You don't say?"]
qText: You don't say?
speaker: Babs

qTextArr: ['Well, come and sit down. How are you both?']
qText: Well, come and sit down. How are you both?
speaker: Milly

qTextArr: ["I think I'm starting a cold,", "I feel awful. Why can't they\nheat this hole, the mean hounds?"]
qText:
I think I'm starting a cold, I feel awful. Why can't they
heat this hole, the mean hounds?
speaker: Babs

qTextArr: ['Care to\ndance?']
qText:
Care to
dance?
speaker: Milly

qTextArr: ['My friend is looking for a lady to take to the seaside,']
qText: My friend is looking for a lady to take to the seaside,
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

qTextArr: ["What, this weather? That'll be a nice treat for a lonely girl."]
qText: What, this weather? That'll be a nice treat for a lonely girl.
speaker: Babs

qTextArr: ["It's for a divorce."]
qText: It's for a divorce.
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

qTextArr:
["Oh, I see. Well, why doesn't he take Milly? She doesn't catch cold
easy. Besides, she knows how to behave at an hotel. Lots of the girls
here are all right to have a lark with in town, but you have to have a
_lady_ for a divorce."]
qText:
Oh, I see. Well, why doesn't he take Milly? She doesn't catch cold
easy. Besides, she knows how to behave at an hotel. Lots of the girls
here are all right to have a lark with in town, but you have to have a
_lady_ for a divorce.
speaker: Babs

qTextArr: ["D'you often get asked to do that?"]
qText: D'you often get asked to do that?
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

qTextArr: ["Now and then. It's a nice rest--but it means so much _talking_ and the\ngentlemen will always go on so about their wives."]
qText:
Now and then. It's a nice rest--but it means so much _talking_ and the
gentlemen will always go on so about their wives.
speaker: Babs

qTextArr: ["I suppose you\nwouldn't care to come away for the week-end?"]
qText:
I suppose you
wouldn't care to come away for the week-end?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Shouldn't mind,", 'Where?']
qText: Shouldn't mind, Where?
speaker: Milly

qTextArr: ['I thought of Brighton.']
qText: I thought of Brighton.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Oh... Is it for a divorce?']
qText: Oh... Is it for a divorce?
speaker: Milly

qText: Yes.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["You wouldn't mind if I brought my little girl with us? She wouldn't be\nany trouble."]
qText:
You wouldn't mind if I brought my little girl with us? She wouldn't be
any trouble.
speaker: Milly

qText: Yes.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["You mean you wouldn't mind?"]
qText: You mean you wouldn't mind?
speaker: Milly

qTextArr: ['I mean I should mind.']
qText: I mean I should mind.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Oh... You wouldn't think I had a little girl of eight, would you?"]
qText: Oh... You wouldn't think I had a little girl of eight, would you?
speaker: Milly

qText: No.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr:
["She's called Winnie. I was only sixteen when I had her. I was the
youngest of the family and our stepfather wouldn't leave any of us girls
alone. That's why I have to work. She lives with a lady at Finchley.
Twenty-eight bob a week it costs me, not counting her clothes. She does
like the seaside."]
qText:
She's called Winnie. I was only sixteen when I had her. I was the
youngest of the family and our stepfather wouldn't leave any of us girls
alone. That's why I have to work. She lives with a lady at Finchley.
Twenty-eight bob a week it costs me, not counting her clothes. She does
like the seaside.
speaker: Milly

qTextArr: ['No,', "I'm sorry but it would be quite impossible. We'll get\na lovely present for you to take back to her."]
qText:
No, I'm sorry but it would be quite impossible. We'll get
a lovely present for you to take back to her.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['All right... One gentleman gave her a fairy-cycle for Christmas. She\nfell off and cut her knee... When do we start?']
qText:
All right... One gentleman gave her a fairy-cycle for Christmas. She
fell off and cut her knee... When do we start?
speaker: Milly

qTextArr: ['Would you like to go by train or car?']
qText: Would you like to go by train or car?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Oh, train. Winnie's sick if she goes in a car."]
qText: Oh, train. Winnie's sick if she goes in a car.
speaker: Milly

qTextArr: ["Winnie's not coming."]
qText: Winnie's not coming.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["No, but let's go by train anyway."]
qText: No, but let's go by train anyway.
speaker: Milly

qTextArr: ['This is going to be hell,']
qText: This is going to be hell,
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Sorry if I'm late,", "Winnie here couldn't find\nher shoes. I brought her along too. I knew you wouldn't mind really. She\ntravels on a half ticket."]
qText:
Sorry if I'm late, Winnie here couldn't find
her shoes. I brought her along too. I knew you wouldn't mind really. She
travels on a half ticket.
speaker: Milly

qTextArr: ["I hope you don't imagine she's coming with us."]
qText: I hope you don't imagine she's coming with us.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Yes, that the idea,', "She won't be any trouble--she's got\nher puzzle."]
qText:
Yes, that the idea, She won't be any trouble--she's got
her puzzle.
speaker: Milly

qTextArr:
['Listen,', "You
don't want to come to a nasty big hotel. You go with this kind gentleman
here. He'll take you to a shop and let you choose the biggest doll you
can find and then he'll drive you back in his motor to your home. You'll
like that, won't you?"]
qText:
Listen, You
don't want to come to a nasty big hotel. You go with this kind gentleman
here. He'll take you to a shop and let you choose the biggest doll you
can find and then he'll drive you back in his motor to your home. You'll
like that, won't you?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['No,', "I want to go to the seaside. I won't go with that\nman. I don't want a doll. I want to go to the seaside with my mummy."]
qText:
No, I want to go to the seaside. I won't go with that
man. I don't want a doll. I want to go to the seaside with my mummy.
speaker: Winnie

qTextArr: ['Oh God!', "I suppose she's got to come."]
qText: Oh God! I suppose she's got to come.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Look,', "we're travelling\nfirst-class. Isn't that fun? We can have tea."]
qText:
Look, we're travelling
first-class. Isn't that fun? We can have tea.
speaker: Milly

qTextArr: ['Can I have an ice?']
qText: Can I have an ice?
speaker: Winnie

qTextArr: ["I don't expect they've got an ice. But you can have some nice tea."]
qText: I don't expect they've got an ice. But you can have some nice tea.
speaker: Milly

qTextArr: ['But I want an ice.']
qText: But I want an ice.
speaker: Winnie

qTextArr: ["You shall have an ice when you get to Brighton. Now be a good girl and\nplay with your puzzle or mother won't take you to the seaside again."]
qText:
You shall have an ice when you get to Brighton. Now be a good girl and
play with your puzzle or mother won't take you to the seaside again.

qText: So am I,
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["A pity we've such a nasty week-end for the job,", 'very\ndamp and blowy. Gets me in the joints.']
qText:
A pity we've such a nasty week-end for the job, very
damp and blowy. Gets me in the joints.

qTextArr: ['Tell me,', 'Is it usual to bring children on an expedition of\nthis kind?']
qText:
Tell me, Is it usual to bring children on an expedition of
this kind?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['It is _not_.']
qText: It is _not_.
speaker: The Detective

qTextArr: ["I thought it couldn't be."]
qText: I thought it couldn't be.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr:
["Since you ask me, Mr Last, I regard it as most irregular and
injudicious. It looks wrong, and cases of this kind depend very much on
making the right impression. Of course as far as James and me are
concerned, the matter is O.K. There won't be a word about it in our
evidence. But you can't trust the servants. You might very likely happen
to strike one who was new to the courts, who'd blurt it out, and then
where would we be. I don't like it, Mr Last, and that's the truth."]
qText:
Since you ask me, Mr Last, I regard it as most irregular and
injudicious. It looks wrong, and cases of this kind depend very much on
making the right impression. Of course as far as James and me are
concerned, the matter is O.K. There won't be a word about it in our
evidence. But you can't trust the servants. You might very likely happen
to strike one who was new to the courts, who'd blurt it out, and then
where would we be. I don't like it, Mr Last, and that's the truth.
speaker: The Detective

when Monday comes."]

It's easier in the summer, the young ladies usually
bathe and the gentlemen read the papers on the esplanade; some goes for

He's a very nice boy, and comes to the club a lot.

qText: His girl didn't seem to like us much.

qText: That's a pretty girl in the corner.

speaker: Milly

qText: Look at that woman's diamonds. Do you think they can be real?

qText: Why don't you ask her, if you're so interested?

This stuff's all right, it won't hurt

I'm so glad Dan brought you, Hope you're getting all

qText: Yes.

qText: No, it's very surprising.

week-end and she wanted to bring the child along too. Of course that put
the kybosh on it, but I've always liked Milly just the same. You can
trust her to behave anywhere."]
qText:
I didn't know for ages. Then I was taking her to Dieppe for the
week-end and she wanted to bring the child along too. Of course that put
the kybosh on it, but I've always liked Milly just the same. You can
trust her to behave anywhere.
speaker: Dan

I doubt if you'll

speaker: Winnie

All right.

qText: I'll wait here. Mother snores so.

qText: Oh, come on,
speaker: Winnie

qText: Why don't you bathe?

qText: Far too cold.

qText: But _they're_ bathing. I want to.

qText: You must ask your mother.

speaker: Winnie

qTextArr:
['Well,', "We have our case now, all quite
regular and complete. I don't think it can come on until next
term--there's a great rush at the moment, but there's no harm in you
having your own evidence ready. I've got it typed out for you. You'd
better keep it by you and get it clear in your mind."]
qText:
Well, We have our case now, all quite
regular and complete. I don't think it can come on until next
term--there's a great rush at the moment, but there's no harm in you
having your own evidence ready. I've got it typed out for you. You'd
better keep it by you and get it clear in your mind.
speaker: Brenda'S Solicitor

qTextArr: ['Is that\nnecessary?']
qText:
Is that
necessary?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr:
['Not strictly, but it is advisable to put it in. A great deal depends on
psychological impression. Judges in their more lucid moments sometimes
wonder why perfectly respectable, happily married men go off for
week-ends to the seaside with women they do not know. It is always
helpful to offer evidence of general degeneracy.']
qText:
Not strictly, but it is advisable to put it in. A great deal depends on
psychological impression. Judges in their more lucid moments sometimes
wonder why perfectly respectable, happily married men go off for
week-ends to the seaside with women they do not know. It is always
helpful to offer evidence of general degeneracy.
speaker: Brenda'S Solicitor

qTextArr: ['I see,', 'Yes, that all seems quite clear.']
qText: I see, Yes, that all seems quite clear.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['This whole business of Brenda is _very_ unfortunate,']
qText: This whole business of Brenda is _very_ unfortunate,
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

qTextArr:
["My mother is extremely upset about it, naturally. I'm upset myself. I
don't mind admitting, perfectly frankly, that I think she has behaved
very foolishly, foolishly and wrongly. I can quite understand your being
upset about it too."]
qText:
My mother is extremely upset about it, naturally. I'm upset myself. I
don't mind admitting, perfectly frankly, that I think she has behaved
very foolishly, foolishly and wrongly. I can quite understand your being
upset about it too.
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

qText: Yes,
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['But all the same, making every allowance for your feelings, I do think\nthat you are behaving rather vindictively in the matter.']
qText:
But all the same, making every allowance for your feelings, I do think
that you are behaving rather vindictively in the matter.
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

qTextArr: ["I'm doing exactly what Brenda wanted."]
qText: I'm doing exactly what Brenda wanted.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["My dear fellow, she doesn't know what she wants. I saw this chap Beaver\nyesterday. I didn't like him _at all_. Do you?"]
qText:
My dear fellow, she doesn't know what she wants. I saw this chap Beaver
yesterday. I didn't like him _at all_. Do you?
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

qTextArr: ['I hardly know him.']
qText: I hardly know him.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr:
["Well, I can assure you I didn't like him. Now you're just throwing
Brenda into his arms. That's what it amounts to, as I see it, and I call
it vindictive. Of course, at the moment Brenda's got the idea that she's
in love with him. But it won't last. It couldn't with a chap like
Beaver. She'll want to come back in a year, just you see. Allan says the
same."]
qText:
Well, I can assure you I didn't like him. Now you're just throwing
Brenda into his arms. That's what it amounts to, as I see it, and I call
it vindictive. Of course, at the moment Brenda's got the idea that she's
in love with him. But it won't last. It couldn't with a chap like
Beaver. She'll want to come back in a year, just you see. Allan says the
same.
speaker: Reggie St Cloud
menEnts: [[['Tony Last'], ['John Beaver'], ['Tony Last'], ['John Beaver'], ['Brenda'], ['Brenda'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['Brenda'], ['Tony Last'], ['Allan']]]

qTextArr: ["I've told Allan. I don't want her back."]
qText: I've told Allan. I don't want her back.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Well, that's vindictive."]
qText: Well, that's vindictive.
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

qTextArr: ["No, I just couldn't feel the same about her again."]
qText: No, I just couldn't feel the same about her again.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr:
["Well, why feel _the same_? One has to change as one gets older. Why,
ten years ago I couldn't be interested in anything later than the
Sumerian age and I assure you that now I find even the Christian era
full of significance."]
qText:
Well, why feel _the same_? One has to change as one gets older. Why,
ten years ago I couldn't be interested in anything later than the
Sumerian age and I assure you that now I find even the Christian era
full of significance.
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

qTextArr:
['Almost every grave had them,', "mostly
referring to the circus factions, scratched on lead. They used to be
dropped in through a funnel. We had found forty-three up-to-date, before
this wretched business happened, and I had to come back. Naturally I'm
upset.", 'Besides, you know,', "it isn't as though it was all
Brenda's fault."]
qText:
Almost every grave had them, mostly
referring to the circus factions, scratched on lead. They used to be
dropped in through a funnel. We had found forty-three up-to-date, before
this wretched business happened, and I had to come back. Naturally I'm
upset. Besides, you know, it isn't as though it was all
Brenda's fault.
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

qTextArr: ["I haven't been thinking particularly whose fault it is."]
qText: I haven't been thinking particularly whose fault it is.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr:
["Well, that's all very well, but you seem rather to be taking the line
of the injured husband--saying you can't feel the same again, and all
that. I mean to say, it takes two to make a quarrel and I gather things
had been going wrong for some time. For instance, you'd been drinking a
lot--have some more burgundy, by the way."]
qText:
Well, that's all very well, but you seem rather to be taking the line
of the injured husband--saying you can't feel the same again, and all
that. I mean to say, it takes two to make a quarrel and I gather things
had been going wrong for some time. For instance, you'd been drinking a
lot--have some more burgundy, by the way.
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

qTextArr: ['Did Brenda say that?']
qText: Did Brenda say that?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr:
["Yes. And then you'd been going round a bit with other girls yourself.
There was some woman with a Moorish name you had to stay at Hetton while
Brenda was there. Well, that's a bit thick, you know. I'm all for people
going their own way, but if they do they can't blame others, if you see
what I mean."]
qText:
Yes. And then you'd been going round a bit with other girls yourself.
There was some woman with a Moorish name you had to stay at Hetton while
Brenda was there. Well, that's a bit thick, you know. I'm all for people
going their own way, but if they do they can't blame others, if you see
what I mean.
speaker: Reggie St Cloud
menEnts: [[['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Jenny Abdul Akbar'], ['Tony Last'], ['Brenda'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last']]]

qTextArr: ['Did Brenda say that?']
qText: Did Brenda say that?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Yes. Don't think I'm trying to lecture you or anything, but all I feel\nis that you haven't any right to be vindictive to Brenda, as things\nare."]
qText:
Yes. Don't think I'm trying to lecture you or anything, but all I feel
is that you haven't any right to be vindictive to Brenda, as things
are.
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

qTextArr: ['She said I drank and was having an affair with the woman with a Moorish\nname?']
qText:
She said I drank and was having an affair with the woman with a Moorish
name?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Well, I don't know she actually said that, but she said you'd been\ngetting tight lately and that you were certainly interested in that\ngirl."]
qText:
Well, I don't know she actually said that, but she said you'd been
getting tight lately and that you were certainly interested in that
girl.
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

qTextArr: ['So that really explains what I want to say,', "It's about money. I understand that when Brenda was in a very agitated\nstate just after the death of her child, she consented to some verbal\narrangement with you about settlements."]
qText:
So that really explains what I want to say, It's about money. I understand that when Brenda was in a very agitated
state just after the death of her child, she consented to some verbal
arrangement with you about settlements.
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

qTextArr: ["Yes, I'm allowing her five hundred a year."]
qText: Yes, I'm allowing her five hundred a year.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr:
["Well, you know, I don't think that you have any right to take advantage
of her generosity in that way. It was most imprudent of her to consider
your proposal--she admits now that she was not really herself when she
did so."]
qText:
Well, you know, I don't think that you have any right to take advantage
of her generosity in that way. It was most imprudent of her to consider
your proposal--she admits now that she was not really herself when she
did so.
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

qTextArr: ['What does she suggest instead?']
qText: What does she suggest instead?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Let's go outside and have coffee."]
qText: Let's go outside and have coffee.
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

qTextArr: ["Well, I've discussed it with the lawyers and with the\nfamily and we decided that the sum should be increased to two thousand."]
qText:
Well, I've discussed it with the lawyers and with the
family and we decided that the sum should be increased to two thousand.
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

qTextArr: ["That's quite out of the question. I couldn't begin to afford it."]
qText: That's quite out of the question. I couldn't begin to afford it.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr:
["Well, you know, I have to consider Brenda's interests. She has very
little of her own and there will be no more coming to her. My mother's
income is an allowance which I pay under my father's will. I shan't be
able to give her anything. I am trying to raise everything I can for an
expedition to one of the oases in the Libyan desert. This chap Beaver
has got practically nothing and doesn't look like earning any. So you
see--"]
qText:
Well, you know, I have to consider Brenda's interests. She has very
little of her own and there will be no more coming to her. My mother's
income is an allowance which I pay under my father's will. I shan't be
able to give her anything. I am trying to raise everything I can for an
expedition to one of the oases in the Libyan desert. This chap Beaver
has got practically nothing and doesn't look like earning any. So you
see--
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

qTextArr: ["But, my dear Reggie, you know as well as I do that it's out of the\nquestion."]
qText:
But, my dear Reggie, you know as well as I do that it's out of the
question.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["It's rather less than a third of your income."]
qText: It's rather less than a third of your income.
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

qTextArr:
["Yes, but almost every penny goes straight back to the estate. Do you
realize that Brenda and I together haven't spent half that amount a year
on our personal expenses? It's all I can do to keep things going as it
is."]
qText:
Yes, but almost every penny goes straight back to the estate. Do you
realize that Brenda and I together haven't spent half that amount a year
on our personal expenses? It's all I can do to keep things going as it
is.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr:
["I didn't expect you'd take this line, Tony. I think it's extremely
unreasonable of you. After all, it's absurd to pretend in these days
that a single man can't be perfectly comfortable on four thousand a
year. It's as much as I've ever had."]
qText:
I didn't expect you'd take this line, Tony. I think it's extremely
unreasonable of you. After all, it's absurd to pretend in these days
that a single man can't be perfectly comfortable on four thousand a
year. It's as much as I've ever had.
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

qTextArr: ['It would mean giving up Hetton.']
qText: It would mean giving up Hetton.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr:
['Well, I gave up Brakeleigh, and I assure you, my dear fellow, I never
regret it. It was a nasty wrench at the time, of course, old association
and everything like that, but I can tell you this, that when the sale
was finally through I felt a different man, free to go where I liked...']
qText:
Well, I gave up Brakeleigh, and I assure you, my dear fellow, I never
regret it. It was a nasty wrench at the time, of course, old association
and everything like that, but I can tell you this, that when the sale
was finally through I felt a different man, free to go where I liked...
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

qTextArr: ["But I don't happen to want to go anywhere else except Hetton."]
qText: But I don't happen to want to go anywhere else except Hetton.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["There's a lot in what these Labour fellows say, you know. Big houses\nare a thing of the past in England."]
qText:
There's a lot in what these Labour fellows say, you know. Big houses
are a thing of the past in England.
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

qTextArr: ['Tell me, did Brenda realize when she agreed to this proposal that it\nmeant my leaving Hetton?']
qText:
Tell me, did Brenda realize when she agreed to this proposal that it
meant my leaving Hetton?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr:
["Yes, it was mentioned, I think. I daresay you'll find it quite easy to
sell to a school or something like that. I remember the agent said when
I was trying to get rid of Brakeleigh that it was a pity it wasn't
Gothic, because schools and convents always go for Gothic. I daresay
you'll get a very comfortable price and find yourself better off in the
end than you are now."]
qText:
Yes, it was mentioned, I think. I daresay you'll find it quite easy to
sell to a school or something like that. I remember the agent said when
I was trying to get rid of Brakeleigh that it was a pity it wasn't
Gothic, because schools and convents always go for Gothic. I daresay
you'll get a very comfortable price and find yourself better off in the
end than you are now.
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

qTextArr: ["No. It's impossible,"]
qText: No. It's impossible,
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["You're making things extremely awkward for everyone,", "I\ncan't understand why you are taking up this attitude."]
qText:
You're making things extremely awkward for everyone, I
can't understand why you are taking up this attitude.
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

qTextArr: ["What is more, I don't believe that Brenda ever expected or wanted me to\nagree."]
qText:
What is more, I don't believe that Brenda ever expected or wanted me to
agree.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Oh yes, she did, my dear fellow. I assure you of that.']
qText: Oh yes, she did, my dear fellow. I assure you of that.
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

qTextArr: ["It's inconceivable."]
qText: It's inconceivable.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr:
['Well,', "there's more to it than just
money. Perhaps I'd better tell you everything. I hadn't meant to. The
truth is that Beaver is cutting up nasty. He says he can't marry Brenda
unless she's properly provided for. Not fair on her, he says. I quite
see his point in a way."]
qText:
Well, there's more to it than just
money. Perhaps I'd better tell you everything. I hadn't meant to. The
truth is that Beaver is cutting up nasty. He says he can't marry Brenda
unless she's properly provided for. Not fair on her, he says. I quite
see his point in a way.
speaker: Reggie St Cloud
menEnts: [[], [['Tony Last'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['Brenda'], ['Brenda'], ['Brenda'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver']]]

qTextArr: ['Yes, I see his point,', 'So what your proposal really amounts\nto, is that I should give up Hetton in order to buy Beaver for Brenda.']
qText:
Yes, I see his point, So what your proposal really amounts
to, is that I should give up Hetton in order to buy Beaver for Brenda.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["It's not how I should have put it,"]
qText: It's not how I should have put it,
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

qTextArr: ["Well, I'm not going to and that's the end of it. If that's all you\nwanted to say, I may as well leave you."]
qText:
Well, I'm not going to and that's the end of it. If that's all you
wanted to say, I may as well leave you.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr:
["No, it isn't quite all I wanted to say. In fact I think I must have put
things rather badly. It comes from trying to respect people's feelings
too much. You see, I wasn't so much asking you to agree to anything as
explaining what our side propose to do. I've tried to keep everything on
a friendly basis but I see it's not possible. Brenda will ask for
alimony of two thousand a year from the Court and on our evidence we
shall get it. I'm sorry you oblige me to put it so bluntly."]
qText:
No, it isn't quite all I wanted to say. In fact I think I must have put
things rather badly. It comes from trying to respect people's feelings
too much. You see, I wasn't so much asking you to agree to anything as
explaining what our side propose to do. I've tried to keep everything on
a friendly basis but I see it's not possible. Brenda will ask for
alimony of two thousand a year from the Court and on our evidence we
shall get it. I'm sorry you oblige me to put it so bluntly.
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

qTextArr: ["I hadn't thought of that."]
qText: I hadn't thought of that.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["No, nor had we, to be quite frank. It was Beaver's idea."]
qText: No, nor had we, to be quite frank. It was Beaver's idea.
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

qTextArr: ['You seem to have got me in a fairly hopeless position.']
qText: You seem to have got me in a fairly hopeless position.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["It's not how I should have put it."]
qText: It's not how I should have put it.
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

qTextArr: ["I should like to make absolutely sure that Brenda is in on this. D'you\nmind if I ring her up?"]
qText:
I should like to make absolutely sure that Brenda is in on this. D'you
mind if I ring her up?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Not at all, my dear fellow. I happen to know she's at Marjorie's\nto-night."]
qText:
Not at all, my dear fellow. I happen to know she's at Marjorie's
to-night.
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

qTextArr: ["Brenda, this is Tony... I've just been dining with Reggie."]
qText: Brenda, this is Tony... I've just been dining with Reggie.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Yes, he said something about it.']
qText: Yes, he said something about it.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['He tells me that you are going to sue for alimony. Is that so?']
qText: He tells me that you are going to sue for alimony. Is that so?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Tony, don't be so bullying. The lawyers are doing everything. It's no\nuse coming to me."]
qText:
Tony, don't be so bullying. The lawyers are doing everything. It's no
use coming to me.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['But did you know that they proposed to ask for two thousand?']
qText: But did you know that they proposed to ask for two thousand?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Yes. They did say that. I know it sounds a lot but...']
qText: Yes. They did say that. I know it sounds a lot but...
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["And you know exactly how my money stands, don't you? You know it means\nselling Hetton, don't you?... hullo, are you still there?"]
qText:
And you know exactly how my money stands, don't you? You know it means
selling Hetton, don't you?... hullo, are you still there?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Yes, I'm here."]
qText: Yes, I'm here.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['You know it means that?']
qText: You know it means that?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Tony, don't make me feel a beast. Everything has been so difficult."]
qText: Tony, don't make me feel a beast. Everything has been so difficult.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['You do know just what you are asking?']
qText: You do know just what you are asking?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Yes... I suppose so.']
qText: Yes... I suppose so.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["All right, that's all I wanted to know."]
qText: All right, that's all I wanted to know.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Tony, how odd you sound... don't ring off."]
qText: Tony, how odd you sound... don't ring off.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Well?']
qText: Well?
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

qTextArr: ["I got on to her. You were quite right. I'm sorry I didn't believe you.\nIt seemed so unlikely at first."]
qText:
I got on to her. You were quite right. I'm sorry I didn't believe you.
It seemed so unlikely at first.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["That's all right, my dear fellow."]
qText: That's all right, my dear fellow.
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

qTextArr: ["I've decided exactly what's going to happen."]
qText: I've decided exactly what's going to happen.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Good.']
qText: Good.
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

qTextArr:
["Brenda is not going to get her divorce. The evidence I provided at
Brighton isn't worth anything. There happens to have been a child there
all the time. She slept both nights in the room I am supposed to have
occupied. If you care to bring the case I shall defend it and win, but I
think when you have seen my evidence you will drop it. I am going away
for six months or so. When I come back, if she wishes it, I shall
divorce Brenda without settlements of any kind. Is that clear?"]
qText:
Brenda is not going to get her divorce. The evidence I provided at
Brighton isn't worth anything. There happens to have been a child there
all the time. She slept both nights in the room I am supposed to have
occupied. If you care to bring the case I shall defend it and win, but I
think when you have seen my evidence you will drop it. I am going away
for six months or so. When I come back, if she wishes it, I shall
divorce Brenda without settlements of any kind. Is that clear?
speaker: Tony Last
menEnts: [[['Brenda'], ['Brenda'], ['Winnie'], ['Reggie St Cloud'], ['Reggie St Cloud'], ['Reggie St Cloud'], ['Brenda'], ['Brenda']]]

qTextArr: ['But look here, my dear fellow.']
qText: But look here, my dear fellow.
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

qTextArr: ['Good night. Thank you for the dinner. Good luck to the excavations.']
qText: Good night. Thank you for the dinner. Good luck to the excavations.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Who on earth would have expected the old boy to turn up like that?']
qText: Who on earth would have expected the old boy to turn up like that?
speaker: Polly Cockpurse

qTextArr: ['Now I understand why they keep going on in the papers about divorce law\nreform,', "It's _too_ monstrous that he should be allowed\nto get away with it."]
qText:
Now I understand why they keep going on in the papers about divorce law
reform, It's _too_ monstrous that he should be allowed
to get away with it.
speaker: Veronica

qTextArr: ['The mistake they made was in telling him first,']
qText: The mistake they made was in telling him first,
speaker: Souki

qTextArr: ["It's so like Brenda to trust everyone,"]
qText: It's so like Brenda to trust everyone,
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

qTextArr: ['I do think Tony comes out of this pretty poorly,']
qText: I do think Tony comes out of this pretty poorly,
speaker: Marjorie

qTextArr: ["Oh, I don't know,", 'I expect your ass of a brother put the\nthing wrong.']
qText:
Oh, I don't know, I expect your ass of a brother put the
thing wrong.
speaker: Allan

qTextArr: ['any idea how many times round the deck make a mile?']
qText: any idea how many times round the deck make a mile?
speaker: The Genial Passenger

qTextArr: ["None, I'm afraid,", 'But I should think you must have walked\na great distance.']
qText:
None, I'm afraid, But I should think you must have walked
a great distance.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Twenty-two times. One soon gets out of sorts at sea if you're used to\nan active life. She's not much of a boat. Travel with this line often?"]
qText:
Twenty-two times. One soon gets out of sorts at sea if you're used to
an active life. She's not much of a boat. Travel with this line often?
speaker: The Genial Passenger

qTextArr: ['Never before.']
qText: Never before.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Ah. Thought you might have been in business in the islands. Not many\ntourists going out this time of year. Just the other way about. All\ncoming home, if you see what I mean. Going far?']
qText:
Ah. Thought you might have been in business in the islands. Not many
tourists going out this time of year. Just the other way about. All
coming home, if you see what I mean. Going far?
speaker: The Genial Passenger

qTextArr: ['Demerara.']
qText: Demerara.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Ah. Looking for minerals perhaps?']
qText: Ah. Looking for minerals perhaps?
speaker: The Genial Passenger

qTextArr: ['No, to tell you the truth I am looking for a city.']
qText: No, to tell you the truth I am looking for a city.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Sounded just like\nyou said you were looking for a city.']
qText:
Sounded just like
you said you were looking for a city.
speaker: The Genial Passenger

qText: Yes.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['That _was_ what you said?']
qText: That _was_ what you said?
speaker: The Genial Passenger

qText: Yes.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['I thought it sounded like that... well, so long. I must do another few\nrounds before dinner.']
qText:
I thought it sounded like that... well, so long. I must do another few

speaker: The Genial Passenger

qTextArr: ['Hullo', 'Bit choppy', 'Here we are again']
qText: Hullo Bit choppy Here we are again
speaker: The Genial Passenger
refExp: the man had taken to nodding then to saying

qTextArr: ["I'm afraid our table is not showing\nup very well to-night,", 'I see you are not a sufferer. My wife\nis in her cabin. _She_ is a sufferer.']
qText:
I'm afraid our table is not showing
up very well to-night, I see you are not a sufferer. My wife
is in her cabin. _She_ is a sufferer.
speaker: The Coloured Archdeacon

qTextArr:
["It's not much of a boat,", 'But I expect things will look brighter when we get into
the sun.', "That's all right,", "we're just
going down to the bar. You know,", "I feel I
owe you an apology. I thought you were potty just now before dinner.
Honestly I did, when you said you were going to Demerara to look for a
city. Well, it sounded pretty potty. Then the purser--I'm at his table.
Always get the cheeriest crowd at the purser's table _and_ the best
attention--the purser told me about you. You're the explorer, aren't
you?"]
qText:
It's not much of a boat, But I expect things will look brighter when we get into
the sun. That's all right, we're just
going down to the bar. You know, I feel I
owe you an apology. I thought you were potty just now before dinner.
Honestly I did, when you said you were going to Demerara to look for a
city. Well, it sounded pretty potty. Then the purser--I'm at his table.
Always get the cheeriest crowd at the purser's table _and_ the best
attention--the purser told me about you. You're the explorer, aren't
you?
speaker: The Genial Passenger
menEnts: [[], [['The Genial Passenger', 'Tony Last']], [], [['The Genial Passenger', 'Tony Last'], ['Tony Last']], [['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last']]]

qTextArr: ['Yes, come to think of it, I suppose I am,']
qText: Yes, come to think of it, I suppose I am,
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['trade goods']
qText: trade goods
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr:
['I am going away shortly,', 'to Brazil. At least it
may be Brazil or Dutch Guiana. One cannot tell. The frontier has never
been demarcated. I ought to have started last week, only my plans were
upset. Do you by any chance know a Nicaraguan calling himself
alternately Ponsonby and FitzClarence?']
qText:
I am going away shortly, to Brazil. At least it
may be Brazil or Dutch Guiana. One cannot tell. The frontier has never
been demarcated. I ought to have started last week, only my plans were
upset. Do you by any chance know a Nicaraguan calling himself
alternately Ponsonby and FitzClarence?
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ["No, I don't think I do."]
qText: No, I don't think I do.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['You are fortunate. That man has just robbed me of two hundred pounds\nand some machine guns.']
qText:
You are fortunate. That man has just robbed me of two hundred pounds
and some machine guns.
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['Machine guns?']
qText: Machine guns?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Yes, I travel with one or two, mostly for show, you know, or for trade,\nand they are not easy to buy nowadays. Have you ever tried?']
qText:
Yes, I travel with one or two, mostly for show, you know, or for trade,
and they are not easy to buy nowadays. Have you ever tried?
speaker: Dr Messinger

qText: No.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Well you can take it from me that it's not easy. You can't just walk\ninto a shop and order machine guns."]
qText:
Well you can take it from me that it's not easy. You can't just walk
into a shop and order machine guns.
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['No, I suppose not.']
qText: No, I suppose not.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Still, at a pinch I can do without them. But I can't do without two\nhundred pounds."]
qText:
Still, at a pinch I can do without them. But I can't do without two
hundred pounds.
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['Ah yes,', 'interesting little place. I expect you know Zingermaun there?']
qText: Ah yes, interesting little place. I expect you know Zingermaun there?
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ["No, I've not been there yet."]
qText: No, I've not been there yet.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr:
["You'd like him--a very straight fellow. He used to do quite a lot,
selling ammunition to the Atlas caids before the pacification. Of course
it was easy money with the capitulations, but he did it better than most
of them. I believe he's running a restaurant now in Mogador.", "The pity is I can't let the R.G.S. in on this
expedition. I've got to find the money privately."]
qText:
You'd like him--a very straight fellow. He used to do quite a lot,
selling ammunition to the Atlas caids before the pacification. Of course
it was easy money with the capitulations, but he did it better than most
of them. I believe he's running a restaurant now in Mogador. The pity is I can't let the R.G.S. in on this
expedition. I've got to find the money privately.
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ["We'd better go up and lunch,"]
qText: We'd better go up and lunch,
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['I have to be very\ncareful what I eat,']
qText:
I have to be very
careful what I eat,
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr:
["...You see, there has been a continuous tradition about the City since
the first explorers of the sixteenth century. It has been variously
allocated, sometimes down in Matto Grosso, sometimes on the upper
Orinoco in what is now Venezuela. I myself used to think it lay
somewhere on the Uraricuera. I was out there last year and it was then
that I established contact with the Pie-wie Indians; no white man had
ever visited them and got out alive. And it was from the Pie-wies that I
learned where to look. None of them had ever visited the City, of
course, but they _knew about it_. Every Indian between Ciudad Bolivar
and Para knows about it. But they won't talk. Queer people. But I became
blood-brother with a Pie-wie--interesting ceremony. They buried me up to
the neck in mud and all the women of the tribe spat on my head. Then we
ate a toad and snake and a beetle and after that I was
blood-brother--well, he told me that the City lies between the head
waters of the Courantyne and the Takutu. There's a vast track of
unexplored country there. I've often thought of visiting it."]
qText:
...You see, there has been a continuous tradition about the City since
the first explorers of the sixteenth century. It has been variously
allocated, sometimes down in Matto Grosso, sometimes on the upper
Orinoco in what is now Venezuela. I myself used to think it lay
somewhere on the Uraricuera. I was out there last year and it was then
that I established contact with the Pie-wie Indians; no white man had
ever visited them and got out alive. And it was from the Pie-wies that I
learned where to look. None of them had ever visited the City, of
course, but they _knew about it_. Every Indian between Ciudad Bolivar
and Para knows about it. But they won't talk. Queer people. But I became
blood-brother with a Pie-wie--interesting ceremony. They buried me up to
the neck in mud and all the women of the tribe spat on my head. Then we
ate a toad and snake and a beetle and after that I was
blood-brother--well, he told me that the City lies between the head
waters of the Courantyne and the Takutu. There's a vast track of
unexplored country there. I've often thought of visiting it.
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr:
["I've been looking up the historical side too, and I more or less know
how the City got there. It was the result of a migration from Peru at
the beginning of the fifteenth century, when the Incas were at the
height of their power. It is mentioned in all the early Spanish
documents as a popular legend. One of the younger princes rebelled and
led his people off into the forest. Most of the tribes had a tradition
in one form or another of a strange race passing through their
territory."]
qText:
I've been looking up the historical side too, and I more or less know
how the City got there. It was the result of a migration from Peru at
the beginning of the fifteenth century, when the Incas were at the
height of their power. It is mentioned in all the early Spanish
documents as a popular legend. One of the younger princes rebelled and
led his people off into the forest. Most of the tribes had a tradition
in one form or another of a strange race passing through their
territory.
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['But what do you suppose this city will be like?']
qText: But what do you suppose this city will be like?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr:
["Impossible to say. Every tribe has a different word for it. The
Pie-wies call it the 'Shining' or 'Glittering', the Arekuna the 'Many
Watered', the Patamonas the 'Bright Feathered', the Warau, oddly enough,
use the same word for it that they use for a kind of aromatic jam they
make. Of course, one can't tell how a civilization may have developed or
degenerated in five hundred years of isolation..."]
qText:
Impossible to say. Every tribe has a different word for it. The
Pie-wies call it the 'Shining' or 'Glittering', the Arekuna the 'Many
Watered', the Patamonas the 'Bright Feathered', the Warau, oddly enough,
use the same word for it that they use for a kind of aromatic jam they
make. Of course, one can't tell how a civilization may have developed or
degenerated in five hundred years of isolation...
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['Done much of that kind of thing?']
qText: Done much of that kind of thing?
speaker: The Genial Passenger

qTextArr: ['No, to tell you the truth it is the first time.']
qText: No, to tell you the truth it is the first time.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Ah. Well, I daresay it's more interesting than it sounds,", "else people wouldn't do it so much."]
qText: Ah. Well, I daresay it's more interesting than it sounds, else people wouldn't do it so much.
speaker: The Genial Passenger

qTextArr: ['I wonder if anyone is doing anything about those dogs,', "I'll ask the purser to-morrow. We\nmight exercise them a bit. Kind of mournful the way they go on."]
qText:
I wonder if anyone is doing anything about those dogs, I'll ask the purser to-morrow. We
might exercise them a bit. Kind of mournful the way they go on.
speaker: The Genial Passenger

qTextArr: ['Been talking to the wireless operator,', 'We ought to pass\nquite near the Yarmouth Castle at about eleven.']
qText:
Been talking to the wireless operator, We ought to pass
quite near the Yarmouth Castle at about eleven.
speaker: The Genial Passenger

qTextArr: ["Look, Ernie, come quick,\nthere's a shark."]
qText:
Look, Ernie, come quick,
there's a shark.
speaker: Unknowable

qTextArr: ["That's not a shark, it's a dolphin."]
qText: That's not a shark, it's a dolphin.
speaker: Unknowable

qTextArr: ['Mr Brink said\nit was a porpoise.']
qText:
Mr Brink said
it was a porpoise.
speaker: Unknowable

qTextArr: ['There he is again. Oh, if I had my camera.']
qText: There he is again. Oh, if I had my camera.
speaker: Unknowable

qTextArr: ['The last days\nhave been terrible. I saw you walking about. How I envied you.']
qText:
The last days
have been terrible. I saw you walking about. How I envied you.
speaker: Therese De Vitre

qTextArr: ['It ought to be calm all the way now,']
qText: It ought to be calm all the way now,
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Are you going\nfar?']
qText:
Are you going
far?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Trinidad. That is my home... I tried to decide who you were from the\npassenger list.']
qText:
Trinidad. That is my home... I tried to decide who you were from the
passenger list.
speaker: Therese De Vitre

qTextArr: ['Who was I?']
qText: Who was I?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Well... someone called Colonel Strapper.']
qText: Well... someone called Colonel Strapper.
speaker: Therese De Vitre

qTextArr: ['Do I look so old?']
qText: Do I look so old?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Are colonels old? I didn't know. It's not a thing we have much in\nTrinidad. Now I know who you are because I asked the head steward. Do\ntell me about your exploring."]
qText:
Are colonels old? I didn't know. It's not a thing we have much in
Trinidad. Now I know who you are because I asked the head steward. Do
tell me about your exploring.
speaker: Therese De Vitre

qTextArr: ["You'd better ask Doctor Messinger. He knows more about it than I do."]
qText: You'd better ask Doctor Messinger. He knows more about it than I do.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['No, _you_ tell me.']
qText: No, _you_ tell me.
speaker: Therese De Vitre

qTextArr:
['...Some of us used to keep lipstick and rouge secretly in our bedrooms
and try it on at night. One girl called Antoinette came to Mass on
Sunday wearing it. There was a terrible row with Madame de Supplice and
she left after that term. It was awfully brave. We all envied her...
But she was an ugly girl, always eating chocolates...']
qText:
...Some of us used to keep lipstick and rouge secretly in our bedrooms
and try it on at night. One girl called Antoinette came to Mass on
Sunday wearing it. There was a terrible row with Madame de Supplice and
she left after that term. It was awfully brave. We all envied her...
But she was an ugly girl, always eating chocolates...
speaker: Therese De Vitre

qTextArr:
['...Now I am coming home to be married... No, I am not yet engaged,
but you see there are so few young men I can marry. They must be
Catholic and of an island family. It would not do to marry an official
and go back to live in England. But it will be easy because I have no
brothers or sisters and my father has one of the best houses in
Trinidad. You must come and see it. It is a stone house, outside the
town. My family came to Trinidad in the French Revolution. There are two
or three other rich families and I shall marry into one of them. Our son
will have the house. It will be easy...']
qText:
...Now I am coming home to be married... No, I am not yet engaged,
but you see there are so few young men I can marry. They must be
Catholic and of an island family. It would not do to marry an official
and go back to live in England. But it will be easy because I have no
brothers or sisters and my father has one of the best houses in
Trinidad. You must come and see it. It is a stone house, outside the
town. My family came to Trinidad in the French Revolution. There are two
or three other rich families and I shall marry into one of them. Our son
will have the house. It will be easy...
speaker: Therese De Vitre

qTextArr:
["...There was an American girl at
Madame de Supplice's who was engaged. She had a ring with a big diamond
but she could never wear it except in bed. Then one day she had a letter
from her young man saying he was going to marry another girl. How she
cried. We all read the letter and most of us cried too... But in
Trinidad it will be quite easy."]
qText:
...There was an American girl at
Madame de Supplice's who was engaged. She had a ring with a big diamond
but she could never wear it except in bed. Then one day she had a letter
from her young man saying he was going to marry another girl. How she
cried. We all read the letter and most of us cried too... But in
Trinidad it will be quite easy.
speaker: Therese De Vitre

qTextArr: ['But of course,', 'there may be nothing in it. It\nought to be an interesting journey in any case.']
qText:
But of course, there may be nothing in it. It
ought to be an interesting journey in any case.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['How I wish I was a man,']
qText: How I wish I was a man,
speaker: Therese De Vitre

qTextArr: ["We'll go in a small boat,", 'so as to escape all that hideous nonsense of\ndeck games.']
qText:
We'll go in a small boat, so as to escape all that hideous nonsense of
deck games.
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['How funny,', "that was the\nname of the man who didn't marry the American girl at Madame de\nSupplice's"]
qText:
How funny, that was the
name of the man who didn't marry the American girl at Madame de
Supplice's
speaker: Therese De Vitre

qTextArr: ["I can't believe this is the same ship as in those cold, rough days,", 'You must come to my home and see what real creole cooking is like,', 'We have a lot of old recipes that the planters used to\nuse. You must meet my father and mother.']
qText:
I can't believe this is the same ship as in those cold, rough days, You must come to my home and see what real creole cooking is like, We have a lot of old recipes that the planters used to
use. You must meet my father and mother.
speaker: Therese De Vitre
menEnts: [[], [['Tony Last']], [['Therese De Vitre'], ['Tony Last'], ["Thrse De Vitr'S Father"]]]

qTextArr: ['Trinidad the day after to-morrow,']
qText: Trinidad the day after to-morrow,
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["I don't like Doctor Messinger at all,", 'Not anything about\nhim.']
qText:
I don't like Doctor Messinger at all, Not anything about
him.
speaker: Therese De Vitre

qTextArr: ['And you will have to choose your husband.']
qText: And you will have to choose your husband.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr:
["Yes. There are seven of them. There was one called Honor? I liked, but
of course I haven't seen him for two years. He was studying to be an
engineer. There's one called Mendoza who's very rich but he isn't really
a Trinidadian. His grandfather came from Dominica and they say he has
coloured blood. I expect it will be Honor?. Mother always brought in his
name when she wrote to me and he sent me things at Christmas and on my
f?te. Rather silly things, because the shops aren't good in Port of
Spain."]
qText:
Yes. There are seven of them. There was one called Honor? I liked, but
of course I haven't seen him for two years. He was studying to be an
engineer. There's one called Mendoza who's very rich but he isn't really
a Trinidadian. His grandfather came from Dominica and they say he has
coloured blood. I expect it will be Honor?. Mother always brought in his
name when she wrote to me and he sent me things at Christmas and on my
f?te. Rather silly things, because the shops aren't good in Port of
Spain.
speaker: Therese De Vitre

qTextArr: ["You'll be coming back by Trinidad, won't you? So I\nshall see you then. Will you be a long time in the bush?"]
qText:
You'll be coming back by Trinidad, won't you? So I
shall see you then. Will you be a long time in the bush?

qTextArr: ["I expect you'll be married by then."]
qText: I expect you'll be married by then.

qText: Tony, why haven't you ever got married?

qText: Yes.

qText: You're teasing me.

qText: No, honestly I am. At least I was.

qText: Oh.

qText: Are you surprised?

qText: I don't know. Somehow I didn't think you were. Where is she?

qText: In England. We had a row.

qText: Oh... What's the time?

qText: Quite early.

qText: Let's go back.

qText: Yes, please. It's been a delightful day.

qText: You said that as if you were saying good-bye.

qTextArr:
['Reserved lot, these
real old creoles,', "Poor as church mice most
of them, but stinking proud. Time and again I've palled up with them on
board and when we got to port it's been good-bye. Do they ever so much
as ask you to their houses? Not they."]
qText:
Reserved lot, these
real old creoles, Poor as church mice most
of them, but stinking proud. Time and again I've palled up with them on
board and when we got to port it's been good-bye. Do they ever so much
as ask you to their houses? Not they.
speaker: The Genial Passenger
refExp: remarked the passenger who had first made friends with Tony

qTextArr: ["Oh, for God's sake."]
qText: Oh, for God's sake.

qTextArr: ["Oh, for God's\nsake,"]
qText:
Oh, for God's
sake,
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ["A vampire bat got it. I must have gone to sleep with my foot against\nthe netting. God knows how long he had been at it, before I woke up.\nThat lamp ought to keep them off but it doesn't seem to."]
qText:
A vampire bat got it. I must have gone to sleep with my foot against
the netting. God knows how long he had been at it, before I woke up.
That lamp ought to keep them off but it doesn't seem to.
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['Vampires\nplenty bad this side, Chief,', 'Dat for why us no leave de\nfire.']
qText:
Vampires
plenty bad this side, Chief, Dat for why us no leave de
fire.
speaker: Unknowable

qTextArr: ["It's just the way to get sick, blast it,", 'I may\nhave lost pints of blood.']
qText:
It's just the way to get sick, blast it, I may
have lost pints of blood.
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr:
['How I hate staying up late,', "but it seems a shame to take
my Mr Beaver away. He's so thrilled to be here, bless him, and it was a
great effort to get him asked... Come to think of it,", 'I suppose that this is the last year _I_ shall be able to go to this
kind of party.']
qText:
How I hate staying up late, but it seems a shame to take
my Mr Beaver away. He's so thrilled to be here, bless him, and it was a
great effort to get him asked... Come to think of it, I suppose that this is the last year _I_ shall be able to go to this
kind of party.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["You're going through with the divorce?"]
qText: You're going through with the divorce?
speaker: Jock

qTextArr:
["I don't know, Jock. It doesn't really depend on me. It's all a matter
of holding down Mr Beaver. He's getting very restive. I have to feed him
a bit of high-life every week or so, and I suppose that'll all stop if
there's a divorce. Any news of Tony?"]
qText:
I don't know, Jock. It doesn't really depend on me. It's all a matter
of holding down Mr Beaver. He's getting very restive. I have to feed him
a bit of high-life every week or so, and I suppose that'll all stop if
there's a divorce. Any news of Tony?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["Not for some time now. I got a cable when he landed. He's gone off on\nsome expedition with a crook doctor."]
qText:
Not for some time now. I got a cable when he landed. He's gone off on
some expedition with a crook doctor.
speaker: Jock

qTextArr: ['Is it _absolutely_ safe?']
qText: Is it _absolutely_ safe?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["Oh, I imagine so. The whole world is civilized now, isn't\nit--charabancs and Cook's offices everywhere."]
qText:
Oh, I imagine so. The whole world is civilized now, isn't
it--charabancs and Cook's offices everywhere.
speaker: Jock

qTextArr: ["Yes, I suppose it is... I hope he's not _brooding_. I shouldn't like\nto think of him being unhappy."]
qText:
Yes, I suppose it is... I hope he's not _brooding_. I shouldn't like
to think of him being unhappy.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["I expect he's getting used to things."]
qText: I expect he's getting used to things.
speaker: Jock

qTextArr: ["I do hope so. I'm very fond of Tony, you know, in spite of the\nmonstrous way he behaved."]
qText:
I do hope so. I'm very fond of Tony, you know, in spite of the
monstrous way he behaved.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Dey people all afeared,']
qText: Dey people all afeared,

qText: She Macushi woman. All these people Macushi people.
speaker: Rosa

qTextArr: ["Oh. I didn't know. Where are the men?"]
qText: Oh. I didn't know. Where are the men?
speaker: Dr Messinger

qText: Men all go hunting three days.
speaker: Rosa

qTextArr: ['When will they be back?']
qText: When will they be back?
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['They go after bush-pig.']
qText: They go after bush-pig.

qTextArr: ['When will they be back?']
qText: When will they be back?
speaker: Dr Messinger

No, bush-pig. Plenty bush-pig. Men all go hunting. You give me
