qTextArr: ['Listen, Rosa, I want to go to the Pie-wie country.']
qText: Listen, Rosa, I want to go to the Pie-wie country.
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['No, this Macushi. All the people Macushi.']
qText: No, this Macushi. All the people Macushi.
speaker: Rosa

qTextArr: ['But we want to go Pie-wie.']
qText: But we want to go Pie-wie.
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['No, _all_ Macushi. You give me cigarette.']
qText: No, _all_ Macushi. You give me cigarette.
speaker: Rosa

qTextArr: ["It's hopeless,"]
qText: It's hopeless,
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['We shall have to wait till the men\ncome back.']
qText:
We shall have to wait till the men
come back.
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['Look,', 'cigarettes.']
qText: Look, cigarettes.
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['Give me.']
qText: Give me.
speaker: Rosa

qTextArr: ['When men come back from hunting you come to river and tell me.\nUnderstand?']
qText:
When men come back from hunting you come to river and tell me.
Understand?
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['No, men hunting bush-pig. You give me cigarettes.']
qText: No, men hunting bush-pig. You give me cigarettes.
speaker: Rosa

qTextArr: ['What else you got?', 'Give me,']
qText: What else you got? Give me,
speaker: Rosa

qTextArr: ['When men come back, I give you plenty things if men come with me to\nPie-wies.']
qText:
When men come back, I give you plenty things if men come with me to
Pie-wies.
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['No, _all_ Macushi here.']
qText: No, _all_ Macushi here.
speaker: Rosa

qTextArr: ["We aren't doing any good,", "We'd better go back to\ncamp and wait. The men have been away three days. It's not likely they\nwill be much longer... I wish I could speak Macushi."]
qText:
We aren't doing any good, We'd better go back to
camp and wait. The men have been away three days. It's not likely they
will be much longer... I wish I could speak Macushi.
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['Number twenty,']
qText: Number twenty,
speaker: Jock

qTextArr:
['The matter is
receiving the closest attention. As the honourable member is no doubt
aware, the question of the importation of pork pies is a matter for the
Board of Trade, not for the Board of Agriculture. With regard to the
specifications of the basic pig, I must remind the honourable member
that, as he is doubtless aware, the eight-and-a-half-score pig is
modelled on the requirements of the bacon curers and has no direct
relation to pig meat for sale in pies. That is being dealt with by a
separate committee who have not yet made their report.']
qText:
The matter is
receiving the closest attention. As the honourable member is no doubt
aware, the question of the importation of pork pies is a matter for the
Board of Trade, not for the Board of Agriculture. With regard to the
specifications of the basic pig, I must remind the honourable member
that, as he is doubtless aware, the eight-and-a-half-score pig is
modelled on the requirements of the bacon curers and has no direct
relation to pig meat for sale in pies. That is being dealt with by a
separate committee who have not yet made their report.
speaker: The Under-Secretary

qTextArr: ['Would the honourable member consider an increase of the specified\nmaximum of fatness on the shoulders?']
qText:
Would the honourable member consider an increase of the specified
maximum of fatness on the shoulders?
speaker: Jock

qTextArr: ['I must have notice of that question.']
qText: I must have notice of that question.
speaker: The Under-Secretary

qTextArr: ['It will take them a week to get sober,']
qText: It will take them a week to get sober,
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['Give me cigarettes,']
qText: Give me cigarettes,
speaker: Rosa

qTextArr: ['You tell them I want men to go Pie-wie country,']
qText: You tell them I want men to go Pie-wie country,
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['Pie-wie bad people. Macushi people no go with Pie-wie people.']
qText: Pie-wie bad people. Macushi people no go with Pie-wie people.
speaker: Rosa

qTextArr: ['You say I want ten men. I give them guns.']
qText: You say I want ten men. I give them guns.
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['You give me cigarettes...']
qText: You give me cigarettes...
speaker: Rosa

qTextArr: ["There's no one to touch it. We can send back for it in case of\nemergency from the Pie-wie country,", 'From now onwards the map is valueless to us,']
qText:
There's no one to touch it. We can send back for it in case of
emergency from the Pie-wie country, From now onwards the map is valueless to us,
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['Mummy, Brenda wants a job.']
qText: Mummy, Brenda wants a job.
speaker: John Beaver

qText: Why?
speaker: Mrs Beaver

qTextArr: ['Just like everybody else, short of money and nothing to do. She\nwondered if she could be any use to you at the shop.']
qText:
Just like everybody else, short of money and nothing to do. She
wondered if she could be any use to you at the shop.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["Well... It's hard to say. At any other time she is exactly the kind of\nsaleswoman I am always looking for... but I don't know. _As things\nare_, I'm not sure it would be wise."]
qText:
Well... It's hard to say. At any other time she is exactly the kind of
saleswoman I am always looking for... but I don't know. _As things
are_, I'm not sure it would be wise.
speaker: Mrs Beaver

qTextArr: ["I said I'd ask you, that's all."]
qText: I said I'd ask you, that's all.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["John, you never tell me _anything_ and I don't like to seem\ninterfering; but what _is_ going to happen between you and Brenda?"]
qText:
John, you never tell me _anything_ and I don't like to seem
interfering; but what _is_ going to happen between you and Brenda?
speaker: Mrs Beaver

qTextArr: ["I don't know."]
qText: I don't know.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['You never tell me _anything_,', 'And there are so\nmany rumours going round. Is there going to be a divorce?']
qText:
You never tell me _anything_, And there are so
many rumours going round. Is there going to be a divorce?
speaker: Mrs Beaver

qTextArr: ["I don't know."]
qText: I don't know.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['Well, I must get back to work. Where are you\nlunching?']
qText:
Well, I must get back to work. Where are you
lunching?
speaker: Mrs Beaver

qTextArr: ["Bratt's."]
qText: Bratt's.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["Poor John. By the way, I thought you were joining Brown's."]
qText: Poor John. By the way, I thought you were joining Brown's.
speaker: Mrs Beaver

qTextArr: ["I haven't heard anything from them. I don't know whether they've had an\nelection yet."]
qText:
I haven't heard anything from them. I don't know whether they've had an
election yet.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['Your father was a member.']
qText: Your father was a member.
speaker: Mrs Beaver

qTextArr: ["I've an idea I shan't get in... anyway I couldn't really afford it."]
qText: I've an idea I shan't get in... anyway I couldn't really afford it.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["I'm not happy about you, John. I'm not sure that things are working out\nas well as I hoped about Christmas-time."]
qText:
I'm not happy about you, John. I'm not sure that things are working out
as well as I hoped about Christmas-time.
speaker: Mrs Beaver

qTextArr: ["There's my telephone. Perhaps it's Margot. She hasn't asked me to\nanything for weeks."]
qText:
There's my telephone. Perhaps it's Margot. She hasn't asked me to
anything for weeks.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["I'm afraid mother's got nothing for you at the shop,"]
qText: I'm afraid mother's got nothing for you at the shop,
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['Oh well. I expect something will turn up. I could do with a little good\nluck just at the moment.']
qText:
Oh well. I expect something will turn up. I could do with a little good
luck just at the moment.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["So could I. Have you asked Allan about Brown's?"]
qText: So could I. Have you asked Allan about Brown's?
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['Yes, I did. He says they elected about ten chaps last week.']
qText: Yes, I did. He says they elected about ten chaps last week.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["Oh, does that mean I've been blackballed?"]
qText: Oh, does that mean I've been blackballed?
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["I shouldn't know. Gentlemen are so odd about their clubs."]
qText: I shouldn't know. Gentlemen are so odd about their clubs.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['I thought that you were going to make Allan and Reggie support me.']
qText: I thought that you were going to make Allan and Reggie support me.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["I asked them. What does it matter anyway? D'you want to come to\nVeronica's for the week-end?"]
qText:
I asked them. What does it matter anyway? D'you want to come to
Veronica's for the week-end?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["I'm not sure that I do."]
qText: I'm not sure that I do.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["_I'd_ like it."]
qText: _I'd_ like it.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["It's a beastly little house--and I don't think Veronica likes me.\nWho'll be there?"]
qText:
It's a beastly little house--and I don't think Veronica likes me.
Who'll be there?
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['I shall be.']
qText: I shall be.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["Yes... well, I'll let you know."]
qText: Yes... well, I'll let you know.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['Am I seeing you this evening?']
qText: Am I seeing you this evening?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["I'll let you know."]
qText: I'll let you know.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['Oh dear,', "Now he's taken against me. It\nisn't my fault he can't get into Brown's. As a matter of fact I believe\nReggie _did_ try to help."]
qText:
Oh dear, Now he's taken against me. It
isn't my fault he can't get into Brown's. As a matter of fact I believe
Reggie _did_ try to help.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["Let's go and have a cosy lunch at the Ritz,"]
qText: Let's go and have a cosy lunch at the Ritz,
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

qTextArr: ["The Ritz isn't cosy at lunch-time and it costs eight and six. I daren't\ncash a cheque for three weeks, Jenny. The lawyers are so disagreeable.\nI've never been like this before."]
qText:
The Ritz isn't cosy at lunch-time and it costs eight and six. I daren't
cash a cheque for three weeks, Jenny. The lawyers are so disagreeable.
I've never been like this before.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["What wouldn't I do to Tony? Leaving you stranded like this."]
qText: What wouldn't I do to Tony? Leaving you stranded like this.
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

qTextArr: ["Oh, what's the good of knocking Tony? I don't suppose he's having a\npacket of fun himself in Brazil or wherever it is."]
qText:
Oh, what's the good of knocking Tony? I don't suppose he's having a
packet of fun himself in Brazil or wherever it is.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["I hear they are putting in bathrooms at Hetton--while you are\npractically starving. And he hasn't even gone to Mrs Beaver for them."]
qText:
I hear they are putting in bathrooms at Hetton--while you are
practically starving. And he hasn't even gone to Mrs Beaver for them.
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

qTextArr: ['Yes, I _do_ think that was mean.']
qText: Yes, I _do_ think that was mean.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['I got Polly and Souki,', "We're going to Daisy's joint. I _wish_ you were coming."]
qText: I got Polly and Souki, We're going to Daisy's joint. I _wish_ you were coming.
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

qTextArr: ["Me? Oh, I'm all right,"]
qText: Me? Oh, I'm all right,
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['We are now in the Amazon system of rivers,', 'You see, the water is running south.']
qText: We are now in the Amazon system of rivers, You see, the water is running south.
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['Very curious,', 'A discovery of genuine scientific\nvalue.']
qText:
Very curious, A discovery of genuine scientific
value.
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['Is there a name for any of these streams?']
qText: Is there a name for any of these streams?
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['Macushi people called him Waurupang.']
qText: Macushi people called him Waurupang.
speaker: Rosa

qTextArr: ['No, not the river where we first camped. _These rivers._']
qText: No, not the river where we first camped. _These rivers._
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['Yes, Waurupang.']
qText: Yes, Waurupang.
speaker: Rosa

qTextArr: ['_This river here._']
qText: _This river here._
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['Macushi people call him all Waurupang.']
qText: Macushi people call him all Waurupang.
speaker: Rosa

qTextArr: ["It's hopeless,"]
qText: It's hopeless,
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ["John, I think it's time you had a holiday."]
qText: John, I think it's time you had a holiday.
speaker: Mrs Beaver

qTextArr: ['A holiday what from, mumsy?']
qText: A holiday what from, mumsy?
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["A change... I'm going to California in July. To the Fischbaums--Mrs\nArnold Fischbaum, not the one who lives in Paris. I think it would do\nyou good to come with me."]
qText:
A change... I'm going to California in July. To the Fischbaums--Mrs
Arnold Fischbaum, not the one who lives in Paris. I think it would do
you good to come with me.
speaker: Mrs Beaver

qTextArr: ['Yes, mumsy.']
qText: Yes, mumsy.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["You _would_ like it, wouldn't you?"]
qText: You _would_ like it, wouldn't you?
speaker: Mrs Beaver

qTextArr: ["Me? Yes, I'd like it."]
qText: Me? Yes, I'd like it.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["You've picked up that way of talking from Brenda. It sounds ridiculous\nin a man."]
qText:
You've picked up that way of talking from Brenda. It sounds ridiculous
in a man.
speaker: Mrs Beaver

qTextArr: ['Sorry, mumsy.']
qText: Sorry, mumsy.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["All right then, that's settled."]
qText: All right then, that's settled.
speaker: Mrs Beaver

qTextArr: ["We can't go on breaking into tinned stores,", 'The men must go out and shoot something.']
qText: We can't go on breaking into tinned stores, The men must go out and shoot something.
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['No birds, no animals here,', 'All gone. Maybe they get\nsome fish.']
qText:
No birds, no animals here, All gone. Maybe they get
some fish.
speaker: Rosa

qTextArr:
['This is clearly Amazon water,', 'It probably flows
into the Rio Branco or the Rio Negro. The Pie-wies live along the bank,
and the City, from all accounts, must be downstream of us, up one of the
tributaries. When we reach the first Pie-wie village we will be able to
get guides.']
qText:
This is clearly Amazon water, It probably flows
into the Rio Branco or the Rio Negro. The Pie-wies live along the bank,
and the City, from all accounts, must be downstream of us, up one of the
tributaries. When we reach the first Pie-wie village we will be able to
get guides.
speaker: Dr Messinger
menEnts: [[], [['Dr Messinger', 'Tony Last'], ['Dr Messinger', 'Tony Last'], ['Dr Messinger', 'Tony Last']]]

qTextArr: ['When will the boats be ready? Ask\nthe men.']
qText:
When will the boats be ready? Ask
the men.
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['Just now.']
qText: Just now.
speaker: Rosa

qTextArr: ['How many days--four?--five?--how many?']
qText: How many days--four?--five?--how many?
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['No, not many. Boats finish just now.']
qText: No, not many. Boats finish just now.
speaker: Rosa

qTextArr:
["We shall take eight men with us. Four can stay behind with the women to
guard the camp. Once we are among the Pie-wies, everything will be easy.
These Macushis can go home then. I don't think they will rob the stores.
There is nothing here that would be much use to them."]
qText:
We shall take eight men with us. Four can stay behind with the women to
guard the camp. Once we are among the Pie-wies, everything will be easy.
These Macushis can go home then. I don't think they will rob the stores.
There is nothing here that would be much use to them.
speaker: Dr Messinger
menEnts: [[['Dr Messinger', 'Tony Last'], ['Dr Messinger', 'Tony Last'], ['Dr Messinger', 'Tony Last']]]

qTextArr: ["Hadn't we better keep Rosa with us to act as interpreter with the\nMacushis?"]
qText:
Hadn't we better keep Rosa with us to act as interpreter with the
Macushis?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Yes, perhaps we had. I will tell her.']
qText: Yes, perhaps we had. I will tell her.
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['Rosa, we have decided to take you down the river with us. We need you\nto help us talk to the men. Understand?']
qText:
Rosa, we have decided to take you down the river with us. We need you
to help us talk to the men. Understand?
speaker: Dr Messinger
menEnts: [[['Rosa'], ['Dr Messinger', 'Tony Last'], ['Rosa'], ['Dr Messinger', 'Tony Last'], ['Dr Messinger', 'Tony Last'], ['Dr Messinger', 'Tony Last']]]

qTextArr: ['Understand?']
qText: Understand?
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr:
['Listen, Rosa, all women and four men stay here in camp. Eight men come
in boats to Pie-wie village. You come with boats. When we reach Pie-wie
village, you and eight men and boats go back to camp to other women and
men. Then back to Macushi country. Understand?']
qText:
Listen, Rosa, all women and four men stay here in camp. Eight men come
in boats to Pie-wie village. You come with boats. When we reach Pie-wie
village, you and eight men and boats go back to camp to other women and
men. Then back to Macushi country. Understand?
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['Macushi peoples no go with Pie-wie peoples.']
qText: Macushi peoples no go with Pie-wie peoples.
speaker: Rosa

qTextArr: ['I am not asking you to go _with_ Pie-wie people. You and the men take\nus as far as Pie-wies, then you go back to Macushi people. Understand?']
qText:
I am not asking you to go _with_ Pie-wie people. You and the men take
us as far as Pie-wies, then you go back to Macushi people. Understand?
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['Macushi peoples there,', 'Pie-wie peoples there,', 'Macushi peoples no go with Pie-wie peoples.']
qText: Macushi peoples there, Pie-wie peoples there, Macushi peoples no go with Pie-wie peoples.
speaker: Rosa

qTextArr: ['Now listen, Rosa. You are sensible, civilized woman. You lived two\nyears with black gentleman, Mr Forbes. You like cigarettes--']
qText:
Now listen, Rosa. You are sensible, civilized woman. You lived two
years with black gentleman, Mr Forbes. You like cigarettes--
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['Yes, give me cigarettes.']
qText: Yes, give me cigarettes.
speaker: Rosa

qTextArr: ['You come with men in boats, I give you plenty, plenty cigarettes.']
qText: You come with men in boats, I give you plenty, plenty cigarettes.
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['Listen. You will have your man and seven others to protect you. How can\nwe talk with men without you?']
qText:
Listen. You will have your man and seven others to protect you. How can
we talk with men without you?
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['Men no go,']
qText: Men no go,
speaker: Rosa

qTextArr: ['Of course the men will go. The only question is, will you come too?']
qText: Of course the men will go. The only question is, will you come too?
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['Macushi peoples no go with Pie-wie peoples,']
qText: Macushi peoples no go with Pie-wie peoples,
speaker: Rosa

qTextArr: ['Oh God,', "All right, we'll talk about it in\nthe morning."]
qText:
Oh God, All right, we'll talk about it in
the morning.
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['You give me cigarette....']
qText: You give me cigarette....
speaker: Rosa

qTextArr: ["It's going to be awkward if that woman doesn't come."]
qText: It's going to be awkward if that woman doesn't come.
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ["It's going to be much more awkward if none of them come,"]
qText: It's going to be much more awkward if none of them come,
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["We're all right for stores,", "There's enough for\nthree weeks at the shortest and we are bound to come across the Pie-wies\nin a day or two. We will start to-morrow."]
qText:
We're all right for stores, There's enough for
three weeks at the shortest and we are bound to come across the Pie-wies
in a day or two. We will start to-morrow.
speaker: Dr Messinger
menEnts: [[['Dr Messinger', 'Tony Last']], [['Dr Messinger', 'Tony Last'], ['Dr Messinger', 'Tony Last']]]

qTextArr: ['We start to-morrow,']
qText: We start to-morrow,
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['Yes, just now.']
qText: Yes, just now.
speaker: Rosa

qTextArr: ['Tell the men what I told you last night. Eight men to come in boats,\nothers wait here. You come in boats. All these stores stay here. All\nthese stores go in boats. You tell men that.']
qText:
Tell the men what I told you last night. Eight men to come in boats,
others wait here. You come in boats. All these stores stay here. All
these stores go in boats. You tell men that.
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['Understand?']
qText: Understand?
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['No peoples go in boats,', 'All peoples go this way,', 'To-morrow or next day all people go back to village.']
qText: No peoples go in boats, All peoples go this way, To-morrow or next day all people go back to village.
speaker: Rosa

qTextArr: ['You tell the men to\ncome here']
qText:
You tell the men to
come here
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ["It's no use threatening them,", "They are a queer, timid lot. If\nyou threaten them they take fright and disappear, leaving you stranded.\nDon't worry, I shall be able to persuade them."]
qText:
It's no use threatening them, They are a queer, timid lot. If
you threaten them they take fright and disappear, leaving you stranded.
Don't worry, I shall be able to persuade them.
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ["We'd better go across and talk to them."]
qText: We'd better go across and talk to them.
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ["What's the matter?", 'I told you to bring the men\nhere.']
qText:
What's the matter? I told you to bring the men
here.
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['So Macushi people are cowards. They are afraid of Pie-wie people.']
qText: So Macushi people are cowards. They are afraid of Pie-wie people.
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['It is the cassava field,', 'We must go back to dig the\ncassava. Otherwise it will be bad.']
qText:
It is the cassava field, We must go back to dig the
cassava. Otherwise it will be bad.
speaker: Rosa

qTextArr: ['Listen. I want the men for one, two weeks. No more. After that, all\nfinish. They can go home.']
qText:
Listen. I want the men for one, two weeks. No more. After that, all
finish. They can go home.
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['It is the time to dig the cassava. Macushi people dig cassava before\nthe big rains. All people go home just now.']
qText:
It is the time to dig the cassava. Macushi people dig cassava before
the big rains. All people go home just now.
speaker: Rosa

qTextArr: ["It's pure blackmail,", "Let's get out some trade\ngoods."]
qText:
It's pure blackmail, Let's get out some trade
goods.
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['You give me this,', 'Give me this,']
qText: You give me this, Give me this,
speaker: Rosa

qTextArr: ['Each man can choose three things from this box if he comes in the\nboats.']
qText:
Each man can choose three things from this box if he comes in the
boats.
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['Macushi peoples dig cassava field just\nnow.']
qText:
Macushi peoples dig cassava field just
now.
speaker: Rosa

qTextArr: ["It's no good,", "We shall have to try with the mice. I wanted to keep them\ntill we reached the Pie-wies. It's a pity. But they'll fall for the\nmice, you see. I _know_ the Indian mind.", "Well, I'm damned,", "that's better than I expected."]
qText:
It's no good, We shall have to try with the mice. I wanted to keep them
till we reached the Pie-wies. It's a pity. But they'll fall for the
mice, you see. I _know_ the Indian mind. Well, I'm damned, that's better than I expected.
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['More than you expected, anyway.']
qText: More than you expected, anyway.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Oh, it's all right. They'll come back. I know them."]
qText: Oh, it's all right. They'll come back. I know them.
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ["We'd better make a fire.\nThey'll come back when it is dark."]
qText:
We'd better make a fire.
They'll come back when it is dark.
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ["We'd better get some supper,"]
qText: We'd better get some supper,
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['We shall find them all here in the morning,', "They're an odd bunch."]
qText: We shall find them all here in the morning, They're an odd bunch.
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ["Let's have the window open,", "It's stuffy in here."]
qText: Let's have the window open, It's stuffy in here.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["It's quite light,"]
qText: It's quite light,
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["After five. Oughtn't we to go to bed?"]
qText: After five. Oughtn't we to go to bed?
speaker: John Beaver

qText: Yes.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Only another week and then all the parties will be over,']
qText: Only another week and then all the parties will be over,
speaker: John Beaver

qText: Yes.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["Well, let's go."]
qText: Well, let's go.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["All right. Can you pay? I just haven't any money."]
qText: All right. Can you pay? I just haven't any money.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Eight shillings,', 'How does Daisy expect to make a success of the place when she charges\nprices like that?']
qText:
Eight shillings, How does Daisy expect to make a success of the place when she charges
prices like that?
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['It does seem a lot.... So you really _are_ going to America?']
qText: It does seem a lot.... So you really _are_ going to America?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['I must. Mother has taken the tickets.']
qText: I must. Mother has taken the tickets.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["Nothing I've said to-night makes any difference?"]
qText: Nothing I've said to-night makes any difference?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["Darling, don't go on. We've been through all that. You know it's the\nonly thing that _can_ happen. Why spoil the last week?"]
qText:
Darling, don't go on. We've been through all that. You know it's the
only thing that _can_ happen. Why spoil the last week?
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["You _have_ enjoyed the summer, haven't you?"]
qText: You _have_ enjoyed the summer, haven't you?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Of course... well, shall we go?']
qText: Of course... well, shall we go?
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["Yes. You needn't bother to see me home."]
qText: Yes. You needn't bother to see me home.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["Sure you don't mind? It _is_ miles out of the way and it's late."]
qText: Sure you don't mind? It _is_ miles out of the way and it's late.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ["There's no knowing what I mind."]
qText: There's no knowing what I mind.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["Brenda, darling, for heaven's sake... It isn't like you to go on like\nthis."]
qText:
Brenda, darling, for heaven's sake... It isn't like you to go on like
this.
speaker: John Beaver

qTextArr: ['I never was one for making myself expensive.']
qText: I never was one for making myself expensive.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['The situation is grave,', 'But not desperate.']
qText: The situation is grave, But not desperate.
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ["It was just a passing attack, wasn't it?", "I shall be\nperfectly fit to-morrow, shan't I?"]
qText:
It was just a passing attack, wasn't it? I shall be
perfectly fit to-morrow, shan't I?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['I hope so,']
qText: I hope so,
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['I feel\ngrand,']
qText:
I feel
grand,
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Good.']
qText: Good.
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ["We've got to go on,", "We can't be far from a village\nnow."]
qText:
We've got to go on, We can't be far from a village
now.
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ["I feel awful. Wouldn't it be better to wait a day till I am perfectly\nfit again?"]
qText:
I feel awful. Wouldn't it be better to wait a day till I am perfectly
fit again?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["It's no good waiting. We've got to get on. D'you think you can manage\nto get into the canoe?"]
qText:
It's no good waiting. We've got to get on. D'you think you can manage
to get into the canoe?
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['So the Indians came back?']
qText: So the Indians came back?
speaker: Tony Last

qText: Yes.
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['I knew they would. Silly of them to be scared by a toy. I suppose the\nothers are following.']
qText:
I knew they would. Silly of them to be scared by a toy. I suppose the
others are following.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Yes, I expect so. Try and sit still.']
qText: Yes, I expect so. Try and sit still.
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['Damned fool, being frightened of a toy mouse,']
qText: Damned fool, being frightened of a toy mouse,
speaker: Tony Last
refExp: Tony said derisively to the woman amidships

qTextArr: ["I'm sorry,", "I didn't see it was you. You wouldn't be frightened of a toy\nmouse."]
qText:
I'm sorry, I didn't see it was you. You wouldn't be frightened of a toy
mouse.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr:
["That's what poise means,", 'D'you know, I once saw a
questionnaire that people had to fill in when they applied for a job in
an American firm, and one of the things they had to answer was "Have you
poise?"']
qText:
That's what poise means, D'you know, I once saw a
questionnaire that people had to fill in when they applied for a job in
an American firm, and one of the things they had to answer was "Have you
poise?"
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["What was so absurd\nabout the question was that they only had the applicant's word for it,", 'I mean--is it a sign of poise to think you\nhave it?']
qText:
What was so absurd
about the question was that they only had the applicant's word for it, I mean--is it a sign of poise to think you
have it?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Just sit quiet here while I sling your hammock.']
qText: Just sit quiet here while I sling your hammock.
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ["Yes, I'll sit here with Brenda. I am so glad she could come. She must\nhave caught the three-eighteen."]
qText:
Yes, I'll sit here with Brenda. I am so glad she could come. She must
have caught the three-eighteen.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["You're down to normal again."]
qText: You're down to normal again.
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ["Thank God. I've been pretty ill, haven't I? I can't remember much."]
qText: Thank God. I've been pretty ill, haven't I? I can't remember much.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["How d'you feel?"]
qText: How d'you feel?
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['Grand,', "Of course, I haven't eaten anything. I expect\nit will be a day or two before I'm really well."]
qText:
Grand, Of course, I haven't eaten anything. I expect
it will be a day or two before I'm really well.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['See if you can drink this.']
qText: See if you can drink this.
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['Are we going on to-day?']
qText: Are we going on to-day?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["We'll think about it."]
qText: We'll think about it.
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr:
["I think I'd better
explain things. It's no use your thinking you are cured because you are
out of fever for one day. That's the way it goes. One day fever and one
day normal. It may take a week or it may take much longer. That's a
thing we've got to face. I can't risk taking you in the canoe. You
nearly upset us several times the day before yesterday."]
qText:
I think I'd better
explain things. It's no use your thinking you are cured because you are
out of fever for one day. That's the way it goes. One day fever and one
day normal. It may take a week or it may take much longer. That's a
thing we've got to face. I can't risk taking you in the canoe. You
nearly upset us several times the day before yesterday.
speaker: Dr Messinger
menEnts: [[['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Dr Messinger', 'Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Dr Messinger', 'Tony Last']]]

qTextArr: ['I thought there was someone there I knew.']
qText: I thought there was someone there I knew.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr:
["You thought a lot of things. It'll go on like that. Meanwhile we've
provisions for about ten days. There's no immediate anxiety there but
it's a thing to remember. Besides, what you need is a roof over your
head and constant nursing. If only we were at a village...."]
qText:
You thought a lot of things. It'll go on like that. Meanwhile we've
provisions for about ten days. There's no immediate anxiety there but
it's a thing to remember. Besides, what you need is a roof over your
head and constant nursing. If only we were at a village....
speaker: Dr Messinger
menEnts: [[['Tony Last'], ['Dr Messinger', 'Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Dr Messinger', 'Tony Last']]]

qTextArr: ["I'm afraid I'm being a great nuisance."]
qText: I'm afraid I'm being a great nuisance.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["That's not the point. The thing is to find what is best for us to do."]
qText: That's not the point. The thing is to find what is best for us to do.
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ["I'm going to fix\nup the tarpaulin as a roof."]
qText:
I'm going to fix
up the tarpaulin as a roof.
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ["Look here, why don't\nyou leave me here and go down the river for help?"]
qText:
Look here, why don't
you leave me here and go down the river for help?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["I thought of that. It's too big a risk."]
qText: I thought of that. It's too big a risk.
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['How long\nhave we been here?']
qText:
How long
have we been here?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Only three days.']
qText: Only three days.
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['What time is it now?']
qText: What time is it now?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Getting on for ten in the morning.']
qText: Getting on for ten in the morning.
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['I feel awful.']
qText: I feel awful.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr:
['I am going downstream for the day,', "to see if there's any sign of a village. I hate leaving you but
it's a chance worth taking. I shall be able to get a long way in the
canoe now it's empty. Lie quiet. Don't move from the hammock. I shall be
back before night. I hope with some Indians to help."]
qText:
I am going downstream for the day, to see if there's any sign of a village. I hate leaving you but
it's a chance worth taking. I shall be able to get a long way in the
canoe now it's empty. Lie quiet. Don't move from the hammock. I shall be
back before night. I hope with some Indians to help.
speaker: Dr Messinger

qTextArr: ['All right,']
qText: All right,
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Mr Graceful,', "I've got to have some more money."]
qText: Mr Graceful, I've got to have some more money.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['I should have thought that was really\na question for your bank manager. I understand that your securities are\nin your own name and that the dividends are paid into your account.']
qText:
I should have thought that was really
a question for your bank manager. I understand that your securities are
in your own name and that the dividends are paid into your account.
speaker: Mr Graceful

qTextArr: ["They never seem to pay dividends nowadays. Besides, it's really very\ndifficult to live on so little."]
qText:
They never seem to pay dividends nowadays. Besides, it's really very
difficult to live on so little.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['No doubt. No doubt.']
qText: No doubt. No doubt.
speaker: Mr Graceful

qTextArr: ["Mr Last left you with power of attorney, didn't he?"]
qText: Mr Last left you with power of attorney, didn't he?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr:
["With strictly limited powers, Lady Brenda. I am instructed to pay the
wage bill at Hetton and all expenses connected with the upkeep of the
estate--he is putting in new bathrooms and restoring some decorations in
the morning-room which had been demolished. But I am afraid that I have
no authority to draw on Mr Last's account for other charges."]
qText:
With strictly limited powers, Lady Brenda. I am instructed to pay the
wage bill at Hetton and all expenses connected with the upkeep of the
estate--he is putting in new bathrooms and restoring some decorations in
the morning-room which had been demolished. But I am afraid that I have
no authority to draw on Mr Last's account for other charges.
speaker: Mr Graceful

qTextArr: ["But, Mr Graceful, I am sure he didn't intend to stay abroad so long. He\ncan't possibly have meant to leave me stranded like this, can he?...\nCan he?"]
qText:
But, Mr Graceful, I am sure he didn't intend to stay abroad so long. He
can't possibly have meant to leave me stranded like this, can he?...
Can he?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['To be quite frank, Lady\nBrenda, I fear that _was_ his intention. I raised this particular point\nshortly before his departure. He was quite resolved on the subject.']
qText:
To be quite frank, Lady
Brenda, I fear that _was_ his intention. I raised this particular point
shortly before his departure. He was quite resolved on the subject.
speaker: Mr Graceful

qTextArr: ["But is he _allowed_ to do that? I mean, haven't I got any rights under\nthe marriage settlement or anything?"]
qText:
But is he _allowed_ to do that? I mean, haven't I got any rights under
the marriage settlement or anything?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr:
['Nothing which you can claim without application to the courts. You
_might_ find solicitors who would advise you to take action. I cannot
say that I should be one of them. Mr Last would oppose any such order to
the utmost and I think that, in the present circumstances, the courts
would undoubtedly find for him. In any case it would be a prolonged,
costly and slightly undignified proceeding.']
qText:
Nothing which you can claim without application to the courts. You
_might_ find solicitors who would advise you to take action. I cannot
say that I should be one of them. Mr Last would oppose any such order to
the utmost and I think that, in the present circumstances, the courts
would undoubtedly find for him. In any case it would be a prolonged,
costly and slightly undignified proceeding.
speaker: Mr Graceful

qTextArr: ["Oh, I see... well, that's that, isn't it?"]
qText: Oh, I see... well, that's that, isn't it?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['It certainly looks as though it were.']
qText: It certainly looks as though it were.
speaker: Mr Graceful

qTextArr: ["There's one thing. Do you know, I mean, can you tell me whether Mr Last\nmade another will?"]
qText:
There's one thing. Do you know, I mean, can you tell me whether Mr Last
made another will?
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ["I'm afraid that is a thing I cannot discuss."]
qText: I'm afraid that is a thing I cannot discuss.
speaker: Mr Graceful

qTextArr: ["No, I suppose not. I'm sorry if it was wrong to ask. I just wanted to\nknow how I am with him."]
qText:
No, I suppose not. I'm sorry if it was wrong to ask. I just wanted to
know how I am with him.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr:
["Perhaps I can say as much as this to guide you.
The heirs-presumptive to Hetton are now his cousins, the Richard Lasts
at Princes Risborough. I think that your knowledge of Mr Last's
character and opinions will tell you that he would always wish his
fortune to go with the estate, in order that it may be preserved in what
he holds to be its right condition."]
qText:
Perhaps I can say as much as this to guide you.
The heirs-presumptive to Hetton are now his cousins, the Richard Lasts
at Princes Risborough. I think that your knowledge of Mr Last's
character and opinions will tell you that he would always wish his
fortune to go with the estate, in order that it may be preserved in what
he holds to be its right condition.
speaker: Mr Graceful
menEnts: [[['Brenda'], ['Richard Last', 'Mrs Last', 'Teddy Last', 'Molly Last'], ['Brenda'], ['Tony Last'], ['Brenda'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last']]]

qTextArr: ['Yes,', 'I ought to have thought of that. Well, good-bye.']
qText: Yes, I ought to have thought of that. Well, good-bye.
speaker: Brenda

qTextArr: ['Why are you dressed like that?']
qText: Why are you dressed like that?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['It looks so dirty.']
qText: It looks so dirty.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["But it isn't Wednesday?"]
qText: But it isn't Wednesday?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["I can't get as far as Pigstanton. I've got to stay here until Messinger\ncomes back. I'm ill. He told me to be quiet. He's coming this evening."]
qText:
I can't get as far as Pigstanton. I've got to stay here until Messinger
comes back. I'm ill. He told me to be quiet. He's coming this evening.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['She has a daughter. She has as much right here as Lady\nCockpurse.']
qText:
She has a daughter. She has as much right here as Lady
Cockpurse.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Ladies and gentlemen,', 'I beg you to understand that I am\nill and must not move from the hammock. Dr Messinger has given the\nclearest instructions.']
qText:
Ladies and gentlemen, I beg you to understand that I am
ill and must not move from the hammock. Dr Messinger has given the
clearest instructions.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Why are you all changing your clothes?']
qText: Why are you all changing your clothes?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Why, I didn't know you were here."]
qText: Why, I didn't know you were here.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['But how can I reach the City if I stay here?']
qText: But how can I reach the City if I stay here?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Yes, in the library. There is no point in using the dining-hall now\nthat her Ladyship has gone to live in Brazil.']
qText:
Yes, in the library. There is no point in using the dining-hall now
that her Ladyship has gone to live in Brazil.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["But I don't want the pony. I told Ben to sell her."]
qText: But I don't want the pony. I told Ben to sell her.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Very well, Ambrose.']
qText: Very well, Ambrose.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr:
["You're the first person who's spoken to me for days,", "The
others won't stop. They keep bicycling by... I'm tired... Brenda was
with me at first but she was frightened by a mechanical mouse, so she
took the canoe and went off. She said she would come back that evening
but she didn't. I expect she's staying with one of her new friends in
Brazil... You haven't seen her, have you?"]
qText:
You're the first person who's spoken to me for days, The
others won't stop. They keep bicycling by... I'm tired... Brenda was
with me at first but she was frightened by a mechanical mouse, so she
took the canoe and went off. She said she would come back that evening
but she didn't. I expect she's staying with one of her new friends in
Brazil... You haven't seen her, have you?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['You are the first stranger I have seen for a very long time.']
qText: You are the first stranger I have seen for a very long time.
speaker: Mr Todd

qTextArr: ["She was wearing a top hat when she left. You can't miss her."]
qText: She was wearing a top hat when she left. You can't miss her.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Do you see that house over there? Do you think you can manage to walk\nto it? If not, I can send some Indians to carry you.']
qText:
Do you see that house over there? Do you think you can manage to walk
to it? If not, I can send some Indians to carry you.
speaker: Mr Todd

qTextArr: ['Architecture harmonizing with local character,', "indigenous\nmaterial employed throughout. Don't let Mrs Beaver see it or she will\ncover it with chromium plating."]
qText:
Architecture harmonizing with local character, indigenous
material employed throughout. Don't let Mrs Beaver see it or she will
cover it with chromium plating.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Try and walk.']
qText: Try and walk.
speaker: Mr Todd

qTextArr: ["I'll ride your bicycle. It _was_ you I passed just now on a bicycle,\nwasn't it?... except that your beard is a different colour. His was\ngreen... green as mice."]
qText:
I'll ride your bicycle. It _was_ you I passed just now on a bicycle,
wasn't it?... except that your beard is a different colour. His was
green... green as mice.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['It is a very short way. When we get there I will give you something to\nmake you better.']
qText:
It is a very short way. When we get there I will give you something to
make you better.
speaker: Mr Todd

qTextArr: ['Very kind of you... rotten thing for a man to have his wife go away in\na canoe. That was a long time ago. Nothing to eat since.', "I say, you're English. I'm English too. My name is Last."]
qText:
Very kind of you... rotten thing for a man to have his wife go away in
a canoe. That was a long time ago. Nothing to eat since. I say, you're English. I'm English too. My name is Last.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["Well, Mr Last, you aren't to bother about anything more. You're ill and\nyou've had a rough journey. I'll take care of you."]
qText:
Well, Mr Last, you aren't to bother about anything more. You're ill and
you've had a rough journey. I'll take care of you.
speaker: Mr Todd

qTextArr: ['Are you all English?']
qText: Are you all English?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Yes, all of us.']
qText: Yes, all of us.
speaker: Mr Todd

qTextArr: ["That dark girl married a Moor... It's very lucky I met you all. I\nsuppose you're some kind of cycling club?"]
qText:
That dark girl married a Moor... It's very lucky I met you all. I
suppose you're some kind of cycling club?
speaker: Tony Last

qText: Yes.
speaker: Mr Todd

qTextArr: ["Well, I feel too tired for bicycling... never liked it much...\nyou fellows ought to get motor bicycles, you know, much faster and\nnoisier... Let's stop here."]
qText:
Well, I feel too tired for bicycling... never liked it much...
you fellows ought to get motor bicycles, you know, much faster and
noisier... Let's stop here.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["No, you must come as far as the house. It's not very much farther."]
qText: No, you must come as far as the house. It's not very much farther.
speaker: Mr Todd

qTextArr: ['All right... I suppose you would have some difficulty getting petrol\nhere.']
qText:
All right... I suppose you would have some difficulty getting petrol
here.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Lie there in the hammock.']
qText: Lie there in the hammock.
speaker: Mr Todd

qTextArr: ["That's what Messinger said. He's in love with John Beaver."]
qText: That's what Messinger said. He's in love with John Beaver.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['I will get something for you.']
qText: I will get something for you.
speaker: Mr Todd

qTextArr: ['Very good of you. Just my usual morning tray--coffee, toast, fruit. And\nthe morning papers. If her Ladyship has been called I will have it with\nher...']
qText:
Very good of you. Just my usual morning tray--coffee, toast, fruit. And
the morning papers. If her Ladyship has been called I will have it with
her...
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr:
['...You would hear better and it would be more polite if you stood
still when I addressed you instead of walking round in a circle. It is
for your own good that I am telling you... I know you are friends of my
wife and that is why you will not listen to me. But be careful. She will
say nothing cruel, she will not raise her voice, there will be no hard
words. She hopes you will be great friends afterwards as before. But she
will leave you. She will go away quietly during the night. She will take
her hammock and her rations of farine... Listen to me. I know I am not
clever but that is no reason why we should forget all courtesy. Let us
kill in the gentlest manner. I will tell you what I have learned in the
forest, where time is different. There is no City. Mrs Beaver has
covered it with chromium plating and converted it into flats. Three
guineas a week, each with a separate bathroom. Very suitable for base
love. And Polly will be there. She and Mrs Beaver under the fallen
battlements...']
qText:
...You would hear better and it would be more polite if you stood
still when I addressed you instead of walking round in a circle. It is
for your own good that I am telling you... I know you are friends of my
wife and that is why you will not listen to me. But be careful. She will
say nothing cruel, she will not raise her voice, there will be no hard
words. She hopes you will be great friends afterwards as before. But she
will leave you. She will go away quietly during the night. She will take
her hammock and her rations of farine... Listen to me. I know I am not
clever but that is no reason why we should forget all courtesy. Let us
kill in the gentlest manner. I will tell you what I have learned in the
forest, where time is different. There is no City. Mrs Beaver has
covered it with chromium plating and converted it into flats. Three
guineas a week, each with a separate bathroom. Very suitable for base
love. And Polly will be there. She and Mrs Beaver under the fallen
battlements...
speaker: Tony Last
refExp: his guest was bolt upright astride the hammock talking

qTextArr: ['Nasty medicine,']
qText: Nasty medicine,
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ["It's very nasty,", 'but it does do good.']
qText: It's very nasty, but it does do good.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr:
['There is medicine for everything in the forest,', 'to make
you well and to make you ill. My mother was an Indian and she taught me
many of them. I have learned others from time to time from my wives.
There are plants to cure you and give you fever, to kill you and send
you mad, to keep away snakes, to intoxicate fish so that you can pick
them out of the water with your hands like fruit from a tree. There are
medicines even I do not know. They say that it is possible to bring dead
people to life after they have begun to stink, but I have not seen it
done.']
qText:
There is medicine for everything in the forest, to make
you well and to make you ill. My mother was an Indian and she taught me
many of them. I have learned others from time to time from my wives.
There are plants to cure you and give you fever, to kill you and send
you mad, to keep away snakes, to intoxicate fish so that you can pick
them out of the water with your hands like fruit from a tree. There are
medicines even I do not know. They say that it is possible to bring dead
people to life after they have begun to stink, but I have not seen it
done.
speaker: Mr Todd
menEnts: [[], [['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last']]]

qTextArr: ['But surely you are English?']
qText: But surely you are English?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr:
['My father was--at least a Barbadian. He came to Guiana as a missionary.
He was married to a white woman but he left her in Guiana to look for
gold. Then he took my mother. The Pie-wie women are ugly but very
devoted. I have had many. Most of the men and women living in this
savannah are my children. That is why they obey--for that reason and
because I have the gun. My father lived to a great age. It is not twenty
years since he died. He was a man of education. Can you read?']
qText:
My father was--at least a Barbadian. He came to Guiana as a missionary.
He was married to a white woman but he left her in Guiana to look for
gold. Then he took my mother. The Pie-wie women are ugly but very
devoted. I have had many. Most of the men and women living in this
savannah are my children. That is why they obey--for that reason and
because I have the gun. My father lived to a great age. It is not twenty
years since he died. He was a man of education. Can you read?
speaker: Mr Todd

qTextArr: ['Yes, of course.']
qText: Yes, of course.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['It is not everyone who is so fortunate. I cannot.']
qText: It is not everyone who is so fortunate. I cannot.
speaker: Mr Todd

qTextArr: ["But I suppose you haven't much opportunity\nhere."]
qText:
But I suppose you haven't much opportunity
here.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr:
['Oh yes, that is just it. I have a _great_ many books. I will show you
when you are better. Until five years ago there was an Englishman--at
least a black man, but he was well educated in Georgetown. He died. He
used to read to me every day until he died. You shall read to me when
you are better.']
qText:
Oh yes, that is just it. I have a _great_ many books. I will show you
when you are better. Until five years ago there was an Englishman--at
least a black man, but he was well educated in Georgetown. He died. He
used to read to me every day until he died. You shall read to me when
you are better.
speaker: Mr Todd

qTextArr: ['I shall be delighted to.']
qText: I shall be delighted to.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Yes, you shall read to me,']
qText: Yes, you shall read to me,
speaker: Mr Todd

qTextArr:
["I will show you the black man's grave,", 'He was very kind. Every afternoon until he
died, for two hours, he used to read to me. I think I will put up a
cross--to commemorate his death and your arrival--a pretty idea. Do you
believe in God?']
qText:
I will show you the black man's grave, He was very kind. Every afternoon until he
died, for two hours, he used to read to me. I think I will put up a
cross--to commemorate his death and your arrival--a pretty idea. Do you
believe in God?
speaker: Mr Todd

qTextArr: ["I suppose so. I've never really thought about it much."]
qText: I suppose so. I've never really thought about it much.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['I have thought about it a _great_ deal and I still do not know...\nDickens did.']
qText:
I have thought about it a _great_ deal and I still do not know...
Dickens did.
speaker: Mr Todd

qTextArr: ['I suppose so.']
qText: I suppose so.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Oh yes, it is apparent in all his books. You will see.']
qText: Oh yes, it is apparent in all his books. You will see.
speaker: Mr Todd

qTextArr: ['Now I think you are well enough to see the books.']
qText: Now I think you are well enough to see the books.
speaker: Mr Todd

qTextArr: ['It has been hard to keep out the worms and ants. Two are practically\ndestroyed. But there is an oil the Indians make that is useful.']
qText:
It has been hard to keep out the worms and ants. Two are practically
destroyed. But there is an oil the Indians make that is useful.
speaker: Mr Todd

qTextArr: ['It does not matter which we take first.']
qText: It does not matter which we take first.
speaker: Mr Todd

qTextArr: ['You are fond of Dickens?']
qText: You are fond of Dickens?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr:
["Why, yes, of course. More than fond, far more. You see, they are the
only books I have ever heard. My father used to read them and then later
the black man... and now you. I have heard them all several times by
now but I never get tired; there is always more to be learned and
noticed, so many characters, so many changes of scene, so many words...
I have all Dickens's books here except those that the ants devoured. It
takes a long time to read them all--more than two years."]
qText:
Why, yes, of course. More than fond, far more. You see, they are the
only books I have ever heard. My father used to read them and then later
the black man... and now you. I have heard them all several times by
now but I never get tired; there is always more to be learned and
noticed, so many characters, so many changes of scene, so many words...
I have all Dickens's books here except those that the ants devoured. It
takes a long time to read them all--more than two years.
speaker: Mr Todd

qTextArr: ['Well,', 'they will well last out my visit.']
qText: Well, they will well last out my visit.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Oh, I hope not. It is delightful to start again. Each time I think I\nfind more to enjoy and admire.']
qText:
Oh, I hope not. It is delightful to start again. Each time I think I
find more to enjoy and admire.
speaker: Mr Todd

qTextArr: ['Repeat the\nname, I have forgotten him,', 'Yes, yes, I remember her well. She\ndies, poor woman.']
qText:
Repeat the
name, I have forgotten him, Yes, yes, I remember her well. She
dies, poor woman.
speaker: Mr Todd

qTextArr: ['Now, why does she say\nthat? Does she really mean it? Did she feel faint because of the heat of\nthe fire or of something in that paper?']
qText:
Now, why does she say
that? Does she really mean it? Did she feel faint because of the heat of
the fire or of something in that paper?
speaker: Mr Todd

qTextArr: ['I\nthink the Dedlock is a very proud man,']
qText:
I
think the Dedlock is a very proud man,
speaker: Mr Todd

qTextArr: ['Mrs Jellyby does not take\nenough care of her children.']
qText:
Mrs Jellyby does not take
enough care of her children.
speaker: Mr Todd

qTextArr: ['You read beautifully,\nwith a far better accent than the black man. And you explain better. It\nis almost as though my father were here again.']
qText:
You read beautifully,
with a far better accent than the black man. And you explain better. It
is almost as though my father were here again.
speaker: Mr Todd

qTextArr: ['I enjoyed that _very_ much.\nIt was an extremely distressing chapter. But, if I remember it rightly,\nit will all turn out well.']
qText:
I enjoyed that _very_ much.
It was an extremely distressing chapter. But, if I remember it rightly,
it will all turn out well.
speaker: Mr Todd

qTextArr: ['We still have a lot to get through. I\nhope I shall be able to finish it before I go.']
qText:
We still have a lot to get through. I
hope I shall be able to finish it before I go.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Oh yes,', 'Do not disturb yourself about that. You will\nhave time to finish it, my friend.']
qText:
Oh yes, Do not disturb yourself about that. You will
have time to finish it, my friend.
speaker: Mr Todd

qTextArr: ['You know, Mr Todd, the time has come when I must be thinking about\ngetting back to civilization. I have already imposed myself on your\nhospitality far too long.']
qText:
You know, Mr Todd, the time has come when I must be thinking about
getting back to civilization. I have already imposed myself on your
hospitality far too long.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['How soon do you think I shall be able to get a boat?... I said, how\nsoon do you think I shall be able to get a boat? I appreciate all your\nkindness to me more than I can say, but...']
qText:
How soon do you think I shall be able to get a boat?... I said, how
soon do you think I shall be able to get a boat? I appreciate all your
kindness to me more than I can say, but...
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['My friend, any kindness I may have shown is amply repaid by your\nreading of Dickens. Do not let us mention the subject again.']
qText:
My friend, any kindness I may have shown is amply repaid by your
reading of Dickens. Do not let us mention the subject again.
speaker: Mr Todd

qTextArr: ["Well, I'm very glad you have enjoyed it. I have, too. But I really must\nbe thinking of getting back..."]
qText:
Well, I'm very glad you have enjoyed it. I have, too. But I really must
be thinking of getting back...
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Yes,', 'The black man was like that. He thought of it all\nthe time. But he died here...']
qText:
Yes, The black man was like that. He thought of it all
the time. But he died here...
speaker: Mr Todd

qTextArr: ['Forgive me, Mr Todd, but I really must press\nthe point. When can I get a boat?']
qText:
Forgive me, Mr Todd, but I really must press
the point. When can I get a boat?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['There is no boat.']
qText: There is no boat.
speaker: Mr Todd

qTextArr: ['Well, the Indians can build one.']
qText: Well, the Indians can build one.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['You must wait for the rains. There is not enough water in the river\nnow.']
qText:
You must wait for the rains. There is not enough water in the river
now.
speaker: Mr Todd

qTextArr: ['How long will that be?']
qText: How long will that be?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['A month... two months...']
qText: A month... two months...
speaker: Mr Todd

qTextArr: ['Now it is time to make preparations to go.']
qText: Now it is time to make preparations to go.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Oh, that is impossible. The Indians will not make a boat during the\nrainy season--it is one of their superstitions.']
qText:
Oh, that is impossible. The Indians will not make a boat during the
rainy season--it is one of their superstitions.
speaker: Mr Todd

qTextArr: ['You might have told me.']
qText: You might have told me.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Did I not mention it? I forgot.']
qText: Did I not mention it? I forgot.
speaker: Mr Todd

qTextArr:
['Mr Last, the Indians tell me that
you have been trying to speak with them. It is easier that you say
anything you wish through me. You realize, do you not, that they would
do nothing without my authority. They regard themselves, quite rightly
in many cases, as my children.']
qText:
Mr Last, the Indians tell me that
you have been trying to speak with them. It is easier that you say
anything you wish through me. You realize, do you not, that they would
do nothing without my authority. They regard themselves, quite rightly
in many cases, as my children.
speaker: Mr Todd
menEnts: [[['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last']]]

qTextArr: ['Well, as a matter of fact, I was asking them about a canoe.']
qText: Well, as a matter of fact, I was asking them about a canoe.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['So they gave me to understand... and now if you have finished your\nmeal perhaps we might have another chapter. I am quite absorbed in the\nbook.']
qText:
So they gave me to understand... and now if you have finished your
meal perhaps we might have another chapter. I am quite absorbed in the
book.
speaker: Mr Todd

qTextArr:
['Mr Todd,', 'I must speak frankly. You saved my life, and when
I get back to civilization I will reward you to the best of my ability.
I will give you anything within reason. But at present you are keeping
me here against my will. I demand to be released.']
qText:
Mr Todd, I must speak frankly. You saved my life, and when
I get back to civilization I will reward you to the best of my ability.
I will give you anything within reason. But at present you are keeping
me here against my will. I demand to be released.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['But, my friend, what is keeping you? You are under no restraint. Go\nwhen you like.']
qText:
But, my friend, what is keeping you? You are under no restraint. Go
when you like.
speaker: Mr Todd

qTextArr: ["You know very well that I can't get away without your help."]
qText: You know very well that I can't get away without your help.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['In that case you must humour an old man. Read me another chapter.']
qText: In that case you must humour an old man. Read me another chapter.
speaker: Mr Todd

qTextArr: ['Mr Todd, I swear by anything you like that when I get to Man?os I will\nfind someone to take my place. I will pay a man to read to you all day.']
qText:
Mr Todd, I swear by anything you like that when I get to Man?os I will
find someone to take my place. I will pay a man to read to you all day.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['But I have no need of another man. You read so well.']
qText: But I have no need of another man. You read so well.
speaker: Mr Todd

qTextArr: ['I have read for the last time.']
qText: I have read for the last time.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['I hope not,']
qText: I hope not,
speaker: Mr Todd

qTextArr: ['May I trouble you to read that passage\nagain? It is one I particularly enjoy.']
qText:
May I trouble you to read that passage
again? It is one I particularly enjoy.
speaker: Mr Todd

qTextArr: ['It is one of the local feast days,', "and they have been\nmaking _pivari_. You may not like it but you should try some. We will go\nacross to this man's home to-night."]
qText:
It is one of the local feast days, and they have been
making _pivari_. You may not like it but you should try some. We will go
across to this man's home to-night.
speaker: Mr Todd

qTextArr: ['You must drink it all without lowering the cup. That is the etiquette.']
qText: You must drink it all without lowering the cup. That is the etiquette.
speaker: Mr Todd

qTextArr: ['Ah, my friend, you are late for the reading this afternoon. There is\nscarcely another half hour of light. How do you feel?']
qText:
Ah, my friend, you are late for the reading this afternoon. There is
scarcely another half hour of light. How do you feel?
speaker: Mr Todd

qTextArr: ["Rotten. That drink doesn't seem to agree with me."]
qText: Rotten. That drink doesn't seem to agree with me.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['I will give you something to make you better. The forest has remedies\nfor everything; to make you awake and to make you sleep.']
qText:
I will give you something to make you better. The forest has remedies
for everything; to make you awake and to make you sleep.
speaker: Mr Todd

qTextArr: ["You haven't seen my watch anywhere?"]
qText: You haven't seen my watch anywhere?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['You have missed it?']
qText: You have missed it?
speaker: Mr Todd

qTextArr: ["Yes. I thought I was wearing it. I say, I've never slept so long."]
qText: Yes. I thought I was wearing it. I say, I've never slept so long.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Not since you were a baby. Do you know how long? Two days.']
qText: Not since you were a baby. Do you know how long? Two days.
speaker: Mr Todd

qTextArr: ["Nonsense. I can't have."]
qText: Nonsense. I can't have.
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr: ['Yes, indeed. It is a long time. It is a pity because you missed our\nguests.']
qText:
Yes, indeed. It is a long time. It is a pity because you missed our
guests.
speaker: Mr Todd

qTextArr: ['Guests?']
qText: Guests?
speaker: Tony Last

qTextArr:
['Why, yes. I have been quite gay while you were asleep. Three men from
outside. Englishmen. It is a pity you missed them. A pity for them, too,
as they particularly wished to see you. But what could I do? You were so
sound asleep. They had come all the way to find you, so--I thought you
would not mind--as you could not greet them yourself, I gave them a
little souvenir, your watch. They wanted something to take back to
England where a reward is being offered for news of you. They were very
pleased with it. And they took some photographs of the little cross I
put up to commemorate your coming. They were pleased with that, too.
They were very easily pleased. But I do not suppose they will visit us
again, our life here is so retired... no pleasures except reading... I
do not suppose we shall ever have visitors again... well, well, I will
get you some medicine to make you feel better. Your head aches, does it
not?... We will not have any Dickens to-day... but to-morrow, and the
day after that, and the day after that. Let us read _Little Dorrit_
again. There are passages in that book I can never hear without the
temptation to weep.']
qText:
Why, yes. I have been quite gay while you were asleep. Three men from
outside. Englishmen. It is a pity you missed them. A pity for them, too,
as they particularly wished to see you. But what could I do? You were so
sound asleep. They had come all the way to find you, so--I thought you
would not mind--as you could not greet them yourself, I gave them a
little souvenir, your watch. They wanted something to take back to
England where a reward is being offered for news of you. They were very
pleased with it. And they took some photographs of the little cross I
put up to commemorate your coming. They were pleased with that, too.
They were very easily pleased. But I do not suppose they will visit us
again, our life here is so retired... no pleasures except reading... I
do not suppose we shall ever have visitors again... well, well, I will
get you some medicine to make you feel better. Your head aches, does it
not?... We will not have any Dickens to-day... but to-morrow, and the
day after that, and the day after that. Let us read _Little Dorrit_
again. There are passages in that book I can never hear without the
temptation to weep.
speaker: Mr Todd
menEnts: [[['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last', 'Mr Todd'], ['Mr Todd', 'Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Mr Todd', 'Tony Last'], ['Mr Todd', 'Tony Last']]]

qTextArr: ['Molly, you have rabbit-feed on your head again.']
qText: Molly, you have rabbit-feed on your head again.
speaker: Mrs Last

qTextArr: ['Oh well, I shall have to tidy up anyway before the jamboree.']
qText: Oh well, I shall have to tidy up anyway before the jamboree.
speaker: Molly Last

qTextArr: ['_Jamboree?_ Is nothing sacred to you children?']
qText: _Jamboree?_ Is nothing sacred to you children?
speaker: Richard Last

qTextArr:
['Another casualty at the stinkeries. That little vixen we
bought from the people at Okehampton got her brush bitten off during the
night. Must have got it through the wire into the next cage. Tricky
birds, foxes.']
qText:
Another casualty at the stinkeries. That little vixen we
bought from the people at Okehampton got her brush bitten off during the
night. Must have got it through the wire into the next cage. Tricky
birds, foxes.
speaker: Teddy Last

qTextArr: ["I'm sorry if I'm late."]
qText: I'm sorry if I'm late.
speaker: Agnes
refExp: She kissed her father and mother and said

qTextArr: ["_If_ you're late..."]
qText: _If_ you're late...
speaker: Richard Last

qTextArr:
['How long will the show last?', "I've got to run over to
Bayton and get some more rabbits for the foxes. Chivers says he's got
about fifty waiting for me. We can't shoot enough here. Greedy little
beggars."]
qText:
How long will the show last? I've got to run over to
Bayton and get some more rabbits for the foxes. Chivers says he's got
about fifty waiting for me. We can't shoot enough here. Greedy little
beggars.
speaker: Teddy Last

qTextArr: ["It will be all over by half-past eleven. Mr Tendril isn't going to\npreach a sermon. It's just as well really. He's got it into his head\nthat Cousin Tony died in Afghanistan."]
qText:
It will be all over by half-past eleven. Mr Tendril isn't going to
preach a sermon. It's just as well really. He's got it into his head
that Cousin Tony died in Afghanistan.
speaker: Unknowable

qTextArr: ["There's a letter here from Cousin Brenda. She's very sorry but she\ncan't get down here for the dedication."]
qText:
There's a letter here from Cousin Brenda. She's very sorry but she
can't get down here for the dedication.
speaker: Unknowable

qText: Oh.
speaker: Unknowable

qTextArr: ['She says that Jock has a three-line whip for this afternoon.']
qText: She says that Jock has a three-line whip for this afternoon.
speaker: Unknowable

qText: Oh.
speaker: Unknowable

qTextArr: ['She could have come without him,']
qText: She could have come without him,
speaker: Molly Last

qTextArr: ['She sends her love to us all and to Hetton.']
qText: She sends her love to us all and to Hetton.
speaker: Unknowable

qTextArr: ["Well, I think it's a jolly good thing,", "She couldn't show\nmuch widowly grief. It didn't take her long to get hitched up again."]
qText:
Well, I think it's a jolly good thing, She couldn't show
much widowly grief. It didn't take her long to get hitched up again.
speaker: Molly Last

qTextArr: ['_Molly!_']
qText: _Molly!_
speaker: Unknowable

qTextArr: ['And you know you think the same.']
qText: And you know you think the same.
speaker: Molly Last

qTextArr: ['I will not allow you to talk like that about Cousin Brenda, whatever we\nthink. She had a perfect right to marry again and I hope she and Mr\nGrant-Menzies are very happy.']
qText:
I will not allow you to talk like that about Cousin Brenda, whatever we
think. She had a perfect right to marry again and I hope she and Mr
Grant-Menzies are very happy.
speaker: Unknowable

qTextArr: ['She was always jolly decent to us when she used to live here,']
qText: She was always jolly decent to us when she used to live here,
speaker: Agnes

qTextArr: ['Well, I should hope so,', "After all, it's our place."]
qText: Well, I should hope so, After all, it's our place.
speaker: Teddy Last

qTextArr:
["I'm glad we put that up,", "You know, I should never have
thought of it, if it had not been for a Mrs Beaver. She wrote to me as
soon as the news of Tony's death was published. I didn't know her at the
time. Of course we knew very few of Tony's friends."]
qText:
I'm glad we put that up, You know, I should never have
thought of it, if it had not been for a Mrs Beaver. She wrote to me as
soon as the news of Tony's death was published. I didn't know her at the
time. Of course we knew very few of Tony's friends.
speaker: Richard Last
menEnts: [[['Lady St Cloud', 'Richard Last']], [['Lady St Cloud'], ['Tony Last'], ['Molly Last', 'Mrs Last', 'Teddy Last', 'Richard Last'], ['Tony Last']]]

qTextArr: ['It was her suggestion?']
qText: It was her suggestion?
speaker: Lady St Cloud

qTextArr:
["Yes, she said that as one of Tony's closest friends she knew he would
wish to have some monument at Hetton. She was most considerate--even
offering to arrange with the contractors for it. Her own plans were more
ambitious. She proposed that we should have the chapel redecorated as a
chantry. But I think this is what he would have preferred. The stone
comes from one of our own quarries and was cut by the estate workmen."]
qText:
Yes, she said that as one of Tony's closest friends she knew he would
wish to have some monument at Hetton. She was most considerate--even
offering to arrange with the contractors for it. Her own plans were more
ambitious. She proposed that we should have the chapel redecorated as a
chantry. But I think this is what he would have preferred. The stone
comes from one of our own quarries and was cut by the estate workmen.
speaker: Richard Last
menEnts: [[['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Molly Last', 'Mrs Last', 'Teddy Last', 'Richard Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Mrs Last', 'Molly', 'Teddy', 'Richard Last', 'Agnes']]]

qTextArr: ['Yes, I think he would have preferred this,']
qText: Yes, I think he would have preferred this,
speaker: Lady St Cloud

qTextArr: ['Coming to the stinkeries?']
qText: Coming to the stinkeries?
speaker: Teddy Last

qTextArr: ["No, I'm looking after Cousin Frances. She got rather on mother's nerves\nthrough crabbing the new boiler."]
qText:
No, I'm looking after Cousin Frances. She got rather on mother's nerves
through crabbing the new boiler.
speaker: Agnes
